原文:
An elegant carriage stood in the middle of the road with a pair of spirited grey horses; there was no one in it, and the coachman had got off his box and stood by; the horses were being held by the bridle.... A mass of people had gathered round, the police standing in front. One of them held a lighted lantern which he was turning on something lying close to the wheels. Everyone was talking, shouting, exclaiming; the coachman seemed at a loss and kept repeating:
“What a misfortune! Good Lord, what a misfortune!”
Raskolnikov pushed his way in as far as he could, and succeeded at last in seeing the object of the commotion and interest. On the ground a man who had been run over lay apparently unconscious, and covered with blood; he was very badly dressed, but not like a workman. Blood was flowing from his head and face; his face was crushed, mutilated and disfigured. He was evidently badly injured.
“Merciful heaven!” wailed the coachman, “what more could I do? If I’d been driving fast or had not shouted to him, but I was going quietly, not in a hurry. Everyone could see I was going along just like everybody else. A drunken man can’t walk straight, we all know.... I saw him crossing the street, staggering and almost falling. I shouted again and a second and a third time, then I held the horses in, but he fell straight under their feet! Either he did it on purpose or he was very tipsy.... The horses are young and ready to take fright... they started, he screamed... that made them worse. That’s how it happened!”
“That’s just how it was,” a voice in the crowd confirmed.
“He shouted, that’s true, he shouted three times,” another voice declared.
“Three times it was, we all heard it,” shouted a third.
But the coachman was not very much distressed and frightened. It was evident that the carriage belonged to a rich and important person who was awaiting it somewhere; the police, of course, were in no little anxiety to avoid upsetting his arrangements. All they had to do was to take the injured man to the police station and the hospital. No one knew his name.
Meanwhile Raskolnikov had squeezed in and stooped closer over him. The lantern suddenly lighted up the unfortunate man’s face. He recognised him.
“I know him! I know him!” he shouted, pushing to the front. “It’s a government clerk retired from the service, Marmeladov. He lives close by in Kozel’s house.... Make haste for a doctor! I will pay, see?” He pulled money out of his pocket and showed it to the policeman. He was in violent agitation.
The police were glad that they had found out who the man was. Raskolnikov gave his own name and address, and, as earnestly as if it had been his father, he besought the police to carry the unconscious Marmeladov to his lodging at once.
“Just here, three houses away,” he said eagerly, “the house belongs to Kozel, a rich German. He was going home, no doubt drunk. I know him, he is a drunkard. He has a family there, a wife, children, he has one daughter.... It will take time to take him to the hospital, and there is sure to be a doctor in the house. I’ll pay, I’ll pay! At least he will be looked after at home... they will help him at once. But he’ll die before you get him to the hospital.” He managed to slip something unseen into the policeman’s hand. But the thing was straightforward and legitimate, and in any case help was closer here. They raised the injured man; people volunteered to help.
Kozel’s house was thirty yards away. Raskolnikov walked behind, carefully holding Marmeladov’s head and showing the way.
“This way, this way! We must take him upstairs head foremost. Turn round! I’ll pay, I’ll make it worth your while,” he muttered.
Katerina Ivanovna had just begun, as she always did at every free moment, walking to and fro in her little room from window to stove and back again, with her arms folded across her chest, talking to herself and coughing. Of late she had begun to talk more than ever to her eldest girl, Polenka, a child of ten, who, though there was much she did not understand, understood very well that her mother needed her, and so always watched her with her big clever eyes and strove her utmost to appear to understand. This time Polenka was undressing her little brother, who had been unwell all day and was going to bed. The boy was waiting for her to take off his shirt, which had to be washed at night. He was sitting straight and motionless on a chair, with a silent, serious face, with his legs stretched out straight before him—heels together and toes turned out.
He was listening to what his mother was saying to his sister, sitting perfectly still with pouting lips and wide-open eyes, just as all good little boys have to sit when they are undressed to go to bed. A little girl, still younger, dressed literally in rags, stood at the screen, waiting for her turn. The door on to the stairs was open to relieve them a little from the clouds of tobacco smoke which floated in from the other rooms and brought on long terrible fits of coughing in the poor, consumptive woman. Katerina Ivanovna seemed to have grown even thinner during that week and the hectic flush on her face was brighter than ever.
“You wouldn’t believe, you can’t imagine, Polenka,” she said, walking about the room, “what a happy luxurious life we had in my papa’s house and how this drunkard has brought me, and will bring you all, to ruin! Papa was a civil colonel and only a step from being a governor; so that everyone who came to see him said, ‘We look upon you, Ivan Mihailovitch, as our governor!’ When I... when...” she coughed violently, “oh, cursed life,” she cried, clearing her throat and pressing her hands to her breast, “when I... when at the last ball... at the marshal’s... Princess Bezzemelny saw me—who gave me the blessing when your father and I were married, Polenka—she asked at once ‘Isn’t that the pretty girl who danced the shawl dance at the breaking-up?’ (You must mend that tear, you must take your needle and darn it as I showed you, or to-morrow—cough, cough, cough—he will make the hole bigger,” she articulated with effort.) “Prince Schegolskoy, a kammerjunker, had just come from Petersburg then... he danced the mazurka with me and wanted to make me an offer next day; but I thanked him in flattering expressions and told him that my heart had long been another’s. That other was your father, Polya; papa was fearfully angry.... Is the water ready? Give me the shirt, and the stockings! Lida,” said she to the youngest one, “you must manage without your chemise to-night... and lay your stockings out with it... I’ll wash them together.... How is it that drunken vagabond doesn’t come in? He has worn his shirt till it looks like a dish-clout, he has torn it to rags! I’d do it all together, so as not to have to work two nights running! Oh, dear! (Cough, cough, cough, cough!) Again! What’s this?” she cried, noticing a crowd in the passage and the men, who were pushing into her room, carrying a burden. “What is it? What are they bringing? Mercy on us!”
生成:
The shrill cry of warning, lost in the cacophony of street vendors' calls and the rumble of carriage wheels, came too late. A collective gasp, a unified inhale of breath, rippled through the bustling Haymarket Square as the inevitable unfolded. Two magnificent grey horses, startled by the sudden obstacle in their path, reared up, their harnesses straining, their hooves a hair's breadth from connecting with the prone figure sprawled on the cobblestones. 

The carriage driver, a burly man with a face weathered by years under the open sky, wrestled with the reins, his curses swallowed by the growing commotion. The crowd surged forward, a tide of curiosity and morbid fascination, encircling the fallen figure and the ornate carriage that had moments before been an emblem of privilege, now a harbinger of misfortune.

Raskolnikov, adrift in his own world of troubled thoughts, was jolted out of his reverie by the sudden shift in the street's energy. He had been navigating the crowded square, his worn boots barely registering the uneven cobblestones, his mind a labyrinth of philosophical quandaries. But even his internal turmoil couldn't drown out the collective gasp of the crowd, the panicked whinny of horses, and the ensuing chaos.

He pushed his way through the throng of onlookers, their faces a mixture of horror and morbid curiosity. The air was thick with the smell of horse manure, cheap tobacco, and the unwashed bodies pressed close around him. Reaching the epicenter of the commotion, he felt a chill course through him as he recognized the crumpled figure lying amidst the cobblestones.

Marmeladov.

The retired government clerk lay unnaturally still, his limbs at awkward angles, his threadbare coat splayed around him like a discarded shroud. A thin trickle of blood traced a path from his temple, staining the grimy stones a macabre crimson. His face, usually flushed with drink, was ashen, his breath coming in shallow gasps.

"He walked right into the horses' path," the coachman was saying, his voice a mixture of annoyance and resignation. "Drunk as a lord, he was. Couldn't even stand straight. I shouted, I did, but he didn't hear a thing." He wiped his brow with the back of his hand, leaving a streak of dirt across his forehead.

The crowd murmured amongst themselves, some nodding in agreement, others casting disapproving glances at the coachman, who seemed more concerned with absolving himself of blame than with the injured man at his feet.

"Someone fetch a doctor!" a voice called out.

"Take him to the hospital!" another shouted.

Raskolnikov, ignoring the clamor around him, knelt beside Marmeladov. The man's eyes flickered open, unfocused and glassy. He moaned, a low, guttural sound that spoke of pain and terror.

"Marmeladov," Raskolnikov said, his voice low and urgent. "Can you hear me?"

Marmeladov's gaze, clouded with pain, settled on Raskolnikov's face. He attempted a smile, a ghastly, pained contortion of his lips. 

"Raskolnikov…," he rasped, his voice barely audible above the din.

"Don't try to talk," Raskolnikov said, gently pressing a hand against Marmeladov's chest, feeling the erratic thump of his heart. "We need to get you help."

He looked around at the crowd, his gaze settling on a policeman who was pushing his way towards them, his face etched with bored authority.

"Officer," Raskolnikov called out, his voice sharp and commanding. "This man needs immediate medical attention."

The policeman, a burly man with a walrus mustache and a disdainful air, surveyed the scene with a weary eye. "So I see," he said, his voice dripping with sarcasm. "And what do you propose we do about it? Public funds don't stretch to treating every drunk who stumbles into traffic."

Raskolnikov, ignoring the policeman's sneer, pulled out a crumpled ruble note from his pocket. "This is for your trouble," he said, holding out the money. "Take him to my lodgings. It's just a few streets from here."

He scribbled the address on a scrap of paper and thrust it into the policeman's hand, adding another ruble note for good measure. The policeman's demeanor shifted subtly, the initial disdain replaced by a grudging acceptance.

"Alright, alright," he muttered, pocketing the money. "Let's get him out of the way, then."

With the help of two willing bystanders, they lifted Marmeladov onto a makeshift stretcher – a battered door removed from a nearby shop. The crowd parted reluctantly, their curiosity momentarily sated. As they navigated the narrow streets, Raskolnikov sent a boy running ahead, instructing him to inform Marmeladov's wife of the situation and to summon a doctor. 

He knew the address well. He'd visited the Marmeladovs once before, drawn in by a perverse fascination with their desperate poverty and Katerina Ivanovna's fierce pride. He remembered the cramped, airless room, the threadbare furniture, the omnipresent stench of illness and despair. 

Reaching their destination, a dilapidated tenement building in one of St. Petersburg's most impoverished neighborhoods, they were greeted by a scene of frantic activity. Katerina Ivanovna, her face etched with worry and exhaustion, stood in the doorway, her three young children clinging to her skirts.

"Katerina Ivanovna," Raskolnikov said, his voice somber. "It's Marmeladov. He's been hurt."

A strangled cry escaped Katerina Ivanovna's lips, a raw, primal sound of fear and anguish. Her face, already pale, drained of all color, her eyes widening in horror.
summary:
Certainly! This passage describes a dramatic scene involving a carriage accident in a bustling street. The carriage, drawn by spirited grey horses, has run over an unconscious, badly injured man lying on the ground. The coachman, distressed but not excessively so, explains that the victim stumbled drunkenly into the horses' path despite his warnings.

Raskolnikov, pushing through the crowd, recognizes the injured man as Marmeladov, a retired government clerk. Displaying urgency and compassion, Raskolnikov insists on taking Marmeladov to his nearby home rather than the hospital, believing he can receive immediate care there. He even offers to pay for a doctor and bribes a policeman to ensure swift action.

The scene shifts to Marmeladov's impoverished home, where his consumptive wife, Katerina Ivanovna, paces the room and laments their ruined lives, particularly due to Marmeladov's alcoholism. She nostalgically recalls her once-privileged life, instructs her children in household tasks, and endures severe fits of coughing. The arrival of the injured Marmeladov carried by the crowd shocks her, and the passage ends with her exclamation of distress.

In summary, the passage juxtaposes a chaotic accident scene with the backdrop of a family's dire situation, highlighting themes of poverty, desperation, and Raskolnikov's moment of empathy.

“I know him! I know him!” he shouted, pushing to the front. “It’s a government clerk retired from the service, Marmeladov. He lives close by in Kozel’s house.... Make haste for a doctor! I will pay, see?” He pulled money out of his pocket and showed it to the policeman. He was in violent agitation.
The police were glad that they had found out who the man was. Raskolnikov gave his own name and address, and, as earnestly as if it had been his father, he besought the police to carry the unconscious Marmeladov to his lodging at once.
“Just here, three houses away,” he said eagerly, “the house belongs to Kozel, a rich German. He was going home, no doubt drunk. I know him, he is a drunkard. He has a family there, a wife, children, he has one daughter.... It will take time to take him to the hospital, and there is sure to be a doctor in the house. I’ll pay, I’ll pay! At least he will be looked after at home... they will help him at once. But he’ll die before you get him to the hospital.” He managed to slip something unseen into the policeman’s hand. But the thing was straightforward and legitimate, and in any case help was closer here. They raised the injured man; people volunteered to help.
Kozel’s house was thirty yards away. Raskolnikov walked behind, carefully holding Marmeladov’s head and showing the way.
“This way, this way! We must take him upstairs head foremost. Turn round! I’ll pay, I’ll make it worth your while,” he muttered.
Katerina Ivanovna had just begun, as she always did at every free moment, walking to and fro in her little room from window to stove and back again, with her arms folded across her chest, talking to herself and coughing. Of late she had begun to talk more than ever to her eldest girl, Polenka, a child of ten, who, though there was much she did not understand, understood very well that her mother needed her, and so always watched her with her big clever eyes and strove her utmost to appear to understand. This time Polenka was undressing her little brother, who had been unwell all day and was going to bed. The boy was waiting for her to take off his shirt, which had to be washed at night. He was sitting straight and motionless on a chair, with a silent, serious face, with his legs stretched out straight before him—heels together and toes turned out.
He was listening to what his mother was saying to his sister, sitting perfectly still with pouting lips and wide-open eyes, just as all good little boys have to sit when they are undressed to go to bed. A little girl, still younger, dressed literally in rags, stood at the screen, waiting for her turn. The door on to the stairs was open to relieve them a little from the clouds of tobacco smoke which floated in from the other rooms and brought on long terrible fits of coughing in the poor, consumptive woman. Katerina Ivanovna seemed to have grown even thinner during that week and the hectic flush on her face was brighter than ever.
“You wouldn’t believe, you can’t imagine, Polenka,” she said, walking about the room, “what a happy luxurious life we had in my papa’s house and how this drunkard has brought me, and will bring you all, to ruin! Papa was a civil colonel and only a step from being a governor; so that everyone who came to see him said, ‘We look upon you, Ivan Mihailovitch, as our governor!’ When I... when...” she coughed violently, “oh, cursed life,” she cried, clearing her throat and pressing her hands to her breast, “when I... when at the last ball... at the marshal’s... Princess Bezzemelny saw me—who gave me the blessing when your father and I were married, Polenka—she asked at once ‘Isn’t that the pretty girl who danced the shawl dance at the breaking-up?’ (You must mend that tear, you must take your needle and darn it as I showed you, or to-morrow—cough, cough, cough—he will make the hole bigger,” she articulated with effort.) “Prince Schegolskoy, a kammerjunker, had just come from Petersburg then... he danced the mazurka with me and wanted to make me an offer next day; but I thanked him in flattering expressions and told him that my heart had long been another’s. That other was your father, Polya; papa was fearfully angry.... Is the water ready? Give me the shirt, and the stockings! Lida,” said she to the youngest one, “you must manage without your chemise to-night... and lay your stockings out with it... I’ll wash them together.... How is it that drunken vagabond doesn’t come in? He has worn his shirt till it looks like a dish-clout, he has torn it to rags! I’d do it all together, so as not to have to work two nights running! Oh, dear! (Cough, cough, cough, cough!) Again! What’s this?” she cried, noticing a crowd in the passage and the men, who were pushing into her room, carrying a burden. “What is it? What are they bringing? Mercy on us!”
summary:
Certainly! This passage describes a dramatic scene involving a carriage accident in a bustling street. The carriage, drawn by spirited grey horses, has run over an unconscious, badly injured man lying on the ground. The coachman, distressed but not excessively so, explains that the victim stumbled drunkenly into the horses' path despite his warnings.

Raskolnikov, pushing through the crowd, recognizes the injured man as Marmeladov, a retired government clerk. Displaying urgency and compassion, Raskolnikov insists on taking Marmeladov to his nearby home rather than the hospital, believing he can receive immediate care there. He even offers to pay for a doctor and bribes a policeman to ensure swift action.

The scene shifts to Marmeladov's impoverished home, where his consumptive wife, Katerina Ivanovna, paces the room and laments their ruined lives, particularly due to Marmeladov's alcoholism. She nostalgically recalls her once-privileged life, instructs her children in household tasks, and endures severe fits of coughing. The arrival of the injured Marmeladov carried by the crowd shocks her, and the passage ends with her exclamation of distress.

In summary, the passage juxtaposes a chaotic accident scene with the backdrop of a family's dire situation, highlighting themes of poverty, desperation, and Raskolnikov's moment of empathy.

原文:
An elegant carriage stood in the middle of the road with a pair of spirited grey horses; there was no one in it, and the coachman had got off his box and stood by; the horses were being held by the bridle.... A mass of people had gathered round, the police standing in front. One of them held a lighted lantern which he was turning on something lying close to the wheels. Everyone was talking, shouting, exclaiming; the coachman seemed at a loss and kept repeating:
“What a misfortune! Good Lord, what a misfortune!”
Raskolnikov pushed his way in as far as he could, and succeeded at last in seeing the object of the commotion and interest. On the ground a man who had been run over lay apparently unconscious, and covered with blood; he was very badly dressed, but not like a workman. Blood was flowing from his head and face; his face was crushed, mutilated and disfigured. He was evidently badly injured.
“Merciful heaven!” wailed the coachman, “what more could I do? If I’d been driving fast or had not shouted to him, but I was going quietly, not in a hurry. Everyone could see I was going along just like everybody else. A drunken man can’t walk straight, we all know.... I saw him crossing the street, staggering and almost falling. I shouted again and a second and a third time, then I held the horses in, but he fell straight under their feet! Either he did it on purpose or he was very tipsy.... The horses are young and ready to take fright... they started, he screamed... that made them worse. That’s how it happened!”
“That’s just how it was,” a voice in the crowd confirmed.
“He shouted, that’s true, he shouted three times,” another voice declared.
“Three times it was, we all heard it,” shouted a third.
But the coachman was not very much distressed and frightened. It was evident that the carriage belonged to a rich and important person who was awaiting it somewhere; the police, of course, were in no little anxiety to avoid upsetting his arrangements. 原文:
The journey from Paris to Dresden at that time took five days and nights. On the German frontier, near Forbach, we met with stormy weather and snow, a greeting which seemed inhospitable after the spring we had already enjoyed in Paris. And, indeed, as we continued our journey through our native land once more, we found much to dishearten us, and I could not help thinking that the Frenchmen who on leaving Germany breathed more freely on reaching French soil, and unbuttoned their coats, as though passing from winter into summer, were not so very foolish after all, seeing that we, for our part, were now compelled to seek protection against this conspicuous change of temperature by being very careful to put on sufficient clothing. The unkindness of the elements became perfect torture when, later on, between Frankfort and Leipzig, we were swept into the stream of visitors to the Great Easter Fair.
The pressure on the mail-coaches was so great, that for two days and a night, amid ceaseless storm, snow and rain, we were continually changing from one wretched ‘substitute’ to another, thus turning our journey into an adventure of almost the same type as our former voyage at sea.
One solitary flash of brightness was afforded by our view of the Wartburg, which we passed during the only sunlit hour of this journey. The sight of this mountain fastness, which, from the Fulda side, is clearly visible for a long time, affected me deeply. A neighbouring ridge further on I at once christened the Horselberg, and as we drove through the valley, pictured to myself the scenery for the third act of my Tannhäuser. This scene remained so vividly in my mind, that long afterwards I was able to give Desplechin, the Parisian scene-painter, exact details when he was working out the scenery under my direction. If I had already been impressed by the significance of the fact that my first journey through the German Rhine district, so famous in legend, should have been made on my way home from Paris, it seemed an even more ominous coincidence that my first sight of Wartburg, which was so rich in historical and mythical associations, should come just at this moment. The view so warmed my heart against wind and weather, Jews and the Leipzig Fair, that in the end I arrived, on 12th April, 1842, safe and sound, with my poor, battered, half-frozen wife, in that selfsame city of Dresden which I had last seen on the occasion of my sad separation from my Minna, and my departure for my northern place of exile.
We put up at the ‘Stadt Gotha’ inn. The city, in which such momentous years of my childhood and boyhood had been spent, seemed cold and dead beneath the influences of the wild, gloomy weather. Indeed, everything there that could remind me of my youth seemed dead. No hospitable house received us. We found my wife’s parents living in cramped and dingy lodgings in very straitened circumstances, and were obliged at once to look about for a small abode for ourselves. This we found in the Topfergasse for twenty-one marks a month. After paying the necessary business visits in connection with Rienzi, and making arrangements for Minna during my brief absence, I set out on 15th April direct for Leipzig, where I saw my mother and family for the first time in six years.
During this period, which had been so eventful for my own life, my mother had undergone a great change in her domestic position through the death of Rosalie. She was living in a pleasant roomy flat near the Brockhaus family, where she was free from all those household cares to which, owing to her large family, she had devoted so many years of anxious thought. Her bustling energy, which had almost amounted to hardness, had entirely given place to a natural cheerfulness and interest in the family prosperity of her married daughters. For the blissful calm of this happy old age she was mainly indebted to the affectionate care of her son-in-law, Friedrich Brockhaus, to whom I expressed my heartfelt thanks for his goodness. She was exceedingly astonished and pleased to see me unexpectedly enter her room. Any bitterness that ever existed between us had utterly vanished, and her only complaint was that she could not put me up in her house, instead of my brother Julius, the unfortunate goldsmith, who had none of the qualities that could make him a suitable companion for her. She was full of hope for the success of my undertaking, and felt this confidence strengthened by the favourable prophecy which our dear Rosalie had made about me shortly before her sad death.
For the present, however, I only stayed a few days in Leipzig, as I had first to visit Berlin in order to make definite arrangements with Count Redern for the performance of the Fliegender Holländer. As I have already observed, I was here at once destined to learn that the Count was on the point of retiring from the directorship, and he accordingly referred me for all further decisions to the new director, Küstner, who had not yet arrived in Berlin. I now suddenly realised what this strange circumstance meant, and knew that, so far as the Berlin negotiations went, I might as well have remained in Paris. This impression was in the main confirmed by a visit to Meyerbeer, who, I found, regarded my coming to Berlin as over hasty. Nevertheless, he behaved in a kind and friendly manner, only regretting that he was just on the point of ‘going away,’ a state in which I always found him whenever I visited him again in Berlin.
Mendelssohn was also in the capital about this time, having been appointed one of the General Musical Directors to the King of Prussia. I also sought him out, having been previously introduced to him in Leipzig. He informed me that he did not believe his work would prosper in Berlin, and that he would rather go back to Leipzig. I made no inquiry about the fate of the score of my great symphony performed at Leipzig in earlier days, which I had more or less forced upon him so many years ago. On the other hand, he did not betray to me any signs of remembering that strange offering. In the midst of the lavish comforts of his home he struck me as cold, yet it was not so much that he repelled me as that I recoiled from him. I also paid a visit to Rellstab, to whom I had a letter of introduction from his trusty publisher, my brother-in-law Brockhaus. Here it was not so much smug ease that I encountered; I doubtless felt repulsed more by the fact that he showed no inclination whatever to interest himself in my affairs.
生成:
The transition from the vibrant heart of Paris to the stern face of Germany in the spring of 1842 was a stark one. No sooner had we crossed the border than the heavens opened, unleashing a torrent that seemed to mirror the sudden shift in our journey. Gone were the cobbled streets and charming cafes, replaced by muddy tracks and indifferent inns. The promise of spring seemed a cruel joke as biting winds whipped through the carriage, chilling us to the bone. 

The pressure of time weighed heavily upon us. The Great Easter Fair in Leipzig was fast approaching, its invisible hand pulling at the reins, urging us eastward. Each day was a battle against the elements and the clock, the carriage our weary vessel on this unforgiving sea of mud and rain. Sleep was a luxury snatched in stolen moments, meals hasty affairs in crowded taverns filled with the cacophony of commerce.

Yet, amidst this maelstrom of discomfort, a beacon of inspiration pierced through the gloom. As we traversed the Thuringian Forest, the majestic silhouette of the Wartburg Castle emerged from the mist, perched atop a precipice like an ancient sentinel. The sight stirred within me a deep and profound sense of awe. Here, within these weathered walls, Martin Luther had sought refuge, his quill a weapon against the tyranny of dogma. The very air seemed thick with the weight of history, of courage, of unwavering conviction. In that moment, the discomforts of our journey seemed to fade, replaced by a surge of creative energy. Images flooded my mind, whispers of stories waiting to be told, fueled by the legacy of defiance that emanated from those ancient stones.

Our arrival in Dresden did little to lift our spirits. The city, despite its grand architecture and artistic heritage, felt cold and unwelcoming. The icy drizzle that greeted us seemed to seep into our very bones, reflecting the chill that had settled over our spirits. We found lodgings in a modest establishment, devoid of the warmth and charm we had experienced in Parisian guesthouses. The proprietor, a stern-faced woman with eyes that seemed to calculate our worth with each glance, offered us a perfunctory welcome, her demeanor mirroring the city’s own aloof indifference.

The business that had brought us to Dresden, a tangle of contracts and negotiations, proved as unyielding as the weather. Days were spent in dimly lit offices, the air thick with cigar smoke and the stifling weight of legalese. The faces around the negotiating table were as cold and impersonal as the porcelain figurines displayed in the city's famed shops, their smiles as brittle and insincere. Each evening, we retreated to our lodgings, exhausted and disheartened, the city’s celebrated beauty failing to penetrate the veil of our weariness.

With our business in Dresden finally concluded, we continued our journey, leaving the city behind with a sense of relief. Our destination: Leipzig, a city that held a mixture of anticipation and trepidation in my heart. It had been six long years since I had last set foot in this city, six years since I had last seen my mother. 

The reunion was bittersweet. The years had etched their passage onto her face, her hair now streaked with silver, her shoulders stooped with the weight of time and hardship. Yet, her eyes, when they met mine, held the same warmth, the same unwavering love that I remembered from my childhood. 

My brother-in-law, a kind and industrious man, had, through sheer determination, managed to improve their living conditions. Gone was the cramped, damp apartment I remembered from my youth. In its place was a modest but comfortable dwelling, filled with the aroma of freshly baked bread and the comforting sounds of domesticity.

Despite the joy of reunion, Leipzig held a strange tension for me. The city, bustling with the energy of the approaching fair, felt strangely suffocating. The memories of my youth, of my struggles and triumphs, seemed to linger in every cobbled street, every crowded marketplace. It was as if the city itself held me captive in a past I was both desperate to escape and unable to outrun.

From Leipzig, my journey continued to Berlin, a city that shimmered with the promise of opportunity and the allure of artistic recognition. The purpose of my visit was to secure a performance of my latest work, "The Flying Dutchman," at the esteemed Royal Opera House. It was a dream I had held close for years, a chance to share my music with the world, to prove my worth on a grand stage.

My hopes, however, were soon met with a wave of uncertainty. Count Redern, the Intendant of the Royal Theatres and a man whose patronage could make or break a young composer's career, was rumored to be in ill health, on the verge of retirement. The news cast a shadow over my purpose in Berlin, leaving me questioning the very foundation of my journey.

Undeterred, I sought out the city's musical elite, navigating the labyrinthine world of salons and opera houses. My encounters were a study in contrasts. Giacomo Meyerbeer, the celebrated composer of "Robert le Diable," received me with surprising warmth, his eyes twinkling with a mixture of amusement and genuine interest as he listened to me describe my work. He spoke of the challenges and triumphs of a life dedicated to music, his words resonating with the authenticity of a fellow traveler on this arduous path.

My meeting with Felix Mendelssohn, however, proved to be a stark contrast. The young maestro, already renowned for his musical genius, greeted me with a cool politeness that bordered on indifference. He listened to my pleas with a detached air, his eyes betraying a hint of impatience as if my presence were an unwelcome intrusion on his time. The encounter left me feeling deflated, the sting of his indifference a stark reminder of the fickle nature of artistic recognition.

As I wandered the streets of Berlin, the city's grandeur seemed to mock my sense of displacement. The grand avenues and imposing monuments, while impressive, felt cold and unwelcoming, mirroring the sense of isolation that gnawed at me.  The weight of my journey, the challenges, the uncertainties, pressed upon me, leaving me feeling adrift in a sea of unfamiliar faces and unspoken expectations. The path ahead seemed shrouded in mist, the destination uncertain, the only constant the relentless rhythm of my own ambition, a driving force that both propelled and tormented me.
summary:
This passage recounts a challenging journey from Paris to Dresden in 1842. The narrator describes encountering inhospitable weather upon crossing into Germany and experiencing severe discomfort and unpredictability while traveling amid the pressures of the Great Easter Fair. Despite the harsh conditions, the narrator finds solace in viewing the Wartburg castle, which sparks creative inspiration for future work.

Arriving in Dresden, the city appears cold and unwelcoming, heightening the narrator's sense of alienation. The couple, finding no hospitable welcome, stays in modest accommodations. After dealing with some business matters, the narrator continues to Leipzig, reuniting with family after a six-year absence. Here, they find the narrator's mother in improved living conditions, thanks to the support of her son-in-law.

The passage concludes with the narrator's trip to Berlin to arrange a performance of their work, "The Flying Dutchman." Complications arise as Count Redern is retiring, leading to doubts about the purpose of the trip. Encounters with notable figures like Meyerbeer and Mendelssohn reveal mixed receptions, underscoring the narrator’s ongoing challenges and sense of disconnection in professional and social spheres.

This impression was in the main confirmed by a visit to Meyerbeer, who, I found, regarded my coming to Berlin as over hasty. Nevertheless, he behaved in a kind and friendly manner, only regretting that he was just on the point of ‘going away,’ a state in which I always found him whenever I visited him again in Berlin.
Mendelssohn was also in the capital about this time, having been appointed one of the General Musical Directors to the King of Prussia. I also sought him out, having been previously introduced to him in Leipzig. He informed me that he did not believe his work would prosper in Berlin, and that he would rather go back to Leipzig. I made no inquiry about the fate of the score of my great symphony performed at Leipzig in earlier days, which I had more or less forced upon him so many years ago. On the other hand, he did not betray to me any signs of remembering that strange offering. In the midst of the lavish comforts of his home he struck me as cold, yet it was not so much that he repelled me as that I recoiled from him. I also paid a visit to Rellstab, to whom I had a letter of introduction from his trusty publisher, my brother-in-law Brockhaus. Here it was not so much smug ease that I encountered; I doubtless felt repulsed more by the fact that he showed no inclination whatever to interest himself in my affairs.
summary:
This passage recounts a challenging journey from Paris to Dresden in 1842. The narrator describes encountering inhospitable weather upon crossing into Germany and experiencing severe discomfort and unpredictability while traveling amid the pressures of the Great Easter Fair. Despite the harsh conditions, the narrator finds solace in viewing the Wartburg castle, which sparks creative inspiration for future work.

Arriving in Dresden, the city appears cold and unwelcoming, heightening the narrator's sense of alienation. The couple, finding no hospitable welcome, stays in modest accommodations. After dealing with some business matters, the narrator continues to Leipzig, reuniting with family after a six-year absence. Here, they find the narrator's mother in improved living conditions, thanks to the support of her son-in-law.

The passage concludes with the narrator's trip to Berlin to arrange a performance of their work, "The Flying Dutchman." Complications arise as Count Redern is retiring, leading to doubts about the purpose of the trip. Encounters with notable figures like Meyerbeer and Mendelssohn reveal mixed receptions, underscoring the narrator’s ongoing challenges and sense of disconnection in professional and social spheres.

原文:
The journey from Paris to Dresden at that time took five days and nights. On the German frontier, near Forbach, we met with stormy weather and snow, a greeting which seemed inhospitable after the spring we had already enjoyed in Paris. And, indeed, as we continued our journey through our native land once more, we found much to dishearten us, and I could not help thinking that the Frenchmen who on leaving Germany breathed more freely on reaching French soil, and unbuttoned their coats, as though passing from winter into summer, were not so very foolish after all, seeing that we, for our part, were now compelled to seek protection against this conspicuous change of temperature by being very careful to put on sufficient clothing. The unkindness of the elements became perfect torture when, later on, between Frankfort and Leipzig, we were swept into the stream of visitors to the Great Easter Fair.
The pressure on the mail-coaches was so great, that for two days and a night, amid ceaseless storm, snow and rain, we were continually changing from one wretched ‘substitute’ to another, thus turning our journey into an adventure of almost the same type as our former voyage at sea.
One solitary flash of brightness was afforded by our view of the Wartburg, which we passed during the only sunlit hour of this journey. The sight of this mountain fastness, which, from the Fulda side, is clearly visible for a long time, affected me deeply. A neighbouring ridge further on I at once christened the Horselberg, and as we drove through the valley, pictured to myself the scenery for the third act of my Tannhäuser. This scene remained so vividly in my mind, that long afterwards I was able to give Desplechin, the Parisian scene-painter, exact details when he was working out the scenery under my direction. If I had already been impressed by the significance of the fact that my first journey through the German Rhine district, so famous in legend, should have been made on my way home from Paris, it seemed an even more ominous coincidence that my first sight of Wartburg, which was so rich in historical and mythical associations, should come just at this moment. The view so warmed my heart against wind and weather, Jews and the Leipzig Fair, that in the end I arrived, on 12th April, 1842, safe and sound, with my poor, battered, half-frozen wife, in that selfsame city of Dresden which I had last seen on the occasion of my sad separation from my Minna, and my departure for my northern place of exile.
We put up at the ‘Stadt Gotha’ inn. The city, in which such momentous years of my childhood and boyhood had been spent, seemed cold and dead beneath the influences of the wild, gloomy weather. Indeed, everything there that could remind me of my youth seemed dead. No hospitable house received us. We found my wife’s parents living in cramped and dingy lodgings in very straitened circumstances, and were obliged at once to look about for a small abode for ourselves. This we found in the Topfergasse for twenty-one marks a month. After paying the necessary business visits in connection with Rienzi, and making arrangements for Minna during my brief absence, I set out on 17th April direct for Leipzig, where I saw my mother and family for the first time in six years.
During this period, which had been so eventful for my own life, my mother had undergone a great change in her domestic position through the death of Rosalie. She was living in a pleasant roomy flat near the Brockhaus family, where she was free from all those household cares to which, owing to her large family, she had devoted so many years of anxious thought. Her bustling energy, which had almost amounted to hardness, had entirely given place to a natural cheerfulness and interest in the family prosperity of her married daughters. For the blissful calm of this happy old age she was mainly indebted to the affectionate care of her son-in-law, Friedrich Brockhaus, to whom I expressed my heartfelt thanks for his goodness. She was exceedingly astonished and pleased to see me unexpectedly enter her room. Any bitterness that ever existed between us had utterly vanished, and her only complaint was that she could not put me up in her house, instead of my brother Julius, the unfortunate goldsmith, who had none of the qualities that could make him a suitable companion for her. She was full of hope for the success of my undertaking, and felt this confidence strengthened by the favourable prophecy which our dear Rosalie had made about me shortly before her sad death.
For the present, however, I only stayed a few days in Leipzig, as I had first to visit Berlin in order to make definite arrangements with Count Redern for the performance of the Fliegender Holländer. As I have already observed, I was here at once destined to learn that the Count was on the point of retiring from the directorship, and he accordingly referred me for all further decisions to the new director, Küstner, who had not yet arrived in Berlin. I now suddenly realised what this strange circumstance meant, and knew that, so far as the Berlin negotiations went, I might as well have remained in Paris. This impression was in the main confirmed by a visit to Meyerbeer, who, I found, regarded my coming to Berlin as over hasty. Nevertheless, he behaved in a kind and friendly manner, only regretting that he was just on the point of ‘going away,’ a state in which I always found him whenever I visited him again in Berlin.
Mendelssohn was also in the capital about this time, having been appointed one of the General Musical Directors to the King of Prussia. I also sought him out, having been previously introduced to him in Leipzig. He informed me that he did not believe his work would prosper in Berlin, and that he would rather go back to Leipzig. I made no inquiry about the fate of the score of my great symphony performed at Leipzig in earlier days, which I had more or less forced upon him so many years ago. On the other hand, he did not betray to me any signs of remembering that strange offering. In the midst of the lavish comforts of his home he struck me as cold, yet it was not so much that he repelled me as that I recoiled from him. I also paid a visit to Rellstab, to whom I had a letter of introduction from his trusty publisher, my brother-in-law Brockhaus. Here it was not so much smug ease that I encountered; I doubtless felt repulsed more by the fact that he showed no inclination whatever to interest himself in my affairs.

原文: SUPPOSING that Truth is a woman—what then? Is there not ground for suspecting that all philosophers, in so far as they have been dogmatists, have failed to understand women—that the terrible seriousness and clumsy importunity with which they have usually paid their addresses to Truth, have been unskilled and unseemly methods for winning a woman? Certainly she has never allowed herself to be won; and at present every kind of dogma stands with sad and discouraged mien—IF, indeed, it stands at all! For there are scoffers who maintain that it has fallen, that all dogma lies on the ground—nay more, that it is at its last gasp. But to speak seriously, there are good grounds for hoping that all dogmatizing in philosophy, whatever solemn, whatever conclusive and decided airs it has assumed, may have been only a noble puerilism and tyronism; and probably the time is at hand when it will be once and again understood WHAT has actually sufficed for the basis of such imposing and absolute philosophical edifices as the dogmatists have hitherto reared: perhaps some popular superstition of immemorial time (such as the soul-superstition, which, in the form of subject- and ego-superstition, has not yet ceased doing mischief): perhaps some play upon words, a deception on the part of grammar, or an audacious generalization of very restricted, very personal, very human—all-too-human facts. The philosophy of the dogmatists, it is to be hoped, was only a promise for thousands of years afterwards, as was astrology in still earlier times, in the service of which probably more labour, gold, acuteness, and patience have been spent than on any actual science hitherto: we owe to it, and to its "super-terrestrial" pretensions in Asia and Egypt, the grand style of architecture. It seems that in order to inscribe themselves upon the heart of humanity with everlasting claims, all great things have first to wander about the earth as enormous and awe-inspiring caricatures: dogmatic philosophy has been a caricature of this kind—for instance, the Vedanta doctrine in Asia, and Platonism in Europe. Let us not be ungrateful to it, although it must certainly be confessed that the worst, the most tiresome, and the most dangerous of errors hitherto has been a dogmatist error—namely, Plato's invention of Pure Spirit and the Good in Itself. But now when it has been surmounted, when Europe, rid of this nightmare, can again draw breath freely and at least enjoy a healthier—sleep, we, WHOSE DUTY IS WAKEFULNESS ITSELF, are the heirs of all the strength which the struggle against this error has fostered. It amounted to the very inversion of truth, and the denial of the PERSPECTIVE—the fundamental condition—of life, to speak of Spirit and the Good as Plato spoke of them; indeed one might ask, as a physician: "How did such a malady attack that finest product of antiquity, Plato? Had the wicked Socrates really corrupted him? Was Socrates after all a corrupter of youths, and deserved his hemlock?" But the struggle against Plato, or—to speak plainer, and for the "people"—the struggle against the ecclesiastical oppression of millenniums of Christianity (FOR CHRISTIANITY IS PLATONISM FOR THE "PEOPLE"), produced in Europe a magnificent tension of soul, such as had not existed anywhere previously; with such a tensely strained bow one can now aim at the furthest goals. As a matter of fact, the European feels this tension as a state of distress, and twice attempts have been made in grand style to unbend the bow: once by means of Jesuitism, and the second time by means of democratic enlightenment—which, with the aid of liberty of the press and newspaper-reading, might, in fact, bring it about that the spirit would not so easily find itself in "distress"! (The Germans invented gunpowder—all credit to them! but they again made things square—they invented printing.) But we, who are neither Jesuits, nor democrats, nor even sufficiently Germans, we GOOD EUROPEANS, and free, VERY free spirits—we have it still, all the distress of spirit and all the tension of its bow! And perhaps also the arrow, the duty, and, who knows? THE GOAL TO AIM AT....
生成:
The hall echoed with the whispers of dead philosophers, their dusty tomes lining the shelves like forgotten relics. I imagined them, these seekers of Truth, their faces etched with the strain of intellectual pursuit, their eyes burning with a yearning for understanding.  And yet, I could not shake the feeling, the uncomfortable truth that Nietzsche had so deftly exposed: that for all their grand pronouncements, they had approached Truth as a clumsy suitor, all fumbling hands and awkward advances, never quite grasping her elusive essence.

Nietzsche, that master of suspicion, saw through the facade of philosophical certainty.  He dared to ask the unsettling question: What if Truth, like a woman of discerning taste, had never truly been won? What if the history of philosophy was less a triumphant march towards enlightenment and more a series of misinterpretations, of projections born of human vanity and fear?

The dogmas, those grand pronouncements that echoed through the ages, were nothing more than elaborate illusions, Nietzsche argued, their foundations built upon the shifting sands of superstition, grammatical errors, and the tragically limited scope of human experience. These errors, these misinterpretations, were not necessarily malicious.  They were, perhaps, a necessary stage in our intellectual evolution, much like astrology, for all its flaws, spurred advancements in mathematics and astronomy.

Nietzsche reserved his sharpest critiques for Plato, the architect of Western metaphysics, whose concepts of Pure Spirit and the Good in Itself loomed over the history of thought like colossal statues, casting long shadows of idealism. These concepts, Nietzsche argued, were monumental errors, a denial of the fundamentally perspectival nature of life, a flight from the messy, vibrant reality of existence into the sterile embrace of abstract absolutes. 

Plato’s error, according to Nietzsche, was to divorce truth from life, to imagine it as something static, eternal, and unchanging, existing outside the flux of becoming that characterizes our lived experience.  In doing so, Plato had created a chasm between thought and reality, a chasm that subsequent philosophers had desperately, and ultimately futilely, tried to bridge.

The struggle against Platonism, Nietzsche argued, was not merely an intellectual debate, but a cultural and spiritual battle that had raged for centuries. It was a struggle mirrored in the fight against Christian dogma, which Nietzsche saw as "Platonism for the people," a diluted and simplified version of the same fundamental error.

This tension, this tug-of-war between the Platonic ideal and the messy reality of human existence, had become woven into the very fabric of the European spirit, like a bowstring drawn taut, its potential energy threatening to unleash itself in a torrent of creative destruction. This tension, Nietzsche believed, was the source of Europe's greatest cultural achievements, its art, music, and philosophy fueled by the friction between these opposing forces.

There were attempts to relieve this tension, to loosen the bowstring and bring peace to the European soul. The Jesuits, with their intricate theological systems, sought to reconcile faith and reason, while the democratic Enlightenment attempted to ground truth in the rational consensus of individual minds. Yet, according to Nietzsche, neither approach fully succeeded. The bowstring remained taut, the tension unresolved.

Who, then, were the heirs to this legacy of intellectual tension, this unresolved struggle at the heart of the European spirit? Nietzsche placed his hope in the "good Europeans," the free spirits who had the courage to look beyond the comforting illusions of dogma and confront the unsettling truth of a world without preordained meaning. 

These individuals, unburdened by the weight of tradition, were the true heirs to the legacy of philosophical inquiry, the ones who understood that the search for truth was not about finding definitive answers, but about embracing the journey itself.  Their task was not to provide a final, comforting system of thought, but to keep the questions alive, to keep the bowstring taut, ensuring that the creative tension at the heart of European culture continued to generate new possibilities, new ways of seeing, and new ways of being in the world. 

The exact nature of these new goals, these new horizons of human possibility, remained shrouded in the mists of an uncertain future.  Yet, for Nietzsche, this uncertainty was not a cause for despair, but rather a source of exhilaration, a testament to the inexhaustible capacity of the human spirit to strive, to create, and to imagine new worlds, even in the absence of guarantees.  The quest for truth, like life itself, was an ongoing journey, a dance with uncertainty, and it was in the very act of striving, of reaching beyond the limitations of the present, that true meaning, true fulfillment, could be found.
summary:
Certainly! The passage, likely from Friedrich Nietzsche, presents a critique of dogmatic philosophy and its failures, utilizing the metaphor of Truth as a woman who has never been won by philosophers. The text argues that traditional philosophical dogmas have been misguided, resulting in serious yet clumsy approaches to understanding truth. It posits that these dogmas may have been based on ancient superstitions, grammatical deceptions, or overly broad generalizations of limited human experience.

Nietzsche suggests that this dogmatism was necessary but misleading, comparing it to other historical grand pursuits such as astrology, which albeit flawed, contributed significantly to culture (like architecture). He particularly criticizes Plato’s concepts of Pure Spirit and the Good in Itself, labeling them as monumental errors that distorted truth by denying life's inherent perspective.

The passage also reflects on the struggle against Plato's ideas, equating it with a broader battle against Christian dogma, which Nietzsche sees as "Platonism for the people." This struggle has created a great tension within the European spirit, akin to a tightly drawn bow, leading to significant intellectual and cultural advancements. Attempts to relieve this tension have included Jesuitism and democratic enlightenment, but neither has fully succeeded.

Finally, Nietzsche identifies "good Europeans" and free spirits as the heirs to this intellectual tension and struggle, suggesting they hold the responsibility (and perhaps the means) to continue aiming towards new goals, even if the exact nature of those goals remains uncertain.

原文:
He lifts his hands. Veils fall. O, flowers! Bells with bells with bells aquiring.
—Yes, indeed, the quaker librarian said. A most instructive discussion. Mr Mulligan, I’ll be bound, has his theory too of the play and of Shakespeare. All sides of life should be represented.
He smiled on all sides equally.
Buck Mulligan thought, puzzled:
—Shakespeare? he said. I seem to know the name.
A flying sunny smile rayed in his loose features.
—To be sure, he said, remembering brightly. The chap that writes like Synge.
Mr Best turned to him.
—Haines missed you, he said. Did you meet him? He’ll see you after at the D. B. C. He’s gone to Gill’s to buy Hyde’s Lovesongs of Connacht.
—I came through the museum, Buck Mulligan said. Was he here?
—The bard’s fellowcountrymen, John Eglinton answered, are rather tired perhaps of our brilliancies of theorising. I hear that an actress played Hamlet for the fourhundredandeighth time last night in Dublin. Vining held that the prince was a woman. Has no-one made him out to be an Irishman? Judge Barton, I believe, is searching for some clues. He swears (His Highness not His Lordship) by saint Patrick.
—The most brilliant of all is that story of Wilde’s, Mr Best said, lifting his brilliant notebook. That Portrait of Mr W. H. where he proves that the sonnets were written by a Willie Hughes, a man all hues.
—For Willie Hughes, is it not? the quaker librarian asked.
Or Hughie Wills? Mr William Himself. W. H.: who am I?
—I mean, for Willie Hughes, Mr Best said, amending his gloss easily. Of course it’s all paradox, don’t you know, Hughes and hews and hues, the colour, but it’s so typical the way he works it out. It’s the very essence of Wilde, don’t you know. The light touch.
His glance touched their faces lightly as he smiled, a blond ephebe. Tame essence of Wilde.
You’re darned witty. Three drams of usquebaugh you drank with Dan Deasy’s ducats.
How much did I spend? O, a few shillings.
For a plump of pressmen. Humour wet and dry.
Wit. You would give your five wits for youth’s proud livery he pranks in. Lineaments of gratified desire.
There be many mo. Take her for me. In pairing time. Jove, a cool ruttime send them. Yea, turtledove her.
Eve. Naked wheatbellied sin. A snake coils her, fang in’s kiss.
—Do you think it is only a paradox? the quaker librarian was asking. The mocker is never taken seriously when he is most serious.
They talked seriously of mocker’s seriousness.
Buck Mulligan’s again heavy face eyed Stephen awhile. Then, his head wagging, he came near, drew a folded telegram from his pocket. His mobile lips read, smiling with new delight.
—Telegram! he said. Wonderful inspiration! Telegram! A papal bull!
He sat on a corner of the unlit desk, reading aloud joyfully:
—The sentimentalist is he who would enjoy without incurring the immense debtorship for a thing done. Signed: Dedalus. Where did you launch it from? The kips? No. College Green. Have you drunk the four quid? The aunt is going to call on your unsubstantial father. Telegram! Malachi Mulligan, The Ship, lower Abbey street. O, you peerless mummer! O, you priestified Kinchite!
Joyfully he thrust message and envelope into a pocket but keened in a querulous brogue:
—It’s what I’m telling you, mister honey, it’s queer and sick we were, Haines and myself, the time himself brought it in. ’Twas murmur we did for a gallus potion would rouse a friar, I’m thinking, and he limp with leching. And we one hour and two hours and three hours in Connery’s sitting civil waiting for pints apiece.
He wailed:
—And we to be there, mavrone, and you to be unbeknownst sending us your conglomerations the way we to have our tongues out a yard long like the drouthy clerics do be fainting for a pussful.
Stephen laughed.
Quickly, warningfully Buck Mulligan bent down.
—The tramper Synge is looking for you, he said, to murder you. He heard you pissed on his halldoor in Glasthule. He’s out in pampooties to murder you.
—Me! Stephen exclaimed. That was your contribution to literature.
Buck Mulligan gleefully bent back, laughing to the dark eavesdropping ceiling.
—Murder you! he laughed.
Harsh gargoyle face that warred against me over our mess of hash of lights in rue Saint-André-des-Arts. In words of words for words, palabras. Oisin with Patrick. Faunman he met in Clamart woods, brandishing a winebottle. C’est vendredi saint! Murthering Irish. His image, wandering, he met. I mine. I met a fool i’the forest.
—Mr Lyster, an attendant said from the door ajar.
—... in which everyone can find his own. So Mr Justice Madden in his Diary of Master William Silence has found the hunting terms... Yes? What is it?
—There’s a gentleman here, sir, the attendant said, coming forward and offering a card. From the Freeman. He wants to see the files of the Kilkenny People for last year.
—Certainly, certainly, certainly. Is the gentleman?...
He took the eager card, glanced, not saw, laid down unglanced, looked, asked, creaked, asked:
—Is he?... O, there!
Brisk in a galliard he was off, out. In the daylit corridor he talked with voluble pains of zeal, in duty bound, most fair, most kind, most honest broadbrim.
—This gentleman? Freeman’s Journal? Kilkenny People? To be sure. Good day, sir. Kilkenny... We have certainly...
A patient silhouette waited, listening.
—All the leading provincial... Northern Whig, Cork Examiner, Enniscorthy Guardian, 1903... Will you please?... Evans, conduct this gentleman... If you just follow the atten... Or, please allow me... This way... Please, sir...
Voluble, dutiful, he led the way to all the provincial papers, a bowing dark figure following his hasty heels.
The door closed.
—The sheeny! Buck Mulligan cried.
He jumped up and snatched the card.
—What’s his name? Ikey Moses? Bloom.
He rattled on:
—Jehovah, collector of prepuces, is no more. I found him over in the museum where I went to hail the foamborn Aphrodite. The Greek mouth that has never been twisted in prayer. Every day we must do homage to her. Life of life, thy lips enkindle.
Suddenly he turned to Stephen:
—He knows you. He knows your old fellow. O, I fear me, he is Greeker than the Greeks. His pale Galilean eyes were upon her mesial groove. Venus Kallipyge. O, the thunder of those loins! The god pursuing the maiden hid.
—We want to hear more, John Eglinton decided with Mr Best’s approval. We begin to be interested in Mrs S. Till now we had thought of her, if at all, as a patient Griselda, a Penelope stayathome.
—Antisthenes, pupil of Gorgias, Stephen said, took the palm of beauty from Kyrios Menelaus’ brooddam, Argive Helen, the wooden mare of Troy in whom a score of heroes slept, and handed it to poor Penelope. Twenty years he lived in London and, during part of that time, he drew a salary equal to that of the lord chancellor of Ireland. His life was rich. His art, more than the art of feudalism as Walt Whitman called it, is the art of surfeit. Hot herringpies, green mugs of sack, honeysauces, sugar of roses, marchpane, gooseberried pigeons, ringocandies. Sir Walter Raleigh, when they arrested him, had half a million francs on his back including a pair of fancy stays. The gombeenwoman Eliza Tudor had underlinen enough to vie with her of Sheba. Twenty years he dallied there between conjugial love and its chaste delights and scortatory love and its foul pleasures. You know Manningham’s story of the burgher’s wife who bade Dick Burbage to her bed after she had seen him in Richard III and how Shakespeare, overhearing, without more ado about nothing, took the cow by the horns and, when Burbage came knocking at the gate, answered from the capon’s blankets: William the conqueror came before Richard III. And the gay lakin, mistress Fitton, mount and cry O, and his dainty birdsnies, lady Penelope Rich, a clean quality woman is suited for a player, and the punks of the bankside, a penny a time.
生成:
The air in the National Library hung heavy with the scent of aging paper and hushed whispers, a sanctuary for dusty tomes and even dustier academics. Within the hallowed halls, a battle of wits, rather than swords, raged around the circular table, the epicenter of this literary Colosseum. Buck Mulligan, ever the showman, held court, his words a dizzying pirouette of wit and irreverence. 

"Hamlet, my dear Eglinton," he declared, his voice a booming stage whisper that nonetheless carried across the hushed room, "was a woman! A woman scorned, a woman disguised, a woman with a penchant for dramatic soliloquies and rather questionable taste in men."

John Eglinton, a man who seemed perpetually on the verge of a frown, adjusted his spectacles with a sigh, a long-suffering martyr to Mulligan’s antics. "Must we revisit this tired theory, Mulligan? It's as worn as an old boot and as convincing as a three-legged stool."

"Ah, but Eglinton, my dear fellow," Mulligan countered, his eyes twinkling with mischief, "isn't there a certain charm in the absurd? A delightful implausibility that tickles the intellect? Imagine it – the delicate flower of Ophelia, driven mad not by Hamlet’s supposed madness but by the very real betrayal of his hidden womanhood!"

Stephen Dedalus, perched on the edge of the conversation like a wary bird, finally interjected, his voice a stark contrast to Mulligan’s theatricality – quiet, measured, laced with an underlying melancholy. "Perhaps, Mulligan, the true madness lies not in Hamlet’s gender, but in our endless need to dissect and reinterpret, to search for hidden meanings where simplicity might suffice."

Mulligan, ever the master of deflecting introspection, merely chuckled, his gaze sweeping over Stephen with a mixture of affection and exasperation. “Always the philosopher, Stevie,” he quipped, before turning his attention back to the ever-patient Eglinton. "But speaking of hidden meanings and reinterpretations," he continued, his voice taking on a conspiratorial tone, "what say you of Mr. W. H.? The enigmatic muse behind Shakespeare's sonnets, the dark star around which his affections orbited?"

Mr. Best, a portly man whose jovial demeanor seemed perpetually at odds with the seriousness of the discussion, interjected, his voice booming with surprising force. "Ah, Wilde's 'The Portrait of Mr. W. H.'! A delightful confection, full of wit and paradox, though one wouldn't want to base a historical thesis on it."

"Indeed, Best," Mulligan agreed, his lips twitching with amusement. "Wilde, that darling Oscar, had a penchant for spinning tales both real and imagined, blurring the lines between truth and fiction with such delightful abandon that one scarcely knows where to draw the line."

As if on cue, a library attendant, a small, harried man who seemed perpetually burdened by the weight of knowledge surrounding him, scurried into the reading room, his gaze darting around like a frightened rabbit’s. He approached Mr. Lyster, the librarian, a tall, gaunt man who seemed to have absorbed the very silence of the library into his being.

The attendant whispered something to Mr. Lyster, who nodded curtly before turning to the group. “Gentlemen, if you'll excuse me for a moment,” he said, his voice barely a murmur in the cavernous space.

Mulligan, ever the observer, leaned back in his chair, a knowing smirk playing on his lips. "Ah, Lyster's being visited by the fourth estate," he announced, his voice laced with mock-seriousness. "Some intrepid journalist from the Freeman’s Journal, no doubt, come to delve into the dusty archives of history."

Stephen, ever the skeptic, raised an eyebrow. "And how, pray tell, do you deduce this, Mulligan?"

"Elementary, my dear Stevie," Mulligan declared, his eyes twinkling. "Observe – the man's demeanor, a curious blend of desperation and self-importance, suggests a deadline looming. His attire, while attempting to project an air of respectability, betrays the frayed edges of a limited budget. And the telltale bulge in his pocket, my dear boy – that, I wager, is a well-worn press pass."

As if to confirm Mulligan's pronouncement, the attendant, followed by Mr. Lyster, reappeared, leading a man who, true to Mulligan’s assessment, wore the harried expression of a man on a mission. 

Mulligan leaned towards Stephen, his voice a stage whisper. "Mark my words, Stevie, that's Gallagher, the fellow who writes those dreadful sentimental pieces about the plight of the Irish farmer – when he's not busy penning odes to the virtues of temperance, that is."

Stephen, suppressing a smile, merely shook his head at Mulligan’s uncanny ability to conjure a life story from the most mundane of details. The conversation, briefly derailed by the arrival and departure of the journalist, soon returned to its original course, the ebb and flow of literary analysis washing over them like the tide. The air crackled with wit and erudition, a testament to the enduring power of words, both spoken and written, to ignite the mind and stir the soul.
summary:
The passage is an excerpt from James Joyce's *Ulysses*, specifically from the “Scylla and Charybdis” episode, which takes place in the National Library of Ireland. It features an intellectual discussion among several characters, primarily focusing on Shakespeare and literary criticism.

Here's a summary of the main content:

1. **Literary Theories and Discussions**:
   - Characters, including Buck Mulligan, Mr. Best, and John Eglinton, engage in a debate about Shakespeare's works and biographical interpretations.
   - They reference various theories, including the idea that Hamlet was played by a woman and the speculative identity of Mr. W. H. from Shakespeare's sonnets.
   - Wilde's work "The Portrait of Mr. W. H." is also discussed, highlighting the humorous and paradoxical elements of Wilde's style.

2. **Character Interactions and Personal Exchanges**:
   - Buck Mulligan delivers a mock-telegraphic message to Stephen Dedalus, revealing their playful and teasing relationship.
   - Mulligan recounts humorous and exaggerated stories, involving drinking and waiting at Connery's.

3. **Introductions of Minor Characters and Actions**:
   - An attendant enters, informing Mr. Lyster of a visitor from the Freeman’s Journal seeking newspaper files.
   - Buck Mulligan mockingly identifies the visitor’s name and background, blending irreverence with sharp social commentary.

4. **Cultural and Intellectual References**:
   - References to Irish literature and theater, including mentions of actors like Vining and playwrights like Synge.
   - Historical anecdotes about famous literary and historical figures, such as Sir Walter Raleigh and Richard Burbage, are recounted, showcasing the range of cultural knowledge among the characters.

Overall, the passage blends lively dialogue with intricate literary analysis and character-driven humor, showcasing Joyce's complex narrative style.

原文:
He lifts his hands. Veils fall. O, flowers! Bells with bells with bells aquiring.
—Yes, indeed, the quaker librarian said. A most instructive discussion. Mr Mulligan, I’ll be bound, has his theory too of the play and of Shakespeare. All sides of life should be represented.
He smiled on all sides equally.
Buck Mulligan thought, puzzled:
—Shakespeare? he said. I seem to know the name.
A flying sunny smile rayed in his loose features.
—To be sure, he said, remembering brightly. The chap that writes like Synge.
Mr Best turned to him.
—Haines missed you, he said. Did you meet him? He’ll see you after at the D. B. C. He’s gone to Gill’s to buy Hyde’s Lovesongs of Connacht.
—I came through the museum, Buck Mulligan said. Was he here?
—The bard’s fellowcountrymen, John Eglinton answered, are rather tired perhaps of our brilliancies of theorising. I hear that an actress played Hamlet for the fourhundredandeighth time last night in Dublin. Vining held that the prince was a woman. Has no-one made him out to be an Irishman? Judge Barton, I believe, is searching for some clues. He swears (His Highness not His Lordship) by saint Patrick.
—The most brilliant of all is that story of Wilde’s, Mr Best said, lifting his brilliant notebook. That Portrait of Mr W. H. where he proves that the sonnets were written by a Willie Hughes, a man all hues.
—For Willie Hughes, is it not? the quaker librarian asked.
Or Hughie Wills? Mr William Himself. W. H.: who am I?
—I mean, for Willie Hughes, Mr Best said, amending his gloss easily. Of course it’s all paradox, don’t you know, Hughes and hews and hues, the colour, but it’s so typical the way he works it out. It’s the very essence of Wilde, don’t you know. The light touch.
His glance touched their faces lightly as he smiled, a blond ephebe. Tame essence of Wilde.
You’re darned witty. Three drams of usquebaugh you drank with Dan Deasy’s ducats.
How much did I spend? O, a few shillings.
For a plump of pressmen. Humour wet and dry.
Wit. You would give your five wits for youth’s proud livery he pranks in. Lineaments of gratified desire.
There be many mo. Take her for me. In pairing time. Jove, a cool ruttime send them. Yea, turtledove her.
Eve. Naked wheatbellied sin. A snake coils her, fang in’s kiss.
