生成:
Hwæt! Ic wille eow gereccan tragisce tale, gefyld mid heofodweorce and heortan sare, þæt belīċþ þa frecenlican neahdunga gelosies and þæs unġesibblican tīman fǣhðe.  

Hit gelamp on fyrndagum þæt se ārfæsta god, Phoebus gehāten, wæs eardfæst on middangearde, under þām heofonlican hēahsetle.  He wæs geond þā ylda hlīsa gemyndigod for his manigfealdum mærðum.  His wlite wæs swa beorht swa sunnan scīma, and his ansyn swa lēoflic swa sumor sæd.  Nænig cniht on eallum þām lande mihte him geanlīcan on ænlicnesse, ne on spēde.

Swa gesċēadwīs wæs he on þām cræfte bogcræftes, þæt he mihte hittan ælc scearp gewinn mid his flānānum.  Hit wæs he se þe ofslōh þone egeslican wyrm Python mid his āgenum handum, þæt fæge deor mid his āttorþearle tungan.  For þyssum sige wæs he geond ealle landa mære, and his hlīsa wæs swa swēte swa hunig on þām mūðe.

Ac Phoebus wæs nā læs gefræge for his gleocræftum.  He hæfde dēopne lufan for sangcræfte and hearpan spēle, and his stefn wæs swa glīwlic þæt hit mihte gehælan þā seocan and gefrēfran þā unrōte.  Oft he sæte on grene felda, under þām scīnan steorran, and his hearpe sang, and his wōrd wæron swa milde þæt þā wudufuglas woldon efstan him tō, and him on þām bōgum sittan, and his sang gehlyste.

Mid him eallum tīdum wæs his getrywe gefera, hwit hræfn, wundorlic on ansyne, forþām þe he hæfde þā gife sprǣce.  Þes hræfn wæs Phoebus gehyldesta þegn, and oft he fleah geond þā wīdan land, and brōhte him tīðing of eallum þām þe gedōn wæron, ge gōde ge yfele.  Swa swēte wæs þæs hræfnes sang, þæt hit mihte gegladian ealle þā þe hit gehȳrdon.

Hit gelamp þæt Phoebus, on his heortan, wearð mid lufan gewundod for fægerre idese, þe on eallum þām lande nāne gelican hæfde.  Hire wlite wæs swa beorht swa morgensteorra, and hire eagan swa scīnende swa þā gimmas on his āgenum crūne.  For hire lufan forlet he his sang and his hearpan spēl, and his dagas wæron gefylled mid hire ānum.

Þā cwæð he on his mode: "Ic hæbbe gefunden mīne heortan lufu, mīne sawle gefēa.  Nū ic cann on mīnum life nānes gōdes butan hire.  Ac ic sceal bewarian hire wel, forþām þe ic nat hwæt yfel on þisse worulde mag gelampan."

Swa gelōme wæs Phoebus mid geloesum geþancum on his mode gedrefed.  He nyste þæt his lufu wæs unwreðelice, and þæt hire heorte wæs swa cald swa īs.  He ne mihte geþencan þæt ænig wif mihte his lufan forseoðan, oþþe him unhold wesan.

Ac hit ne wearð swa swa he gehyrnode.  Forþām þe þā hwīle þe Phoebus wæs āweg on huntunge, oþþe on sumum ōðrum ærende, þā gemētte his wif hire āgenne lufan, ceorl of læssan cynne, ac mid fægerre ansyne.  Oft þēos unhold ides brēac hire weres bedd, and heold hire unriht lufe digol on hire breoste.

Ac þæt ne mihte beon lange digol.  Forþām þe se hwita hræfn, se þe eall gehyrde and eall geseah, brōhte þā sārlican tīðing tō his hlāforde.  He fleah on Phoebus eaxlum, and sang his sārlic leoð, "Cuckoo, cuckoo," þæt getacnode þæt his wif wæs unhold.

Þā wearð Phoebus mid unāsecgendlicum sāre on his breoste gewundod.  He ne mihte gelȳfan þām hræfnes wōrdum, ac he ne mihte nā leng his heortan sāre ācwencan.  He eode intō his botl, and þǣr fand he his wif on þæs ceorles earmum.

Þā wearð he swa swīðe geæbyligod þæt he nāne lēan ne geseah, butan þæt he his āgen hand on his unholdan wife wræce.  He genam his boga and his flān, and mid ānum sceote ofslog he þā unrihte idese.

Ac his sār wæs nā þȳ læs.  Forþām þe he hæfde ofslegen þā þe he lufodest on eallum þisum middangearde.  He wearð swa swīðe mid sāre geangsumod þæt he ealle his hearpan and his gleocraftas forbræc, and swōr āð þæt he næfre eft ne wolde sangcræft begietan.

Þus wearð se ārfæsta god, Phoebus, gedrefed mid sāre and mid heofodweorce, þurh þæt yfel his wifes unholdnesse.  And þus belīċþ þēos tragisce tale þā frecenlican neahdunga gelosies and þæs unġesibblican tīman fǣhðe.
summary:
Certainly! Here's a summary of the passage:

The passage recounts the story of Phoebus (Apollo) when he lived on Earth, highlighting his excellent attributes: he was the most pleasant bachelor, a skilled archer who killed the serpent Python, and a talented musician and singer. Phoebus had a white crow that could speak and sing wonderfully. Phoebus also had a wife whom he loved deeply, but he was jealous and overly protective.

Despite his efforts to keep her faithful, his wife was untrue, taking another lover of lower status while Phoebus was away. The white crow witnessed the infidelity and reported it to Phoebus upon his return, singing "Cuckoo" to signify his wife's betrayal. Phoebus, devastated by this revelation, killed his wife in a fit of rage, destroyed his musical instruments, and swore off his former pursuits. The story explores themes of jealousy, infidelity, and the futility of trying to control someone's natural tendencies.

原文:
1. No Knowledge without Discernment.
Another faculty we may take notice of in our minds is that of DISCERNING and DISTINGUISHING between the several ideas it has. It is not enough to have a confused perception of something in general. Unless the mind had a distinct perception of different objects and their qualities, it would be capable of very little knowledge, though the bodies that affect us were as busy about us as they are now, and the mind were continually employed in thinking. On this faculty of distinguishing one thing from another depends the evidence and certainty of several, even very general, propositions, which have passed for innate truths;—because men, overlooking the true cause why those propositions find universal assent, impute it wholly to native uniform impressions; whereas it in truth depends upon this clear discerning faculty of the mind, whereby it PERCEIVES two ideas to be the same, or different. But of this more hereafter.
2. The Difference of Wit and Judgment.
How much the imperfection of accurately discriminating ideas one from another lies, either in the dulness or faults of the organs of sense; or want of acuteness, exercise, or attention in the understanding; or hastiness and precipitancy, natural to some tempers, I will not here examine: it suffices to take notice, that this is one of the operations that the mind may reflect on and observe in itself. It is of that consequence to its other knowledge, that so far as this faculty is in itself dull, or not rightly made use of, for the distinguishing one thing from another,—so far our notions are confused, and our reason and judgment disturbed or misled. If in having our ideas in the memory ready at hand consists quickness of parts; in this, of having them unconfused, and being able nicely to distinguish one thing from another, where there is but the least difference, consists, in a great measure, the exactness of judgment, and clearness of reason, which is to be observed in one man above another. And hence perhaps may be given some reason of that common observation,—that men who have a great deal of wit, and prompt memories, have not always the clearest judgment or deepest reason. For WIT lying most in the assemblage of ideas, and putting those together with quickness and variety, wherein can be found any resemblance or congruity, thereby to make up pleasant pictures and agreeable visions in the fancy; JUDGMENT, on the contrary, lies quite on the other side, in separating carefully, one from another, ideas wherein can be found the least difference, thereby to avoid being misled by similitude, and by affinity to take one thing for another. This is a way of proceeding quite contrary to metaphor and allusion; wherein for the most part lies that entertainment and pleasantry of wit, which strikes so lively on the fancy, and therefore is so acceptable to all people, because its beauty appears at first sight, and there is required no labour of thought to examine what truth or reason there is in it. The mind, without looking any further, rests satisfied with the agreeableness of the picture and the gaiety of the fancy. And it is a kind of affront to go about to examine it, by the severe rules of truth and good reason; whereby it appears that it consists in something that is not perfectly conformable to them.
3. Clearness alone hinders Confusion.
To the well distinguishing our ideas, it chiefly contributes that they be CLEAR and DETERMINATE. And when they are so, it will not breed any confusion or mistake about them, though the senses should (as sometimes they do) convey them from the same object differently on different occasions, and so seem to err. For, though a man in a fever should from sugar have a bitter taste, which at another time would produce a sweet one, yet the idea of bitter in that man’s mind would be as clear and distinct from the idea of sweet as if he had tasted only gall. Nor does it make any more confusion between the two ideas of sweet and bitter that the same sort of body produces at one time one, and at another time another idea by the taste, than it makes a confusion in two ideas of white and sweet, or white and round, that the same piece of sugar produces them both in the mind at the same time. And the ideas of orange-colour and azure, that are produced in the mind by the same parcel of the infusion of lignum nephritium, are no less distinct ideas than those of the same colours taken from two very different bodies.
4. Comparing.
The COMPARING them one with another, in respect of extent, degrees, time, place, or any other circumstances, is another operation of the mind about its ideas, and is that upon which depends all that large tribe of ideas comprehended under RELATION; which, of how vast an extent it is, I shall have occasion to consider hereafter.
5. Brutes compare but imperfectly.
How far brutes partake in this faculty, is not easy to determine. I imagine they have it not in any great degree, for, though they probably have several ideas distinct enough, yet it seems to me to be the prerogative of human understanding, when it has sufficiently distinguished any ideas, so as to perceive them to be perfectly different, and so consequently two, to cast about and consider in what circumstances they are capable to be compared. And therefore, I think, beasts compare not their ideas further than some sensible circumstances annexed to the objects themselves. The other power of comparing, which may be observed in men, belonging to general ideas, and useful only to abstract reasonings, we may probably conjecture beasts have not.
6. Compounding.
The next operation we may observe in the mind about its ideas is COMPOSITION; whereby it puts together several of those simple ones it has received from sensation and reflection, and combines them into complex ones. Under this of composition may be reckoned also that of ENLARGING, wherein, though the composition does not so much appear as in more complex ones, yet it is nevertheless a putting several ideas together, though of the same kind. Thus, by adding several units together, we make the idea of a dozen; and putting together the repeated ideas of several perches, we frame that of a furlong.
7. Brutes compound but little.
In this also, I suppose, brutes come far short of man. For, though they take in, and retain together, several combinations of simple ideas, as possibly the shape, smell, and voice of his master make up the complex idea a dog has of him, or rather are so many distinct marks whereby he knows him; yet I do not think they do of themselves ever compound them, and make complex ideas. And perhaps even where we think they have complex ideas, it is only one simple one that directs them in the knowledge of several things, which possibly they distinguish less by their sight than we imagine. For I have been credibly informed that a bitch will nurse, play with, and be fond of young foxes, as much as, and in place of her puppies, if you can but get them once to suck her so long that her milk may go through them. And those animals which have a numerous brood of young ones at once, appear not to have any knowledge of their number; for though they are mightily concerned for any of their young that are taken from them whilst they are in sight or hearing, yet if one or two of them be stolen from them in their absence, or without noise, they appear not to miss them, or to have any sense that their number is lessened.
8. Naming.
When children have, by repeated sensations, got ideas fixed in their memories, they begin by degrees to learn the use of signs. And when they have got the skill to apply the organs of speech to the framing of articulate sounds, they begin to make use of words, to signify their ideas to others. These verbal signs they sometimes borrow from others, and sometimes make themselves, as one may observe among the new and unusual names children often give to things in the first use of language.
9. Abstraction.
The use of words then being to stand as outward mark of our internal ideas, and those ideas being taken from particular things, if every particular idea that we take up should have a distinct name, names must be endless. To prevent this, the mind makes the particular ideas received from particular objects to become general; which is done by considering them as they are in the mind such appearances,—separate from all other existences, and the circumstances of real existence, as time, place, or any other concomitant ideas. This is called ABSTRACTION, whereby ideas taken from particular beings become general representatives of all of the same kind; and their names general names, applicable to whatever exists conformable to such abstract ideas. Such precise, naked appearances in the mind, without considering how, whence, or with what others they came there, the understanding lays up (with names commonly annexed to them) as the standards to rank real existences into sorts, as they agree with these patterns, and to denominate them accordingly. Thus the same colour being observed to-day in chalk or snow, which the mind yesterday received from milk, it considers that appearance alone, makes it a representative of all of that kind; and having given it the name WHITENESS, it by that sound signifies the same quality wheresoever to be imagined or met with; and thus universals, whether ideas or terms, are made.
10. Brutes abstract not.
If it may be doubted whether beasts compound and enlarge their ideas that way to any degree; this, I think, I may be positive in,—that the power of abstracting is not at all in them; and that the having of general ideas is that which puts a perfect distinction betwixt man and brutes, and is an excellency which the faculties of brutes do by no means attain to. For it is evident we observe no footsteps in them of making use of general signs for universal ideas; from which we have reason to imagine that they have not the faculty of abstracting, or making general ideas, since they have no use of words, or any other general signs.
生成:
##  Ðā Cræftas þæs Modes

Hēah is se weorþscipe þæs modes, þæt wundorlice tocyn Godes cræftes, þurh hwone se man, ofer eallum eorþlicum cynnum, āhafen is tō þām hēahsetle gelīcnesse his Scyppendes.  Ne stent se weorþscipe ānes on līfe, on æte, oþþe on strengþo, ac on þām inneran līhte þære sawle, on þām cræftum þæs modes, þe hine scēaðaþ fram þām dumbum neatum and hine gehiersumiaþ tō þām hēahum geþeahte.

Fyrst sceal mann habban þone cræft tōcnāwennesse, tō dǣlendum betwēox sundor-geþōhtum. Swā swā se līchaman eage sundor-dǣleþ betwēox mislicum hīwum and scēapum, swā sceal se mod eage sundor-dǣlan betwēox mislicum geþōhtum, oððe elles biþ se mann bedyrned on þēostrum ungesceadwīsnysse.  Forþām þe gif se mod ne cann āscūfan betwēox þām sōþan and þām lēasan, betwēox þām gōdan and þām yflan, þonne færð hē āgylt, swā swā blind mann on stīge.  Þes cræft tōcnāwennesse is sēo hand þe ūre geþōhtas gegripeþ and hīe geornlice behealdeþ, þæt wē magon hiora gelīcnesse and hiora ungelīcnesse gecnawan.

Of þissum cræfte cymeþ se māra cræft dōmes.  Forþām þe witt, þēah hē swiftlice gegaderaþ manigfealde geþōhtas, ne cann hē ā betwēonan hiora weorþscipe.  Swā swā se gleaw ceorl cann manigfealde blōstman gegaderian, ac se cræftega wīrt cann þā wyrta cēosan þe hǣlo brēngaþ, swā cann witt manigfealde geþōhtas gegaderian, ac dōm sceal þā geþōhtas cēosan þe sōþfæstnesse brēngaþ.  Witt is swēte and wynsum on his weorce, ac dōm is strang and stedefæst on his staþole.  Witt is swā swā se swiftan hræfn, þe flīegeþ ofer manigum landum, ac dōm is swā swā se gleawe beo, þe his hunig geornlice ceoseþ.

Þonne se mod cann wel betwēonan sundor-geþōhtum, þonne cymeþ se cræft clænnysse.  Forþām þe sēo clænnes þæs modes is swā swā sēo beorhtnes þæs glæses, þurh hwone wē magon þā þing gesēon þe on ūs besceawiað.  Gif se glæs biþ besmiten, þonne ne magon wē wel þurh hine gesēon.  Swā ēac, gif se mod biþ bedyrned mid unclǣnum geþōhtum, ne mæg hē þā sōþfæstnesse gesēon.  Ac hwæt is sēo clænnes þæs modes, būton þæt wē ūre geþōhtas habbaþ clæne and smēðe and wel geordnet, swā þæt wē magon ælc geþōht āscūfan fram þām oðrum?  Forþām þe þēah þe ūre līchaman eagan magon gesēon þæt sum þing biþ hwīt oððe blæc, þēah þā geþōhtas þæs hwītes and þæs blæces ne magon beon gemenged on ūrum mode.  Swā ēac, þēah þe ūre līchaman tungan mage gefēlan þæt sum þing biþ swēte oððe biter, þēah þā geþōhtas þæs swētes and þæs biteres ne magon beon gemenged on ūrum mode.

Þonne se mod cann wel betwēonan sundor-geþōhtum and hīe habban clæne and smēðe, þonne cymeþ se cræft geanlīcnesse.  Forþām þe se cræft geanlīcnesse is swā swā se cræft þæs smeahes, þe cann þā mislican mētalas geanlīcian and hiora weorþscipe gecnawan.  Swā ēac, se mod cann þā mislican geþōhtas geanlīcian and hiora weorþscipe gecnawan.  Hē cann geanlīcian geþōht wiþ geþōht, and þing wiþ þing, and tīd wiþ tīd, and stede wiþ stede.  Hē cann geanlīcian þæt grēate wiþ þæt lȳtle, þæt lange wiþ þæt scorte, þæt hefige wiþ þæt lēohte.  Of þissum cræfte geanlīcnesse cymeþ sēo brādnes and sēo dēopnes ūres geþēodes, forþām þe wē ne magon geþencan nān þing būton wē hit magon geanlīcian wiþ sum oðer þing.

Ac her me mæg sum mann āxian, "Gif se cræft geanlīcnesse is swā nytlic tō þām mode, hū is hit þæt þā dumban neten habbaþ nānne cræft geanlīcnesse?"  Ic andswarie, þæt þā dumban neten habbaþ sumne cræft geanlīcnesse, ac hē is swīðe wancol and unstrang.  Forþām þe þā dumban neten ne magon geþencan būton þā þing þe hīe magon gesēon oþþe gehīeran oþþe gefēlan.  Hīe ne magon geþencan þā þing þe wǣron on geārdagum, oþþe þā þing þe cumaþ on tōweardum dagum.  Hīe ne magon geþencan þā þing þe sindon on oðrum landum, oþþe þā þing þe sindon on heofonum.  Ac se mann, þurh þone cræft geanlīcnesse, mæg geþencan ealle þās þing, and fela māra þing þe ic her ne mæg ātellan.

Þonne se mod cann wel betwēonan sundor-geþōhtum, and hīe habban clæne and smēðe, and hē cann wel geanlīcian geþōht wiþ geþōht, þonne cymeþ se cræft gesamnunge.  Forþām þe se cræft gesamnunge is swā swā se cræft þæs hrēodes, þe cann manigfealde þing gegaderian and hīe on ān gegaderian.  Swā ēac, se mod cann manigfealde geþōhtas gegaderian and hīe on ān gegaderian.  Hē cann gegaderian geþōht wiþ geþōht, and þing wiþ þing, and tīd wiþ tīd.  Hē cann gegaderian þā twelf monaþ on ān gear, and þā seofon dagas on āne wucu.  Hē cann gegaderian hund-teontig scēapa on ānne heord, and þūsend manna on āne fyrde.  Of þissum cræfte gesamnunge cymeþ sēo miht and sēo strengþu ūres geþēodes, forþām þe wē ne magon nān grēate þing geþencan būton wē hit magon gegaderian of manigum lȳtlum þingum.

Ac her me mæg sum mann āxian, "Gif se cræft gesamnunge is swā nytlic tō þām mode, hū is hit þæt þā dumban neten habbaþ nānne cræft gesamnunge?"  Ic andswarie, þæt þā dumban neten habbaþ sumne cræft gesamnunge, ac hē is swīðe wancol and unstrang.  Forþām þe þā dumban neten ne magon gegaderian būton þā þing þe hīe magon gesēon ætgædere oþþe gehīeran ætgædere oþþe gefēlan ætgædere.  Hīe ne magon gegaderian þā þing þe ne sindon ætgædere.  Ac se mann, þurh þone cræft gesamnunge, mæg gegaderian ealle þās þing, and fela māra þing þe ic her ne mæg ātellan.

Þonne se mod cann wel betwēonan sundor-geþōhtum, and hīe habban clæne and smēðe, and hē cann wel geanlīcian geþōht wiþ geþōht, and hē cann wel gegaderian geþōht wiþ geþōht, þonne cymeþ se cræft naman.  Forþām þe se cræft naman is swā swā se cræft þæs sealfere, þe cann þā mislican þing mid mislicum naman gecīgean.  Swā ēac, se mod cann þā mislican geþōhtas mid mislicum naman gecīgean.  Hē cann þone geþōht þæs mannes gecīgean "mann," and þone geþōht þæs horses gecīgean "hors," and þone geþōht þæs trēowes gecīgean "trēow."  Of þissum cræfte naman cymeþ sēo miht and sēo beorhtnes ūre sprǣce, forþām þe wē ne magon nān þing sprecan būton wē hit magon gecīgean mid sumum naman.

Ac her me mæg sum mann āxian, "Gif se cræft naman is swā nytlic tō þām mode, hū is hit þæt þā dumban neten habbaþ nānne cræft naman?"  Ic andswarie, þæt þā dumban neten habbaþ sumne cræft naman, ac hē is swīðe wancol and unstrang.  Forþām þe þā dumban neten ne magon gecīgean þā þing mid mislicum naman, ac hīe habbaþ ānlīcne stefn for eallum þingum.  Ac se mann, þurh þone cræft naman, mæg gecīgean ealle þing mid mislicum naman, and þæt is se mǣsta dǣl þære manna sprǣce þe hīe fram þām dumbum neatum gescēaðaþ.

Þonne se mod cann wel betwēonan sundor-geþōhtum, and hīe habban clæne and smēðe, and hē cann wel geanlīcian geþōht wiþ geþōht, and hē cann wel gegaderian geþōht wiþ geþōht, and hē cann wel gecīgean geþōht mid naman, þonne cymeþ se cræft ādietrodon.  Forþām þe se cræft ādietrodon is se hēahsta cræft þæs modes, þurh hwone se mann mæg āstīgan fram þissum eorþlicum þingum tō þām heofonlicum þingum.  Forþām þe se cræft ādietrodon is swā swā se cræft þæs fugeles, þe mæg flīegan fram þissum eorþan ūp tō þām heofonum.  Swā ēac, se mod, þurh þone cræft ādietrodon, mæg flīegan fram þissum eorþlicum geþōhtum ūp tō þām heofonlicum geþōhtum.  Hē mæg geþencan þā þing þe sindon ēce and ungesewenlice, þā þing þe ne mihton beon gesewen mid līchaman eagum ne gehīered mid līchaman earum ne gegrāpen mid līchaman handum.

Ac her me mæg sum mann āxian, "Gif se cræft ādietrodon is swā nytlic tō þām mode, hū is hit þæt þā dumban neten habbaþ nānne cræft ādietrodon?"  Ic andswarie, þæt þā dumban neten ne magon nā þone cræft ādietrodon habban, forþām þe hīe ne habbaþ nānne geþēod buton þone geþēod hiora līchaman.  Hīe ne magon geþencan nān þing buton þā þing þe hīe magon gesēon oþþe gehīeran oþþe gefēlan.  Ac se mann, þurh þone cræft ādietrodon, mæg geþencan ealle þing, ægþer ge þā þe sindon gesewenlice ge þā þe sindon ungesewenlice, and þæt is se mǣsta dǣl þæs mannes geþēodes þe hine fram þām dumbum neatum gescēaðaþ.

Þus hæbbe wē gesprecen be þām cræftum þæs modes, þurh hwone se mann is gesceapen on gelīcnesse his Scyppendes.  Uton wē þonne þās cræftas on ūs geornlice gecīgean and hīe mid eallre estfulnesse brūcan, þæt wē magon þurh hīe becuman þā beorhtan burglēode þæs heofonlican rīces.  Āmen.
summary:
Certainly! Here’s a summary of the main content of the passage:

1. **Discernment and Knowledge**: 
   - The ability to discern and distinguish between different ideas is crucial for acquiring knowledge. 
   - Confusion arises when the mind fails to distinctly perceive different objects and their qualities.
   - This faculty allows the mind to recognize the certainty and evidence of propositions, often mistaken for innate truths.

2. **Wit vs. Judgment**:
   - Wit involves assembling ideas quickly, often creating entertaining and agreeable images.
   - Judgment requires careful separation of ideas to avoid confusion and ensure clarity of reason.
   - Wit is appreciated for its immediate appeal, while judgment involves deeper analysis and truth-seeking.

3. **Clearness to Prevent Confusion**:
   - Clear and definite ideas prevent confusion, even if sensory perceptions vary.
   - For example, even if sugar tastes different under different conditions, clear ideas of "bitter" and "sweet" remain distinct.

4. **Comparing**:
   - Comparing ideas involves examining their extent, degrees, time, place, and other circumstances. 
   - This operation leads to a broad variety of relational ideas.

5. **Brutes and Comparison**:
   - Animals may have distinct ideas but do not compare them extensively.
   - Humans uniquely compare ideas beyond immediate sensory circumstances, aiding abstract reasoning.

6. **Compounding**:
   - The mind can combine simple ideas to form complex ones, such as forming a dozen from several units.
   - This faculty seems limited in animals, who may recognize combinations of simple ideas but do not create complex ideas themselves.

7. **Brutes and Compounding**:
   - Animals may recognize combinations of sensory attributes but don’t seem to create complex ideas akin to human cognition.
   - For example, a bitch may care for young foxes like her puppies if their relationship is established through nursing.

8. **Naming**:
   - As children gain ideas, they use words to signify these ideas, often creating unique names.
   - Words are used to communicate internal ideas to others.

9. **Abstraction**:
   - To manage endless particular ideas, the mind creates general ideas through abstraction, separating appearances from their specific circumstances.
   - These abstract ideas become general representatives (universals) and their corresponding terms are general names.

10. **Brutes and Abstraction**:
    - Unlike humans, animals do not seem to possess the ability to abstract or form general ideas.
    - Abstract thinking and the use of general signs, such as words, distinguish human cognition from that of brutes.

The central theme of the passage is the cognitive faculties of the human mind, particularly focusing on discernment, judgment, comparison, compounding, naming, and abstraction, and how these faculties differentiate humans from animals.

原文:
1. No Knowledge without Discernment.
Another faculty we may take notice of in our minds is that of DISCERNING and DISTINGUISHING between the several ideas it has. It is not enough to have a confused perception of something in general. Unless the mind had a distinct perception of different objects and their qualities, it would be capable of very little knowledge, though the bodies that affect us were as busy about us as they are now, and the mind were continually employed in thinking. On this faculty of distinguishing one thing from another depends the evidence and certainty of several, even very general, propositions, which have passed for innate truths;—because men, overlooking the true cause why those propositions find universal assent, impute it wholly to native uniform impressions; whereas it in truth depends upon this clear discerning faculty of the mind, whereby it PERCEIVES two ideas to be the same, or different. But of this more hereafter.
2. The Difference of Wit and Judgment.
How much the imperfection of accurately discriminating ideas one from another lies, either in the dulness or faults of the organs of sense; or want of acuteness, exercise, or attention in the understanding; or hastiness and precipitancy, natural to some tempers, I will not here examine: it suffices to take notice, that this is one of the operations that the mind may reflect on and observe in itself. It is of that consequence to its other knowledge, that so far as this faculty is in itself dull, or not rightly made use of, for the distinguishing one thing from another,—so far our notions are confused, and our reason and judgment disturbed or misled. If in having our ideas in the memory ready at hand consists quickness of parts; in this, of having them unconfused, and being able nicely to distinguish one thing from another, where there is but the least difference, consists, in a great measure, the exactness of judgment, and clearness of reason, which is to be observed in one man above another. And hence perhaps may be given some reason of that common observation,—that men who have a great deal of wit, and prompt memories, have not always the clearest judgment or deepest reason. For WIT lying most in the assemblage of ideas, and putting those together with quickness and variety, wherein can be found any resemblance or congruity, thereby to make up pleasant pictures and agreeable visions in the fancy; JUDGMENT, on the contrary, lies quite on the other side, in separating carefully, one from another, ideas wherein can be found the least difference, thereby to avoid being misled by similitude, and by affinity to take one thing for another. This is a way of proceeding quite contrary to metaphor and allusion; wherein for the most part lies that entertainment and pleasantry of wit, which strikes so lively on the fancy, and therefore is so acceptable to all people, because its beauty appears at first sight, and there is required no labour of thought to examine what truth or reason there is in it. The mind, without looking any further, rests satisfied with the agreeableness of the picture and the gaiety of the fancy. And it is a kind of affront to go about to examine it, by the severe rules of truth and good reason; whereby it appears that it consists in something that is not perfectly conformable to them.
3. Clearness alone hinders Confusion.
To the well distinguishing our ideas, it chiefly contributes that they be CLEAR and DETERMINATE. And when they are so, it will not breed any confusion or mistake about them, though the senses should (as sometimes they do) convey them from the same object differently on different occasions, and so seem to err. For, though a man in a fever should from sugar have a bitter taste, which at another time would produce a sweet one, yet the idea of bitter in that man’s mind would be as clear and distinct from the idea of sweet as if he had tasted only gall. Nor does it make any more confusion between the two ideas of sweet and bitter that the same sort of body produces at one time one, and at another time another idea by the taste, than it makes a confusion in two ideas of white and sweet, or white and round, that the same piece of sugar produces them both in the mind at the same time. And the ideas of orange-colour and azure, that are produced in the mind by the same parcel of the infusion of lignum nephritium, are no less distinct ideas than those of the same colours taken from two very different bodies.
4. Comparing.
The COMPARING them one with another, in respect of extent, degrees, time, place, or any other circumstances, is another operation of the mind about its ideas, and is that upon which depends all that large tribe of ideas comprehended under RELATION; which, of how vast an extent it is, I shall have occasion to consider hereafter.
5. Brutes compare but imperfectly.
How far brutes partake in this faculty, is not easy to determine. I imagine they have it not in any great degree, for, though they probably have several ideas distinct enough, yet it seems to me to be the prerogative of human understanding, when it has sufficiently distinguished any ideas, so as to perceive them to be perfectly different, and so consequently two, to cast about and consider in what circumstances they are capable to be compared. And therefore, I think, beasts compare not their ideas further than some sensible circumstances annexed to the objects themselves. The other power of comparing, which may be observed in men, belonging to general ideas, and useful only to abstract reasonings, we may probably conjecture beasts have not.
6. Compounding.
The next operation we may observe in the mind about its ideas is COMPOSITION; whereby it puts together several of those simple ones it has received from sensation and reflection, and combines them into complex ones. Under this of composition may be reckoned also that of ENLARGING, wherein, though the composition does not so much appear as in more complex ones, yet it is nevertheless a putting several ideas together, though of the same kind. Thus, by adding several units together, we make the idea of a dozen; and putting together the repeated ideas of several perches, we frame that of a furlong.
7. Brutes compound but little.
In this also, I suppose, brutes come far short of man. For, though they take in, and retain together, several combinations of simple ideas, as possibly the shape, smell, and voice of his master make up the complex idea a dog has of him, or rather are so many distinct marks whereby he knows him; yet I do not think they do of themselves ever compound them, and make complex ideas. And perhaps even where we think they have complex ideas, it is only one simple one that directs them in the knowledge of several things, which possibly they distinguish less by their sight than we imagine. For I have been credibly informed that a bitch will nurse, play with, and be fond of young foxes, as much as, and in place of her puppies, if you can but get them once to suck her so long that her milk may go through them. And those animals which have a numerous brood of young ones at once, appear not to have any knowledge of their number; for though they are mightily concerned for any of their young that are taken from them whilst they are in sight or hearing, yet if one or two of them be stolen from them in their absence, or without noise, they appear not to miss them, or to have any sense that their number is lessened.
8. Naming.
When children have, by repeated sensations, got ideas fixed in their memories, they begin by degrees to learn the use of signs. And when they have got the skill to apply the organs of speech to the framing of articulate sounds, they begin to make use of words, to signify their ideas to others. These verbal signs they sometimes borrow from others, and sometimes make themselves, as one may observe among the new and unusual names children often give to things in the first use of language.
9. Abstraction.
The use of words then being to stand as outward mark of our internal ideas, and those ideas being taken from particular things, if every particular idea that we take up should have a distinct name, names must be endless. To prevent this, the mind makes the particular ideas received from particular objects to become general; which is done by considering them as they are in the mind such appearances,—separate from all other existences, and the circumstances of real existence, as time, place, or any other concomitant ideas. This is called ABSTRACTION, whereby ideas taken from particular beings become general representatives of all of the same kind; and their names general names, applicable to whatever exists conformable to such abstract ideas. Such precise, naked appearances in the mind, without considering how, whence, or with what others they came there, the understanding lays up (with names commonly annexed to them) as the standards to rank real existences into sorts, as they agree with these patterns, and to denominate them accordingly. Thus the same colour being observed to-day in chalk or snow, which the mind yesterday received from milk, it considers that appearance alone, makes it a representative of all of that kind; and having given it the name WHITENESS, it by that sound signifies the same quality wheresoever to be imagined or met with; and thus universals, whether ideas or terms, are made.
11. Brutes abstract not.
If it may be doubted whether beasts compound and enlarge their ideas that way to any degree; this, I think, I may be positive in,—that the power of abstracting is not at all in them; and that the having of general ideas is that which puts a perfect distinction betwixt man and brutes, and is an excellency which the faculties of brutes do by no means attain to. For it is evident we observe no footsteps in them of making use of general signs for universal ideas; from which we have reason to imagine that they have not the faculty of abstracting, or making general ideas, since they have no use of words, or any other general signs.

原文:
Enter MATHIAS and KATHARINE. 75

MATHIAS. What make the Jew and Lodowick so private?
I fear me 'tis about fair Abigail.
[Aside.]

BARABAS. [to LODOWICK.] Yonder comes Don Mathias; let us stay: 76
He loves my daughter, and she holds him dear;
But I have sworn to frustrate both their hopes,
And be reveng'd upon the—governor.
[Aside.]
[Exit LODOWICK.]

KATHARINE. This Moor is comeliest, is he not? speak, son.

MATHIAS. No, this is the better, mother, view this well.

BARABAS. Seem not to know me here before your mother,
Lest she mistrust the match that is in hand:
When you have brought her home, come to my house;
Think of me as thy father: son, farewell.

MATHIAS. But wherefore talk'd Don Lodowick with you?

BARABAS. Tush, man! we talk'd of diamonds, not of Abigail.

KATHARINE. Tell me, Mathias, is not that the Jew?

BARABAS. As for the comment on the Maccabees,
I have it, sir, and 'tis at your command.

MATHIAS. Yes, madam, and my talk with him was 77
About the borrowing of a book or two.

KATHARINE. Converse not with him; he is cast off from heaven.—

MATHIAS. Sirrah Jew, remember the book.

BARABAS. Marry, will I, sir.

FIRST OFFICER. Come, I have made a reasonable market; let's away.
[Exeunt OFFICERS with SLAVES.]

Thy birth, condition, and profession.

my profession what you please.

BARABAS. Hast thou no trade? then listen to my words,
And I will teach [thee] that shall stick by thee:
First, be thou void of these affections,
Compassion, love, vain hope, and heartless fear;
Be mov'd at nothing, see thou pity none,
But to thyself smile when the Christians moan.

ITHAMORE. O, brave, master! 78 I worship your nose 79 for this.

BARABAS. As for myself, I walk abroad o' nights,
And kill sick people groaning under walls:
Sometimes I go about and poison wells;
And now and then, to cherish Christian thieves,
I am content to lose some of my crowns,
That I may, walking in my gallery,
See 'em go pinion'd along by my door.
Being young, I studied physic, and began
To practice first upon the Italian;
There I enrich'd the priests with burials,
And always kept the sexton's arms in ure 80
With digging graves and ringing dead men's knells:
And, after that, was I an engineer,
And in the wars 'twixt France and Germany,
Under pretence of helping Charles the Fifth,
Slew friend and enemy with my stratagems:
Then, after that, was I an usurer,
And with extorting, cozening, forfeiting,
And tricks belonging unto brokery,
I fill'd the gaols with bankrupts in a year,
And with young orphans planted hospitals;
And every moon made some or other mad,
And now and then one hang himself for grief,
Pinning upon his breast a long great scroll
How I with interest tormented him.
But mark how I am blest for plaguing them;—
I have as much coin as will buy the town.
But tell me now, how hast thou spent thy time?

ITHAMORE. Faith, master,
In setting Christian villages on fire,
Chaining of eunuchs, binding galley-slaves.
One time I was an hostler in an inn,
And in the night-time secretly would I steal
To travellers' chambers, and there cut their throats:
Once at Jerusalem, where the pilgrims kneel'd,
I strewed powder on the marble stones,
And therewithal their knees would rankle so,
That I have laugh'd a-good 81 to see the cripples
Go limping home to Christendom on stilts.

BARABAS. Why, this is something: make account of me
As of thy fellow; we are villains both;
Both circumcised; we hate Christians both:
Be true and secret; thou shalt want no gold.
But stand aside; here comes Don Lodowick.

Enter LODOWICK. 82

LODOWICK. O, Barabas, well met;
Where is the diamond you told me of?

BARABAS. I have it for you, sir: please you walk in with me.—
What, ho, Abigail! open the door, I say!

]From Ormus, and the post stays here within.

BARABAS. Give me the letters.—Daughter, do you hear?
Entertain Lodowick, the governor's son,
With all the courtesy you can afford,
Provided that you keep your maidenhead:
Use him as if he were a Philistine;
Dissemble, swear, protest, vow love to him: 83
He is not of the seed of Abraham.—
[Aside to her.]
I am a little busy, sir; pray, pardon me.—
Abigail, bid him welcome for my sake.

ABIGAIL. For your sake and his own he's welcome hither.

BARABAS. Daughter, a word more: kiss him, speak him fair,
And like a cunning Jew so cast about,
That ye be both made sure 84 ere you come out.
[Aside to her.]

ABIGAIL. O father, Don Mathias is my love!

BARABAS. I know it: yet, I say, make love to him;
Do, it is requisite it should be so.—
[Aside to her.]
Nay, on my life, it is my factor's hand;
But go you in, I'll think upon the account.
[Exeunt ABIGAIL and LODOWICK into the house.]
The account is made, for Lodovico 85 dies.
My factor sends me word a merchant's fled
That owes me for a hundred tun of wine:
I weigh it thus much[snapping his fingers]! I have wealth enough;
For now by this has he kiss'd Abigail,
And she vows love to him, and he to her.
As sure as heaven rain'd manna for the Jews,
So sure shall he and Don Mathias die:
His father was my chiefest enemy.

**[Scene:  On strǣte neah þǣm stōwe Matthie.]**

**[Enter Matthie and his mōdor, Cātharina.]**

**Matthie:**   Mīn mōdor, ic habbe lang geseted þæt þǣr is sum dēogol þing betwēonan þone Iūdēiscan, Barabas, and þone Lodowic.  Hīe oft sprǣcaþ in hūsum, and hīe sendeþ ærendmen betwēonan him.

**Cātharina:**   Hū!  Ne sēo þū nā āfyrht, mīn sunu.  Þā Iūdēas sindon ā fæcne and ungelēaffulle.  Hīe ne cunnon nā lufu oþþe trēowþe, ac ā sēceaþ hīe hīera āgen gewinn.

**Matthie:**   Ic cann nā forstandan hƿæt þæt gewinn biþ.  Lodowic is þæs ealdormannes sunu, and Barabas is… wel, hē is Iūdēisc.  Hƿæt gemǣne hæbbaþ hīe?

**Cātharina:**   Hwa cann secgan?  Ac ic þē secge, Matthie, beware þū þæs Iūdēiscan.  Hē is nā þīn frēond.

**[Enter Barabas and Lodowic.]**

**Barabas:**   Gōdne dæg, Matthie!  Ic ne wēnde nā þæt ic þē hēr gemētte.

**Barabas:**   Þæt is gōd, þæt is gōd.  And hū gæþ hit þē, Cātharina?

**Cātharina:**   Wel, ic þancie þē, Iūdēa.

**Barabas:**   Þæt me geblīssaþ tō gehȳranne.  And hū standeþ hit mid þīnum sunu?  Is hē gesund and strang?

**Cātharina:**   Hē is, ic þancie þē.

**Barabas:**   Þæt is gōd, þæt is gōd.  Hē is cēne geonga, þīn sunu.  Ic cann gemunan þā tīde þā hē wæs lītel cild, and hē efne swā cēne þā.

**Cātharina:**   Ic þancie þē for þīne word.  Ac nū, Matthie, ūs is tō gānne.  Fara þū wel, Iūdēa.

**[Matthie and Cātharina exeunt.]**

**Barabas:**  [Tō Lodowic]  Þū gesāwe hū ic him besceādode?  Ic spræc nā of þīnre dēore Abigail.

**Lodowic:**  Nēah, þū wǣre swīðe slyt.  Ac hƿæt of Abigail?  Hƿænne mæg ic hīe eft gesēon?

**Barabas:**  Beo geþyldig, mīn frēond.  Þīn tīd cymþ.  Ac nū, ic hæbbe sumne ærend tō gānne.  Fara þū wel.

**[Enter Ithamore.]**

**Barabas:**   Ah, Ithamore!  Þū cymst æt niehstan!  Ic hæbbe sum þing tō tellanne þē.

**Ithamore:**  Hƿæt is hit, mīn hlāford?

**Barabas:**   Ic hæbbe hit gedōn!  Matthie and Lodowic - hīe feallaþ bā intō mīne honda!

**Ithamore:**  Tell me, mīn hlāford, tell me!

**Barabas:**   Ic hæbbe Lodowic beswīcen þæt hē sceolde lufian mīne dohtor, Abigail.  Hē is swa blinde mid lust þæt hē ne gesiehþ þæt hē is acān tool in mīnum handum.

**Ithamore:**  And Matthie?

**Barabas:**   Matthie is eac beswīcen.  Hē ġelīefþ þæt Lodowic is his frēond, ac Lodowic is nā þæs ealdormannes sunu - hē is...wel, þæt is nā her tō tellanne.  Ac hit is genōh tō secganne þæt Matthie is in grēatum frēcednesse.

**Ithamore:**  Þū eart swīðe cræftig, mīn hlāford.  Ac hƿæt is þīn plan?

**Barabas:**   Þe plan, mīn dēore Ithamore, is swīðe fæger in his cræfte.  Lodowic, blinde mid lust, sceal berǣdan Abigail.  Matthie, in his

1. **Mathias and Katharine** - Mathias suspects there is something secretive between the Jew, Barabas, and another character, Lodowick. Katharine, Mathias’s mother, expresses a negative opinion about Jews.

In summary, the passage is a complex interplay of deceit, manipulation, and plans for revenge orchestrated by Barabas, with his daughter Abigail and servant Ithamore playing crucial roles in his schemes against Mathias and the governor’s son, Lodowick.

And be reveng'd upon the—governor.

KATHARINE. This Moor is comeliest, is he not? speak, son.

原文:
[TAMBURLAINE gets up on him into his chair.]

TAMBURLAINE. Now clear the triple region of the air,
And let the Majesty of Heaven behold
Their scourge and terror tread on emperors.
Smile, stars that reign'd at my nativity,
And dim the brightness of your 199 neighbour lamps;
Disdain to borrow light of Cynthia!
For I, the chiefest lamp of all the earth,
First rising in the east with mild aspect,
But fixed now in the meridian line,
Will send up fire to your turning spheres,
And cause the sun to borrow light of you.
My sword struck fire from his coat of steel,
Even in Bithynia, when I took this Turk;
As when a fiery exhalation,
Wrapt in the bowels of a freezing cloud,
Fighting for passage, make[s] the welkin crack,
And casts a flash of lightning to 200 the earth:
But, ere I march to wealthy Persia,
Or leave Damascus and th' Egyptian fields,
As was the fame of Clymene's brain-sick son
That almost brent 201 the axle-tree of heaven,
So shall our swords, our lances, and our shot
Fill all the air with fiery meteors;
Then, when the sky shall wax as red as blood,
It shall be said I made it red myself,
To make me think of naught but blood and war.

ZABINA. Unworthy king, that by thy cruelty
Unlawfully usurp'st the Persian seat,
Dar'st thou, that never saw an emperor
Before thou met my husband in the field,
Being thy captive, thus abuse his state,
Keeping his kingly body in a cage,
That roofs of gold and sun-bright palaces
Should have prepar'd to entertain his grace?
And treading him beneath thy loathsome feet,
Whose feet the kings 202 of Africa have kiss'd?

TECHELLES. You must devise some torment worse, my lord,
To make these captives rein their lavish tongues.

TAMBURLAINE. Zenocrate, look better to your slave.

ZENOCRATE. She is my handmaid's slave, and she shall look
That these abuses flow not from 203 her tongue.—
Chide her, Anippe.

ANIPPE. Let these be warnings, then, for you, 204 my slave,
How you abuse the person of the king;
Or else I swear to have you whipt stark nak'd. 205

BAJAZETH. Great Tamburlaine, great in my overthrow,
Ambitious pride shall make thee fall as low,
For treading on the back of Bajazeth,
That should be horsed on four mighty kings.

TAMBURLAINE. Thy names, and titles, and thy dignities 206
Are fled from Bajazeth, and remain with me,
That will maintain it 'gainst a world of kings.—
Put him in again.

[They put him into the cage.]

BAJAZETH. Is this a place for mighty Bajazeth?
Confusion light on him that helps thee thus!

TAMBURLAINE. There, whiles 207 he lives, shall Bajazeth be kept;
And, where I go, be thus in triumph drawn;
And thou, his wife, shalt 208 feed him with the scraps
My servitors shall bring thee from my board;
For he that gives him other food than this,
Shall sit by him, and starve to death himself:
This is my mind, and I will have it so.
Not all the kings and emperors of the earth,
If they would lay their crowne before my feet,
Shall ransom him, or take him from his cage:
The ages that shall talk of Tamburlaine,
Even from this day to Plato's wondrous year,
Shall talk how I have handled Bajazeth:
These Moors, that drew him from Bithynia
To fair Damascus, where we now remain,
Shall lead him with us wheresoe'er we go.—
Techelles, and my loving followers,
Now may we see Damascus' lofty towers,
Like to the shadows of Pyramides
That with their beauties grace 209 the Memphian fields.
The golden stature 210 of their feather'd bird, 211
That spreads her wings upon the city-walls,
Shall not defend it from our battering shot:
The townsmen mask in silk and cloth of gold,
And every house is as a treasury;
The men, the treasure, and the town are 212 ours.

THERIDAMAS. Your tents of white now pitch'd before the gates,
And gentle flags of amity display'd,
I doubt not but the governor will yield,
Offering Damascus to your majesty.

TAMBURLAINE. So shall he have his life, and all the rest:
But, if he stay until the bloody flag
Be once advanc'd on my vermilion tent,
He dies, and those that kept us out so long;
And, when they see me march in black array,
With mournful streamers hanging down their heads,
Were in that city all the world contain'd,
Not one should scape, but perish by our swords.

ZENOCRATE. Yet would you have some pity for my sake,
Because it is my country 213 and my father's.

TAMBURLAINE. Not for the world, Zenocrate, if I have sworn.—
Come; bring in the Turk.
生成:
Hwæt! Ic secge eow nu be ðam miclan and ðam egesfulan Tamburlaine, se þe hæfde his handa befangene mid þam cynedomum manna, and his heafod gecirred mid þam cræfte his agenre mægenes. He sæt on heahsetle, geglenged mid golde and gimmum, and his eagan blikodon mid þam fyre unasecgendlicre dyrstignesse.

And þa cwæð Tamburlaine mid stefne swa hlud swa þunor: "Ic eom se micla Tamburlaine, se þe hæefþ gebēat ealle cyningas and ealdormen fram eastdæle to westdæle! Ic eom se þe hæfþ gehnægde þa heartran þara rice, and gehnacod þa heafdu þara ofermodigan! Min nama is āwriten on þam steorrum, and min hlisa scæl wunian oð ende þyssere worulde!"

And þa cwæð Zabina, seo cwēn þara Persea, mid stefne gehæfted mid sāre: "Eala, þu wælhrēowa Tamburlaine! Hu miht þu þus fægnian on þīnre anwealde, þonne þu hæfst gebrocod þæt heafod mīnes hlāfordes, þæs mǣran cyninges Bajazeth? Hu miht þu þus āhēawan þone þe ǣr wæs swa mære and swa mihtig, and nu is gehnacod to nahte?"

And Techelles, se wæs Tamburlaines þegn, cwæð mid grimman andgite: "Hlāford, hwi forbēarest þu þissum wifmen þæt heo þus spræce? Hēt hie beon gestilled, oððe læt hie beon geþrēad under þīnum fōtum!"

Ac Zenocrate, Tamburlaines lufu, cwæð mid miltsum wordum: "Nān, Techelles, ne beo þu swa hrēð to cwylmenne. Lǣt þis wif hire sāre gecyðan. Hit is þearle grimlic þing þæt heo hæfþ geþoled."

And þa cwæð Bajazeth, se ǣr wæs cyning, fram þam cwearterne þær he wæs gehæfted: "Ahyr me, Tamburlaine! Ic wāt þæt þīn dyrstigness is micel, and þæt þīn hand is strang. Ac ic secge þē, þīn ofermetto scæl þē fordon! Se þe āhīehð hine sylfne, he byð gehnacod; and se þe geēaðmēdeð hine sylfne, he byð āhafen!"

And Tamburlaine cwæð mid hlūdan hleahtre: "Þū eart gehnacod, Bajazeth! Þīn cynedōm is nu min, and þīn hlisa is forweard! Ic eom nu se mǣsta cyning under þære sunnan, and nān ne mæg standan ongēan me!"

And he bebead þæt Bajazeth sceolde beon gehæfted on īsernum bendum, and þæt he sceolde beon gefēded mid þam crumum fram his bōrde. And he cwæð þæt swa he wolde dōn eallum þam þe him wiðsōcon.

And þa cwæð Theridamas, se wæs Tamburlaines oðer þegn: "Hlāford, þīn weorud stent gearu æt þam geatum Damascu. Hwat is þīn willa?"

And Tamburlaine cwæð: "Lǣt us gān and winnan þā ceastre! Ic hæbbe geāðswarade þæt ic wolde hie forbærnan, and ic ne ābrece min āð!"

Ac Zenocrate cwæð mid wēpendum heortan: "Eala, min hlāford, āria þā burgware! Damascu is min ēðel, and þær wunigeð min fæder and min mōdor. Ne forbærn þu þā ceastre, ic þē bidde!"

Ac Tamburlaine cwæð: "Ne mæg ic þē gehyrsumian on þyssum þinge, min lufu. Ic hæbbe geāðswarade, and ic ne mæg min āð ābrecan."

And swa ferde Tamburlaine mid his weorude to Damascu, and he wann þā ceastre mid strangre handa. And he bebead þæt seo burg sceolde beon forbærned, and ealle þā burgware ofslagene, būton þam þe woldon him gehyrsumian.

And þus cwæð Tamburlaine, se wæs swa mihtig and swa egesful: "Ic eom se hyrde, and þis is min heord! Se þe ne wyle gān on minum wege, he scæl beon fortrēdde under mīnum fōtum!"
summary:
Certainly! This passage is an excerpt from Christopher Marlowe's play "Tamburlaine." Here's a summary of its main content:

**Scene Description**:
- **Tamburlaine** asserts his dominance by ascending to a throne or prominent position.

**Key Events**:
- **Tamburlaine** gives a soliloquy where he boasts about his power and the fear he instills in emperors. He describes how he has subjugated his enemies, including Bajazeth, and how his ascent to power is as monumental as heavenly events.
- **Zabina**, Bajazeth's wife, condemns Tamburlaine's cruelty and his unlawful seizure of the Persian throne. She laments her husband’s captivity, who she believes deserves respect and honor rather than imprisonment in a cage.
- **Techelles**, one of Tamburlaine’s followers, suggests that more severe torment should be devised for the captives to silence their complaints.
- **Zenocrate**, Tamburlaine's love interest, instructs her handmaid **Anippe** to reprimand Zabina for her insults.
- **Bajazeth** speaks from his confinement, cursing Tamburlaine and warning that his pride will lead to his downfall.
- **Tamburlaine** dismisses Bajazeth’s titles and claims, declaring that Bajazeth’s former glories now belong to him. He orders that Bajazeth be kept in the cage and fed scraps, asserting that anyone who disobeys will starve.
- He further declares that no power on earth will be able to rescue Bajazeth from his captivity, ensuring that future generations will remember his deeds.
- **Theridamas** talks about how Tamburlaine’s forces are ready to capture Damascus, anticipating that the governor might surrender to avoid bloodshed.
- **Zenocrate** appeals to Tamburlaine to have pity on Damascus, her homeland, but Tamburlaine remains resolute and declares that he must keep his oath.

**Themes**:
- The passage vividly explores themes of power, cruelty, pride, and conquest.
- Tamburlaine’s monologue emphasizes his belief in his own greatness and invincibility.
- Zabina’s and Bajazeth’s speeches underscore the suffering caused by Tamburlaine’s ambition, as well as the fall from high status to utter humiliation.
- Zenocrate’s plea highlights the personal conflicts and emotional costs of war and conquest.

Overall, the passage illustrates Tamburlaine’s ruthless nature, his disregard for mercy, and his desire to be eternally remembered for his conquests.

原文:
[TAMBURLAINE gets up on him into his chair.]

TAMBURLAINE. Now clear the triple region of the air,
And let the Majesty of Heaven behold
Their scourge and terror tread on emperors.
Smile, stars that reign'd at my nativity,
And dim the brightness of your 199 neighbour lamps;
Disdain to borrow light of Cynthia!
For I, the chiefest lamp of all the earth,
First rising in the east with mild aspect,
But fixed now in the meridian line,
Will send up fire to your turning spheres,
And cause the sun to borrow light of you.
My sword struck fire from his coat of steel,
Even in Bithynia, when I took this Turk;
As when a fiery exhalation,
Wrapt in the bowels of a freezing cloud,
Fighting for passage, make[s] the welkin crack,
And casts a flash of lightning to 200 the earth:
But, ere I march to wealthy Persia,
Or leave Damascus and th' Egyptian fields,
As was the fame of Clymene's brain-sick son
That almost brent 201 the axle-tree of heaven,
So shall our swords, our lances, and our shot
Fill all the air with fiery meteors;
Then, when the sky shall wax as red as blood,
It shall be said I made it red myself,
To make me think of naught but blood and war.

ZABINA. Unworthy king, that by thy cruelty
Unlawfully usurp'st the Persian seat,
Dar'st thou, that never saw an emperor
Before thou met my husband in the field,
Being thy captive, thus abuse his state,
Keeping his kingly body in a cage,
That roofs of gold and sun-bright palaces

BAJAZETH. Great Tamburlaine, great in my overthrow,

TAMBURLAINE. Thy names, and titles, and thy dignities 206

That will maintain it 'gainst a world of kings.—

原文:
KING. My Lord of Guise, we understand that you
Have gathered a power of men.
What your intent is yet we cannot learn,
But we presume it is not for our good.

GUISE. Why I am no traitor to the crowne of France.
What I have done tis for the Gospel's sake.

EPERNOUNE. Nay for the Popes sake, and shine owne benefite.
What Peere in France but thou (aspiring Guise)
Durst be in armes without the Kings consent?
I challenge thee for treason in the cause.

GUISE. Oh base Epernoune, were not his highnes heere,
Thou shouldst perceive the Duke of Guise is mov'd.

KING. Be patient Guise and threat not Epernoune,
Least thou perceive the King of France be mov'd.

GUISE. Why? I am a Prince of the Valoyses line,
Therfore an enemy to the Burbonites.
I am a juror in the holy league,
And therfore hated of the Protestants.
What should I doe but stand upon my guarde?
And being able, Ile keep an hoast in pay.

EPERNOUNE. Thou able to maintaine an hoast in pay,
That livest by forraine exhibition?
The Pope and King of Spaine are thy good frends,
Else all France knowes how poor a Duke thou art.

KING. I, those are they that feed him with their golde,
To countermaund our will and check our freends.

GUISE. My Lord, to speak more plainely, thus it is:
Being animated by Religious zeale,
I meane to muster all the power I can,
To overthrow those factious Puritans:
And know, the Pope will sell his triple crowne,
I, and the catholick Philip King of Spaine,
Ere I shall want, will cause his Indians,
To rip the golden bowels of America.
Navarre that cloakes them underneath his wings,
Shall feele the house of Lorayne is his foe:
Your highnes need not feare mine armies force,
Tis for your safetie and your enemies wrack.

KING. Guise, weare our crowne, and be thou King of France,
And as Dictator make or warre or peace,
Whilste I cry placet like a Senator.
I cannot brook thy hauty insolence,
Dismisse thy campe or else by our Edict,
Be thou proclaimde a traitor throughout France.

GUISE. The choyse is hard, I must dissemble.

[Aside.]

My Lord, in token of my true humilitie,
And simple meaning to your Majestie,
I kisse your graces hand, and take my leave,
Intending to dislodge my campe with speed.

KING. Then farwell Guise, the King and thou art freends.

Exit Guise.

EPERNOUNE. But trust him not my Lord,
For had your highnesse seene with what a pompe
He entred Paris, and how the Citizens
With gifts and shewes did entertaine him
And promised to be at his commaund:
Nay, they fear'd not to speak in the streetes,
That Guise ch, durst stand in armes against the King,
For not effecting of his holines will.

KING. Did they of Paris entertaine him so?
Then meanes he present treason to our state.
Well, let me alone, whose within there?

Enter one with e pen and inke.

Make a discharge of all my counsell straite,
And Ile subscribe my name and seale it straight.
My head shall be my counsell, they are false:
And Epernoune I will be rulde by thee.

EPERNOUNE. My Lord,
I think for safety of your person,
It would be good the Guise were made away,
And so to quite your grace of all suspect.

KING. First let us set our hand and seale to this,
And then Ile tell thee what I meane to doe.

He writes.

So, convey this to the counsell presently.

Exit one.

And Epernoune though I seeme milde and calme,
Thinke not but I am tragicall within:
Ile secretly convey me unto Bloyse,
For now that Paris takes the Guises parse,
Heere is not staying for the King of France,
Unles he means to be betraide and dye:
But as I live, so sure the Guise shall dye.
生成:
Hwæt! Ic wille eow gereccan þæt gewinn, þæt ungesibblice ætstand betweox þam cyninge and þam eorle of Guise, se mid his unrihtum gewinne and ofermettum þone cynedome on hreownesse sette.

Se cyning, on his heorte gedrefed be þam eorle and his micclan here, þone he gesamnod hæfde, cwæð to him, "Eala, Guise, þin weorc is me uncuð. Þu hæfst micelne here gegaderod, ac for hwæs neode? Ic ne seah næfre earfeð on minum rice, þe me ne mihte min agen folc bewarian. Ac me þinceð þæt þu þis ne dēst for minum gode, ac for þinum agenum."

Guise him andswarode, "Min hlaford cyning, ne beo þu swa gedrefed. Ic ne hæbbe nænne yfelne willan ongen þe oððe þin rice. Se here þe ic gegaderod hæbbe, ic hine hæbbe for þæs Hælendes godspelles ware. Hit is æghwylcum Cristenum men to bearme þæt þæt halige geleaf beo gehealden and bewarian wið þam hereticum þe hit willað fordon."

Þa cwæð Epernoune, se wæs þæs cyninges getreowost ealdorman, "Eala, Guise, þu sprēcst lease word. Þu ne cearast na for þam godspelle, ac for þam papan and his agenum willan. Þu wylt þis rice for þe sylfum habban, and þone cyning of his cynedome adrife. Þu eart forsworen and ungetriew, and þu hæfst þone cyning belogen."

Þa wearð Guise swiðe yrre, and cwæð, "Þu lyhst, Epernoune! Ic eom swa æþele geboren swa ænig man on þisum rice, and ic næfre ne pohte yfel ongen þone cyning. Ac ic ne forbere na þæt þu me swa hospest. Þu eart ungesibb and ungefōg, and þu scealt þin worda abidan."

And he teah his seax, and wolde him on Epernoune. Ac se cyning him betweonon eode, and cwæð, "Lætað eowre saca, ic hit eow bidde! Hit ne gedafenað na þæt ge on minum hirede winnan."

Guise þa his seax up ahof, and cwæð, "For þinum lufon, min hlaford cyning, ic wille me nu gestillan. Ac ic swerige þurh þone ælmihtigan God þæt ic me næfre ne forbere þæt þa hereticas and þa þe him fylgeað, and ealra mæst Navarre, se þe on þone cyning swa yfele tiht, ne sculon habban þone hire sylfne on minum agnum lande."

Se cyning wearð þa swiðe yrre, and cwæð, "Guise, þin ofermetta me mislycað. Þu sprīcst swa swa þu wære cyning, and ic nære. Ic þe bebeode þæt þu þisne here tostencest and hamor gange, oððe ic swerige þurh þone ælmihtigan God þæt ic þe swa for swican hæbbe swa ic næfre ær nanne man ne dyde."

Guise him andswarode, "Min hlaford cyning, ic wille þinum willan gehyrsumian. Ac ic hit dō for þinum lufon, na for minum ege."

And he eode ut of þam healle, and eal his geþofta mid him. Ac Epernoune cwæð to þam cyninge, "Min hlaford, ne trūwe þu þisum Guise! He is fæcne and lease, and he þencþ on þe yfel. He wyle þe fordon, gif he æfre mæg."

Se cyning cwæð, "Ic wat þæt he is min fægna, ac ic ne mæg him nu na onfeohtan. He is to strong for me."

And hit gelamp sona æfter þisum þæt se cyning gehyrde þæt ealle þa burgware on Paris Guise heolden, and wið þone cyning wæron. Þa wearð se cyning swiðe gedrefed, forþam he wiste þæt he on micelre nearonesse wæs. He wiste þæt Guise him wolde fordon, and he ne wiste hwat he don mihte.

Þa cwæð he to his witan, "Leofe freond, ge geseoð þæt we on micelre nearonesse sind. Guise is ure fægna, and he wyle us fordon. He hæfþ ealle þa burgware on Paris him to handa, and we ne magon him her on feohtan. Us is betere þæt we fleoð þanon we magon."

Ac his witan him andswarodon, "Næfre we for þam fleoð, hlaford! We willað þe mid ure lifum bewerian."

Se cyning þa gehyrde þæt his witan him fram faran noldon, and he wearð þæs þeawum gleawra. He cwæð þa, "Eala, leofe freond, ic þancie eow eowre getreowþa. Ac us is betere þæt we mid sumum cræfte Guise of þisum life fordōn, þonne we ealle for him losian."

And he cwæð þa to his scrifum, "Writað nu hraðe gewrit, and senðað hit to Guise, and beodað him þæt he cume to me on þam ylcan dæge, forþam ic wille mid him spræcan be micelre neode."

And þa þæt gewrit gewriten wæs, he hit sylf geinseglede, and sende hit to Guise.
summary:
Of course! Here's a summary of the passage:

The King addresses the Duke of Guise, expressing suspicion about the troops Guise has gathered, fearing they are not for the King's benefit. Guise denies any treason, claiming his actions are in support of the Gospel, while Epernoune counters that Guise acts for the Pope and his own gain. Epernoune accuses Guise of treason, and tensions rise between them until the King intervenes to maintain order. Guise defends his actions, asserting his noble lineage and religious zeal, and promises to use his power against the Protestants and their supporter, Navarre. The King, frustrated by Guise's arrogance, demands he disband his troops or be declared a traitor. Guise outwardly complies and leaves, but Epernoune warns the King not to trust him. After learning that the citizens of Paris support Guise, the King realizes the threat of imminent treason and decides to handle matters personally. He begins by formalizing a decree, indicating his future actions against Guise and hinting at a plan to eliminate him to ensure his own safety.

原文:
KING. My Lord of Guise, we understand that you
Have gathered a power of men.
What your intent is yet we cannot learn,
But we presume it is not for our good.

GUISE. Why I am no traitor to the crowne of France.
What I have done tis for the Gospel's sake.

EPERNOUNE. Nay for the Popes sake, and shine owne benefite.
What Peere in France but thou (aspiring Guise)
Durst be in armes without the Kings consent?
I challenge thee for treason in the cause.

GUISE. Oh base Epernoune, were not his highnes heere,
Thou shouldst perceive the Duke of Guise is mov'd.

KING. Be patient Guise and threat not Epernoune,
Least thou perceive the King of France be mov'd.

GUISE. Why? I am a Prince of the Valoyses line,
Therfore an enemy to the Burbonites.
I am a juror in the holy league,
And therfore hated of the Protestants.
What should I doe but stand upon my guarde?
And being able, Ile keep an hoast in pay.

EPERNOUNE. Thou able to maintaine an hoast in pay,
That livest by forraine exhibition?
The Pope and King of Spaine are thy good frends,
Else all France knowes how poor a Duke thou art.

KING. I, those are they that feed him with their golde,
To countermaund our will and check our freends.

GUISE. My Lord, to speak more plainely, thus it is:
Being animated by Religious zeale,
I meane to muster all the power I can,
To overthrow those factious Puritans:
And know, the Pope will sell his triple crowne,
I, and the catholick Philip King of Spaine,
Ere I shall want, will cause his Indians,
To rip the golden bowels of America.
Navarre that cloakes them underneath his wings,
Shall feele the house of Lorayne is his foe:
Your highnes need not feare mine armies force,
Tis for your safetie and your enemies wrack.

KING. Guise, weare our crowne, and be thou King of France,
And as Dictator make or warre or peace,
Whilste I cry placet like a Senator.
I cannot brook thy hauty insolence,
Dismisse thy campe or else by our Edict,
Be thou proclaimde a traitor throughout France.

GUISE. The choyse is hard, I must dissemble.

[Aside.]

My Lord, in token of my true humilitie,
And simple meaning to your Majestie,
I kisse your graces hand, and take my leave,
Intending to dislodge my campe with speed.

KING. Then farwell Guise, the King and thou art freends.

Exit Guise.

EPERNOUNE. But trust him not my Lord,
For had your highnesse seene with what a pompe
He entred Paris, and how the Citizens
With gifts and shewes did entertaine him
And promised to be at his commaund:
Nay, they fear'd not to speak in the streetes,
That Guise ch, durst stand in armes against the King,
For not effecting of his holines will.

KING. Did they of Paris entertaine him so?
Then meanes he present treason to our state.
Well, let me alone, whose within there?

Enter one with e pen and inke.

Make a discharge of all my counsell straite,
And Ile subscribe my name and seale it straight.
My head shall be my counsell, they are false:
And Epernoune I will be rulde by thee.

EPERNOUNE. My Lord,
I think for safety of your person,
It would be good the Guise were made away,
And so to quite your grace of all suspect.

KING. First let us set our hand and seale to this,
And then Ile tell thee what I meane to doe.

He writes.

So, convey this to the counsell presently.

Exit one.

And Epernoune though I seeme milde and calme,
Thinke not but I am tragicall within:
Ile secretly convey me unto Bloyse,
For now that Paris takes the Guises parse,
Heere is not staying for the King of France,
Unles he means to be betraide and dye:
But as I live, so sure the Guise shall dye.

Of course! Here's a summary of the passage:

The King addresses the Duke of Guise, expressing suspicion about the troops Guise has gathered, fearing they are not for the King's benefit. Guise denies any treason, claiming his actions are in support of the Gospel, while Epernoune counters that Guise acts for the Pope and his own gain. Epernoune accuses Guise of treason, and tensions rise between them until the King intervenes to maintain order. Guise defends his actions, asserting his noble lineage and religious zeal, and promises to use his power against the Protestants and their supporter, Navarre. 原文:
What dire offence from am'rous causes springs,
What mighty contests rise from trivial things,
I sing — This verse to Caryl, Muse! is due:
This, ev'n Belinda may vouchsafe to view:
Slight is the subject, but not so the praise,
If She inspire, and He approve my lays.

Say what strange motive, Goddess! could compel
A well-bred Lord t' assault a gentle Belle?
O say what stranger cause, yet unexplor'd,
Could make a gentle Belle reject a Lord?
In tasks so bold, can little men engage,
And in soft bosoms dwells such mighty Rage?

Sol thro' white curtains shot a tim'rous ray,
And oped those eyes that must eclipse the day:
Now lap-dogs give themselves the rousing shake,
And sleepless lovers, just at twelve, awake:
Thrice rung the bell, the slipper knock'd the ground,
And the press'd watch return'd a silver sound.
Belinda still her downy pillow prest,
Her guardian Sylph prolong'd the balmy rest:
'Twas He had summon'd to her silent bed
The morning-dream that hover'd o'er her head;
A Youth more glitt'ring than a Birth-night Beau,
(That ev'n in slumber caus'd her cheek to glow)
Seem'd to her ear his winning lips to lay,
And thus in whispers said, or seem'd to say.
Fairest of mortals, thou distinguish'd care
Of thousand bright Inhabitants of Air!
If e'er one vision touch.'d thy infant thought,
Of all the Nurse and all the Priest have taught;
Of airy Elves by moonlight shadows seen,
The silver token, and the circled green,
Or virgins visited by Angel-pow'rs,
With golden crowns and wreaths of heav'nly flow'rs;
Hear and believe! thy own importance know,
Nor bound thy narrow views to things below.
Some secret truths, from learned pride conceal'd,
To Maids alone and Children are reveal'd:
What tho' no credit doubting Wits may give?
The Fair and Innocent shall still believe.
Know, then, unnumber'd Spirits round thee fly,
The light Militia of the lower sky:
These, tho' unseen, are ever on the wing,
Hang o'er the Box, and hover round the Ring.
Think what an equipage thou hast in Air,
And view with scorn two Pages and a Chair.
As now your own, our beings were of old,
And once inclos'd in Woman's beauteous mould;
Thence, by a soft transition, we repair
From earthly Vehicles to these of air.
Think not, when Woman's transient breath is fled
That all her vanities at once are dead;
Succeeding vanities she still regards,
And tho' she plays no more, o'erlooks the cards.
Her joy in gilded Chariots, when alive,
And love of Ombre, after death survive.
For when the Fair in all their pride expire,
To their first Elements their Souls retire:
The Sprites of fiery Termagants in Flame
Mount up, and take a Salamander's name.
Soft yielding minds to Water glide away,
And sip, with Nymphs, their elemental Tea.
The graver Prude sinks downward to a Gnome,
In search of mischief still on Earth to roam.
The light Coquettes in Sylphs aloft repair,
And sport and flutter in the fields of Air.
生成:
Hwæt! Ic wolde singan hu micle pleoh,
Hu deop gewinn, hu stranglic feohð,
Betwixt a hlaford and a hlæfdige weox,
From lytlum þingum, swylce uncuð seox,
Oððe wordes flit, oððe locces scyte,
Þe ahte mægðhad, and engla bryce.
Caryl, min Muse, gecyð me þæs stríðes gecynd!
And þu, Belinda, gif þin eare find
Genam þis leoð, ne forseoð min geswing.

Nu on morgentid, þa sunne up astah,
And mid golde beamas ealne grund betah,
Belinda slæp, in slæpe fægeru,
Oðð þæt hire Sylph, mid fiðerum gleawu,
Hire wehte up, and cwæð mid stefne swete,
"Awacastu, Belinda! Seo sunne is gete,
And dæges leoht cymeð ofer eallum landum,
Ac ic hæbbe gehealden þin slæp mid hondum,
Forþam ic brohte þe swefna wundorlic."

Belinda cwæð, "Min Sylph, hwæt hæfst þu gesewen
In þam swefne? Was hit nihtlic egeslic deowen?
Oððe dracan grimme, oððe helle grund?"

"Ne nan þara þinga," hire Sylph ageafunde,
"Ac cniht fægerran þonne ænig on grund,
Mid eagum swylce steorran, and hwittran wund,
And loccas swylce gold, and wlite beorht,
He com to þe, and cwæð mid wordum leoht,
'Belinda, wes þu gegrēted! Ic eom gesended
From þam engla werode, þæt þe is gesended,
To wesanne þe and þin wlite to herianne,
And þin lif to giemanne, and ælc yfel to werianne.
Wite þu, Belinda, þæt manige gastas wuniað,
Þe we Sylphs hatað, and on lufte scinað;
We wæron iu wimmen, swylce þu eart nu,
Ac for urum wlite and urum dædum tru,
We wæron gecorene to þyssum heofonlicum dreamum,
To flitenne on lufte mid gymmum and mid gleamum.
Sum ure geferan giemað þa steorran,
Sume þa sunnan, and sume þa æftran gearran;
Ac ure mesta bliss is to beon neah,
And to gieman þa wimmen, þa us wæron swæ gear.
We sindon þine þegenas, and we willað þe wissian,
In ælcum þingum, and ælc yfel forðrissian.'"

Belinda cwæð, "Min Sylph, þis is wundorlic spell,
And þes cniht fægerra þonne ic mæg tellan well.
Ac hwæt is seo þearf þysses gastlicra þegna,
Gif we sindon deadlice, and ure lif is ægen?"

"Þeah þe ge sindon deadlice," hire Sylph cwæð,
"And eower lichaman to duste geweað,
Eower gastas libbað, and on lufte scinað,
And eowre wlite mid eow on ecnesse wunað.
And þeah þe ge forlætað þis eorðlice lif,
And ealle þa þing þa ge lufedon on þyssum rífe,
Eowre idelnesse mid eow farað,
And on oðrum formun eow sylfe gecyðað.
Þa þe wæron prude on heora wlite,
Beoð eft fægere blostman, mid deawum biþeaht;
Þa þe wæron gramhydige, and on heora heortan weorc,
Beoð eft wedera þurh wolcna gefleoc;
Ac þa þe wæron mihtigan, and woruldlice rice,
Beoð eft steorran beorhte, on þam heofonlicum wice.
Forþam, Belinda, ne forseoð þin wlite,
Ac bruc þin iugud, and wes æfre glede!
Forþam æfter þyssum life, on oðrum stede,
Þin wlite þegneð þe, on þam ecan gefean."

Þus spræc se Sylph, and mid þyssum wordum fleah,
And Belinda awoc, and lange stille læg,
And þohte ymbe þæt swefn, and þæs Sylphes læran.
summary:
The passage appears to be an excerpt from Alexander Pope's "The Rape of the Lock," a mock-epic poem that humorously treats a trivial domestic incident in an elevated, grandiose style. The excerpt begins by contemplating the seemingly large conflicts that arise from minor causes, embodied in the tale of a confrontation between a lord and a lady. The narrator mentions the Muse Caryl and suggests that even the subject of the story, a lady named Belinda, might endorse his poetic efforts.

The passage then shifts to a scene where Belinda is waking up. Her guardian Sylph, a kind of airy spirit, has prolonged her sleep and brought her a compelling dream involving a handsome youth. The dream youth speaks to Belinda, revealing certain mystical truths: that many unseen spirits (Sylphs) watch over her and that women, after death, continue to exhibit their earthly vanities in various spiritual forms. The Sylph explains that these spirits, once women themselves, oversee Belinda’s daily activities and subtly influence her life, suggesting a continuity between earthly and supernatural realms.

Overall, the passage uses elaborate romantic and supernatural imagery to open a whimsical narrative about courtship, vanity, and the roles of women, underpinned by the involvement of ethereal beings.

Her joy in gilded Chariots, when alive,
And love of Ombre, after death survive.
For when the Fair in all their pride expire,
To their first Elements their Souls retire:
The Sprites of fiery Termagants in Flame
Mount up, and take a Salamander's name.
Soft yielding minds to Water glide away,
And sip, with Nymphs, their elemental Tea.
The graver Prude sinks downward to a Gnome,
In search of mischief still on Earth to roam.
The light Coquettes in Sylphs aloft repair,
And sport and flutter in the fields of Air.

原文:
What dire offence from am'rous causes springs,
What mighty contests rise from trivial things,
I sing — This verse to Caryl, Muse! is due:
This, ev'n Belinda may vouchsafe to view:
Slight is the subject, but not so the praise,
If She inspire, and He approve my lays.

Say what strange motive, Goddess! could compel
A well-bred Lord t' assault a gentle Belle?
O say what stranger cause, yet unexplor'd,
Could make a gentle Belle reject a Lord?
In tasks so bold, can little men engage,
And in soft bosoms dwells such mighty Rage?

Sol thro' white curtains shot a tim'rous ray,
And oped those eyes that must eclipse the day:
Now lap-dogs give themselves the rousing shake,
And sleepless lovers, just at twelve, awake:
Thrice rung the bell, the slipper knock'd the ground,
And the press'd watch return'd a silver sound.
Belinda still her downy pillow prest,
Her guardian Sylph prolong'd the balmy rest:
'Twas He had summon'd to her silent bed
The morning-dream that hover'd o'er her head;
A Youth more glitt'ring than a Birth-night Beau,
(That ev'n in slumber caus'd her cheek to glow)
Seem'd to her ear his winning lips to lay,
And thus in whispers said, or seem'd to say.
Fairest of mortals, thou distinguish'd care
Of thousand bright Inhabitants of Air!
If e'er one vision touch.'d thy infant thought,
Of all the Nurse and all the Priest have taught;
Of airy Elves by moonlight shadows seen,
The silver token, and the circled green,
Or virgins visited by Angel-pow'rs,
With golden crowns and wreaths of heav'nly flow'rs;
Hear and believe! thy own importance know,
Nor bound thy narrow views to things below.
Some secret truths, from learned pride conceal'd,
To Maids alone and Children are reveal'd:
What tho' no credit doubting Wits may give?
The Fair and Innocent shall still believe.
Know, then, unnumber'd Spirits round thee fly,
The light Militia of the lower sky:
These, tho' unseen, are ever on the wing,
Hang o'er the Box, and hover round the Ring.
Think what an equipage thou hast in Air,
And view with scorn two Pages and a Chair.
As now your own, our beings were of old,
And once inclos'd in Woman's beauteous mould;
Thence, by a soft transition, we repair
From earthly Vehicles to these of air.
Think not, when Woman's transient breath is fled
That all her vanities at once are dead;
Succeeding vanities she still regards,
And tho' she plays no more, o'erlooks the cards.
Her joy in gilded Chariots, when alive,
And love of Ombre, after death survive.
For when the Fair in all their pride expire,
To their first Elements their Souls retire:
The Sprites of fiery Termagants in Flame
Mount up, and take a Salamander's name.
Soft yielding minds to Water glide away,
And sip, with Nymphs, their elemental Tea.
The graver Prude sinks downward to a Gnome,
In search of mischief still on Earth to roam.
The light Coquettes in Sylphs aloft repair,
And sport and flutter in the fields of Air.
