原文:
May I for my own self song’s truth reckon,
Journey’s jargon, how I in harsh days
Hardship endured oft.
Bitter breast-cares have I abided,
Known on my keel many a care’s hold,
And dire sea-surge, and there I oft spent
Narrow nightwatch nigh the ship’s head
While she tossed close to cliffs. Coldly afflicted,
My feet were by frost benumbed.
Chill its chains are; chafing sighs
Hew my heart round and hunger begot
Mere-weary mood. Lest man know not
That he on dry land loveliest liveth,
List how I, care-wretched, on ice-cold sea,
Weathered the winter, wretched outcast
Deprived of my kinsmen;
Hung with hard ice-flakes, where hail-scur flew,
There I heard naught save the harsh sea
And ice-cold wave, at whiles the swan cries,
Did for my games the gannet’s clamour,
Sea-fowls, loudness was for me laughter,
The mews' singing all my mead-drink.
Storms, on the stone-cliffs beaten, fell on the stern
In icy feathers; full oft the eagle screamed
With spray on his pinion.
Not any protector
May make merry man faring needy.
This he little believes, who aye in winsome life
Abides ’mid burghers some heavy business,
Wealthy and wine-flushed, how I weary oft
Must bide above brine.
Neareth nightshade, snoweth from north,
Frost froze the land, hail fell on earth then
Corn of the coldest. Nathless there knocketh now
The heart's thought that I on high streams
The salt-wavy tumult traverse alone.
Moaneth alway my mind’s lust
That I fare forth, that I afar hence
Seek out a foreign fastness.
For this there’s no mood-lofty man over earth’s midst,
Not though he be given his good, but will have in his youth greed;
Nor his deed to the daring, nor his king to the faithful
But shall have his sorrow for sea-fare
Whatever his lord will.
He hath not heart for harping, nor in ring-having
Nor winsomeness to wife, nor world's delight
Nor any whit else save the wave's slash,
Yet longing comes upon him to fare forth on the water.
Bosque taketh blossom, cometh beauty of berries,
Fields to fairness, land fares brisker,
All this admonisheth man eager of mood,
The heart turns to travel so that he then thinks
On flood-ways to be far departing.
Cuckoo calleth with gloomy crying,
He singeth summerward, bodeth sorrow,
The bitter heart's blood. Burgher knows not —
He the prosperous man — what some perform
Where wandering them widest draweth.
So that but now my heart burst from my breast-lock,
My mood ’mid the mere-flood,
Over the whale’s acre, would wander wide.
On earth’s shelter cometh oft to me,
Eager and ready, the crying lone-flyer,
Whets for the whale-path the heart irresistibly,
O'er tracks of ocean; seeing that anyhow
My lord deems to me this dead life
On loan and on land, I believe not
That any earth-weal eternal standeth
Save there be somewhat calamitous
That, ere a man’s tide go, turn it to twain.
Disease or oldness or sword-hate
Beats out the breath from doom-gripped body.
And for this, every earl whatever, for those speaking after —
Laud of the living, boasteth some last word,
That he will work ere he pass onward,
Frame on the fair earth ’gainst foes his malice,
Daring ado, ...
So that all men shall honour him after
And his laud beyond them remain ’mid the English,
Aye, for ever, a lasting life’s-blast,
Delight mid the doughty.
Days little durable,
And all arrogance of earthen riches,
There come now no kings nor Cæsars
Nor gold-giving lords like those gone.
Howe’er in mirth most magnified,
Whoe’er lived in life most lordliest,
Drear all this excellence, delights undurable!
Waneth the watch, but the world holdeth.
Tomb hideth trouble. The blade is layed low.
Earthly glory ageth and seareth.
No man at all going the earth’s gait,
But age fares against him, his face paleth,
Grey-haired he groaneth, knows gone companions,
Lordly men are to earth o’ergiven,
Nor may he then the flesh-cover, whose life ceaseth,
Nor eat the sweet nor feel the sorry,
Nor stir hand nor think in mid heart,
And though he strew the grave with gold,
His born brothers, their buried bodies
Be an unlikely treasure hoard.
生成:
Hwæt! Ic þis giedd gecype, searopancolnesse mines sefan onwreoh,  
Hu ic earfoðu þolade on yða gewealce,  
Bitrum brydgedon, frostcealdne fearh.  
Oft ic on nacan hreoh werigmod ceas,  
Wælfæðme sæcce, þær mec winterceald 
Geband mid grimman grapum, iscealde sæ.  

Atol yþa gewealc, anfealdnesse lif,  
Þurh deop wæter dreorigne sefan drefde.  
Ne wat ic on eorðan ænigne mann,  
Swa andwealdene, þæt he on þam brime  
Geþristlice feran meahte, frean egesan ne ondrede.  

Ac me se ælmihtiga eallunga gesceop  
Þæt ic his weallas wuldrian sceolde, 
Ofer holma gemang hygegeomrum ceorle. 
Oft ic sceolde ana, earm ond unrot, 
Mine ceare cwiðan cealdum sæflodum. 

Hwilum mec on lagulade lifgende cwom,  
Fela me gesæltes, swylce ic on foldan sceolde  
Mid minum hlaforde hean eard gewinnan.  
Ac se ælmihtiga eft oncyrde  
Minne hyge to holme, þær ic hreðe sceolde  
Eft earfoðu þolian, ana on nacan. 

Ne mæg se hlisa, þone hæleð gewinnað,  
Wæpnum gefeohtan, ne wunden gold 
Freondum gecyðan, gif he to grunde siðan 
On feorhgeniðlan feallan sceal.  
Ne mæg he þær his giefe geotan, ne his dreamas lange  
Gebrucan, þær him beorgas stondað  
Cealde geðreade, and him ceald wæter  
Ofer ymblide eal swa ic gebiden hæbbe. 

Hwæt! Oft ic geseah þa geongan men  
Gamenian on healle, gleomen dream cyþan, 
Wynnum welan brucan. Ic þæs wuldres ne gefræn, 
Ne þæs beorhtan goldes, þæt me on brime scolde 
Efn sceattas bringan, oððe on earðan blæd. 

A swa ic on gyrnnesse geond yða ful 
Hwearf þæt ic wundor geseon meahte, 
Oððe ealdgewinnes ende gecnawan.  
Ac me seo anhydig eallunga forstod,  
And me to ealdgewinge eft gesceop. 

Ne mæg ænig manna þæs morgenes blæd,  
Ne þæs middages mære, ne seo monige swetnes  
Þe æfre on eorðan ænig gefremede, 
Þone deorcne deað æfre forðinnan.  
Ealle hie to duste gewitað, and him dæg scaneð  
Ofer heora byrgennum, beorht sunne scineð,  
Ac him seo beorhtnes bot ne gecyþeð. 

Forþon ic georne gecyðan wille 
Þam þe þis lif licaþ, and on lustum wuniaþ,  
Þæt hie heora heortan geþenceað, hu seo þis læne world 
Wendaþ and wancaþ, swa swa þeos wilde sæ  
Hefig and heah hwilum stigeð, 
Hwilum under eorðan eft gesiþað. 

Forþon þas eorðan wynne eallunga sindon  
Fæle and gewitende, and se fela goldes,  
Þone hæleð hordað, him ne freomað, 
Þonne him se deað cymeð, ceald and grim.  
Betre is þæt he his sawle gefeormie 
Mid godum dædum, þonne he gold hwearfie. 

Forþon se ælmihtiga eall geman þonne 
Þe we on eorðan æfre gefremedon, 
Ge gode ge yfele, and us gelean wille 
Æfter urum dædum, on þam dome dæge.  
Þær us ealle for him standan sceolon, 
And æghwylc sceal for him andsware geotan 
Be his sawle gestreonum, swa he on worulde gecwemde, 
Oððe gode oððe yfele. Þæt georne geþenceð.
summary:
Certainly! This passage, often recognized as a translation of an Old English elegy, presents a vivid contemplation of the hardships and existential reflections of a seafarer. Here is a summary of its main content:

1. **Personal Hardship and Isolation**: The narrator recounts enduring severe hardships and isolation while at sea. They describe the physical and emotional toll of navigating through harsh weather, frost, and relentless sea conditions. This includes nights spent wakeful and cold, the only sounds being the cries of sea-birds and the crashing of waves.

2. **Contrast with Life on Land**: The narrator contrasts their own suffering with the relatively comfortable and joyous life of those on land. People living in towns, engaged in business, surrounded by wealth and warmth, cannot understand the seafarer's tribulations.

3. **Yearning for the Sea**: Despite the difficulties, the narrator feels an irresistible pull towards the sea. This longing is powerful and persistent, suggesting a deeper existential drive or a sense of fate compelling them towards the open water.

4. **Transient Nature of Life and Earthly Pleasures**: The narrator reflects on the fleeting nature of life and earthly pleasures. Whether it be youthful desires, familial bonds, or worldly delights, everything ultimately succumbs to the passage of time.

5. **Search for Eternal Meaning**: The passage ends with a meditation on the search for lasting fame and meaning. It suggests that human endeavors, although temporary, aim to achieve a form of eternal remembrance through deeds and legacies. This is juxtaposed with the inevitability of death and decay, emphasizing the transient yet impactful nature of human actions.

Overall, the passage provides a melancholic yet philosophical reflection on the human condition, emphasizing the dichotomy between temporary earthly experiences and the enduring quest for meaning.

原文:
It's as if someone should give a gift to my people—
they will kill him if he comes to the troop.
It is otherwise for us.
Wulf is on an island, I on another.
Fast is that island, surrounded by fen.
The men on the island are murderous and cruel;
they will kill him if he comes to the troop.
It is otherwise for us.
I felt far-wandering hopes for my Wulf,
as I sat weeping in the rainy weather,
when the bold warrior's arms embraced me—
it was sweet to me, yet I also despised it.
Wulf, my Wulf! My wanting you
has made me sick—your seldom coming,
my mourning heart, not lack of meat.
Do you hear, Eadwacer? A wolf bears away
our wretched cub to the woods.
One can easily split what was never united,
the song of the two of us.
生成:
Hwæt! Ic þis giedd wrecan wille,
of langunge minre, ond lufen gedæled.
Wulf is min wynn, ac he is ofer yðum,
ofer garsecge, þær guman wuniað,
wearhfare menn þe hine woldon cwellan,
gif he meahte þider cuman.

Oft ic his herige, hu he me on fæðme hylt,
hwonne unc gemōt biþ on sælum swete.
Ac se wop cymeð, þonne he eft fareð,
ofer brim blācne, ond ic her gebīde,
ān on minum angsum, Eadwacer, þīn.

Wǣron unc giedd ond gleo, gamen ond bliss,
nu is þæt lond swa strang betwēox unc,
sēo brine mid byrlaste. Eala, þæt ic sēo,
on þam ilcan ēðele, þær min Wulf wunað!
Ac hit is earfoðdāge, þæt unc æfre mōte
samod sīgan. Þæt ic gewīte, þæt usic ne gedælde
næfre on life, nu hit lēohtlice mæg!
summary: Certainly! The passage is a poetic expression of longing and despair. The speaker reflects on a divided love, with her beloved, Wulf, being separated from her by treacherous islands. The islands are depicted as dangerous, inhabited by murderous men who would kill Wulf if he were to come. Despite being apart, the speaker yearns deeply for Wulf, expressing both the joy and pain of their rare encounters. The speaker also addresses Eadwacer, hinting at a sense of betrayal or loss, as though their union or relationship has been disrupted irreparably. The lament concludes with a melancholy note on the ease with which something that was never truly united can be torn apart.

原文:
It's as if someone should give a gift to my people—
they will kill him if he comes to the troop.
It is otherwise for us.
Wulf is on an island, I on another.
Fast is that island, surrounded by fen.
The men on the island are murderous and cruel;
they will kill him if he comes to the troop.
It is otherwise for us.
I felt far-wandering hopes for my Wulf,
as I sat weeping in the rainy weather,

has made me sick—your seldom coming,
my mourning heart, not lack of meat.
Do you hear, Eadwacer? A wolf bears away
our wretched cub to the woods.
One can easily split what was never united,
the song of the two of us.

The islands are depicted as dangerous, inhabited by murderous men who would kill Wulf if he were to come. 原文:
THESEUS.
Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour
Draws on apace; four happy days bring in
Another moon; but oh, methinks, how slow
This old moon wanes! She lingers my desires,
Like to a step-dame or a dowager,
Long withering out a young man’s revenue.
HIPPOLYTA.
Four days will quickly steep themselves in night;
Four nights will quickly dream away the time;
And then the moon, like to a silver bow
New bent in heaven, shall behold the night
Of our solemnities.
THESEUS.
Go, Philostrate,
Stir up the Athenian youth to merriments;
Awake the pert and nimble spirit of mirth;
Turn melancholy forth to funerals;
The pale companion is not for our pomp.
[Exit Philostrate.]
Hippolyta, I woo’d thee with my sword,
And won thy love doing thee injuries;
But I will wed thee in another key,
With pomp, with triumph, and with revelling.
Enter Egeus, Hermia, Lysander and Demetrius.
EGEUS.
Happy be Theseus, our renownèd Duke!
THESEUS.
Thanks, good Egeus. What’s the news with thee?
EGEUS.
Full of vexation come I, with complaint
Against my child, my daughter Hermia.
Stand forth, Demetrius. My noble lord,
This man hath my consent to marry her.
Stand forth, Lysander. And, my gracious Duke,
This man hath bewitch’d the bosom of my child.
Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes,
And interchang’d love-tokens with my child.
Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung,
With feigning voice, verses of feigning love;
And stol’n the impression of her fantasy
With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gauds, conceits,
Knacks, trifles, nosegays, sweetmeats (messengers
Of strong prevailment in unharden’d youth)
With cunning hast thou filch’d my daughter’s heart,
Turn’d her obedience (which is due to me)
To stubborn harshness. And, my gracious Duke,
Be it so she will not here before your grace
Consent to marry with Demetrius,
I beg the ancient privilege of Athens:
As she is mine I may dispose of her;
Which shall be either to this gentleman
Or to her death, according to our law
Immediately provided in that case.
THESEUS.
What say you, Hermia? Be advis’d, fair maid.
To you your father should be as a god;
One that compos’d your beauties, yea, and one
To whom you are but as a form in wax
By him imprinted, and within his power
To leave the figure, or disfigure it.
Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.
HERMIA.
So is Lysander.
THESEUS.
In himself he is.
But in this kind, wanting your father’s voice,
The other must be held the worthier.
HERMIA.
I would my father look’d but with my eyes.
THESEUS.
Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.
HERMIA.
I do entreat your Grace to pardon me.
I know not by what power I am made bold,
Nor how it may concern my modesty
In such a presence here to plead my thoughts:
But I beseech your Grace that I may know
The worst that may befall me in this case,
If I refuse to wed Demetrius.
THESEUS.
Either to die the death, or to abjure
For ever the society of men.
Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires,
Know of your youth, examine well your blood,
Whether, if you yield not to your father’s choice,
You can endure the livery of a nun,
For aye to be in shady cloister mew’d,
To live a barren sister all your life,
Chanting faint hymns to the cold fruitless moon.
Thrice-blessèd they that master so their blood
To undergo such maiden pilgrimage,
But earthlier happy is the rose distill’d
Than that which, withering on the virgin thorn,
Grows, lives, and dies, in single blessedness.
生成:
Hwæt! In geardagum, on ðæm fægeran burgum Aþenan, under ðæm cyninge Þeoseuse, weard þær micel unfriþ betweox fæder and dehter. Þeoseus, se mæra cyning, hæfde gecweden his bryd-dæg mid þære cyninges-cwene Hippolyta, and eall seo burg wæs gefylled mid gleownesse and gefean. Ac þær wæs sumor-niht, under þæm sciman steorran, þæt eall seo gleowednes wæs gecyrred to unrotnisse.

Egeus, eald and welig þegn, com to Þeoseuse mid his dehter, Hermia. Heo wæs fæger and geþyldig, ac hire heorte wæs gefylled mid unrotnisse, forþæm hire fæder hæfde gecoren hiere wer, Demetrius. Ac Hermia ne lufode Demetrius; heo lufode oðerne geongan cniht, Lysander.

"Min hlaford cyning," cwæð Egeus, "ic hæbbe come to þe for þinum dome. Min dohtor, Hermia, ne wile minre hæse hyran. Ic hæbbe gecoren hiere wer, se welega and æþele Demetrius, ac heo forseoð hine and lufað oðerne, se is unweorð hire."

Þeoseus beheold Hermia mid mild-heortnesse. "Cweð me, Hermia," cwæð he, "hwi ne wilt þu þinum fæder gehyrsumian? Demetrius is welig and æþele; he wære ælcere fæmnan wyrðe."

"Min hlaford cyning," cwæð Hermia, and hire stefn wæs swæte and liþe swa sanges stefn, "ic ne mæg minre heortan gewyrnan. Ic ne lufige Demetrius; ic lufige Lysander. Ne forseoð ic Demetrius for his æþelborennysse oððe for his welan; ac min heorte ne cann hine lufian."

Þa wæs Þeoseus geswenced, forþæm he nolde nanum men unriht dón. "Hermia," cwæð he æt siðestan, "þu scealt geþencan þæt þu ne canst þinum fæder forseoðan. He hæfð þone anweald ofer þe, and he hæfð þa rihtwisnesse on his healfe. Gif þu ne wilt Demetrius gewifian, þonne scealt þu deaþe sweltan, oððe þu scealt gán into nunnan mynstre and þær libban on æwfæstum clænnysse."

Hermia wæs afyrhted þæs cyninges wordum. Heo beheold Lysander mid geomrunge on hire eagum. "Hwæt sceal ic dón, Lysander?" cwæð heo. "Min fæder is heard-heort, and se cyning wile him gehyrsumian. Ic ne mæg deaþe sweltan, and ic ne mæg þe forlætan."

Lysander cniht genam hire hand on his. "Ne beo þu afyrhted, min leofe Hermia," cwæð he. "We findað sumne weg fram þissum earfoðnyssum. Þær is sum wudu near þyssere byrig, and þær wuniað fægere elfan. Ic hæbbe gehyred secgan þæt þa elfan hæbben micel cræft, and þæt hi mægen manna heortan gecyrran. We secaoð þa elfan, and we biddað hiere fultume."

Þa wæs Hermia geblissod, forþæm heo hæfde micelne truwan on Lysanderes wordum. "Þæt is wel gecweden, min leofa Lysander," cwæð heo. "We secaoð þa elfan, and we biddað hiere fultum."

And swa, on þære sumor-niht, under þæm sciman steorran, flugon Hermia and Lysander fram þære byrig into þæm dimman wudue, and mid him flugon hiere heortan, gebundene togædere mid þæm strengum lufe. Þær, on þæm wudue, under þæm ealdan treowum, hi gemetton þa fægran elfan, and þær begann se spell þære Sumor-Nihtes Dreame.
summary:
Certainly! This passage is from Act 1, Scene 1 of William Shakespeare's play "A Midsummer Night's Dream." Here's a summary of the main content:

Theseus, the Duke of Athens, is speaking to his fiancée Hippolyta about their upcoming wedding, expressing impatience for the event. Hippolyta reassures him that the days will pass quickly. Theseus then instructs Philostrate to prepare the youth of Athens for celebrations and festivities in anticipation of the wedding.

Egeus enters with his daughter Hermia and two suitors, Lysander and Demetrius. Egeus is upset because Hermia refuses to marry Demetrius, whom he favors, and instead, loves Lysander. 原文:
Scene I. On a ship at sea: a tempestuous noise of thunder and lightning heard.
Enter a Ship-Master and a Boatswain.
Mast. Boatswain!
Boats. Here, master: what cheer?
Mast. Good, speak to the mariners: fall to’t, yarely, or we run ourselves aground: bestir, bestir.Exit.
Enter Mariners.
5Boats. Heigh, my hearts! cheerly, cheerly, my hearts! yare, yare! Take in the topsail. Tend to the master’s whistle. Blow, till thou burst thy wind, if room enough!
Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Antonio, Ferdinand, Gonzalo, and others.
Alon. Good boatswain, have care. Where’s the master? Play the men.
10Boats. I pray now, keep below.
Ant. Where is the master, boatswain?
4
Boats. Do you not hear him? You mar our labour: keep your cabins: you do assist the storm.
Gon. Nay, good, be patient.
15Boats. When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers for the name of king? To cabin: silence! trouble us not.
Gon. Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.
Boats. None that I more love than myself. You are a 20Counsellor; if you can command these elements to silence, and work the peace of the present, we will not hand a rope more; use your authority: if you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long, and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap. Cheerly, good I. 1. 25hearts! Out of our way, I say.Exit.
Gon. I have great comfort from this fellow: methinks he hath no drowning mark upon him; his complexion is perfect gallows. Stand fast, good Fate, to his hanging: make the rope of his destiny our cable, for our own doth 30little advantage. If he be not born to be hanged, our case is miserable.Exeunt.
Re-enter Boatswain.
Boats. Down with the topmast! yare! lower, lower! Bring her to try with main-course. [A cry within.] A plague upon this howling! they are louder than the weather 35or our office.
Re-enter Sebastian, Antonio, and Gonzalo.
Yet again! what do you here? Shall we give o’er, and drown? Have you a mind to sink?
Seb. A pox o’ your throat, you bawling, blasphemous, incharitable dog!
40Boats. Work you, then.
Ant. Hang, cur! hang, you whoreson, insolent noise-maker. We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.
5
Gon. I’ll warrant him for drowning; though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell, and as leaky as an unstanched 45wench.
Boats. Lay her a-hold, a-hold! set her two courses off to sea again; lay her off.
Enter Mariners wet.
Mariners. All lost! to prayers, to prayers! all lost!
Boats. What, must our mouths be cold?
I. 1. 50Gon. The king and prince at prayers! let’s assist them,
For our case is as theirs.
Seb.
I’m out of patience.
Ant. We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards:
This wide-chapp’d rascal,—would thou mightst lie drowning
The washing of ten tides!
Gon.
He’ll be hang’d yet,
55Though every drop of water swear against it,
And gape at widest to glut him.
A confused noise within: “Mercy on us!”—“We split, we split!”—“Farewell my wife and children!”—“Farewell, brother!”—“We split, we split, we split!”
60Ant. Let’s all sink with the king.
Seb. Let’s take leave of him.Exeunt Ant. and Seb.
Gon. Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground, long heath, brown furze, any thing. The wills above be done! but I would fain die a 65dry death.Exeunt.
生成:
Alas, a tempest most fierce doth rage upon the vast expanse of the ocean, its wrath unleashed upon a hapless ship, tossing it to and fro like a leaf in the wind. The sky, once a canvas of azure, now churns with an ominous darkness, rent by flashes of lightning that illuminate the scene with an eerie, fleeting brilliance. The thunder, a deafening roar that echoes across the heavens, seems to mock the puny efforts of the mariners struggling to maintain control of their vessel.

Amidst this chaos, the Ship-Master, his voice barely audible above the howling wind, barks orders to his Boatswain, a man hardened by years of battling the elements. "Hasten, Boatswain!" he cries, his face etched with concern, "Bid the men furl the topsail with all speed! We must lighten our burden lest we be dashed upon the jagged rocks that lie in wait beneath these treacherous waves!"

The Boatswain, his weathered face a mask of grim determination, turns to his crew, a motley band of men, their faces pale with fear yet resolute in their duty. "To your tasks, lads!" he bellows, his voice a reassuring presence amidst the storm's fury. "Let not your hearts be daunted by this tempest! We have weathered storms before, and we shall weather this one too! Now, heave ho! Show the sea who's master!"

But even as the mariners toil tirelessly, their efforts are hampered by the arrival of several noblemen, their fine attire and haughty demeanour ill-suited to the perilous situation at hand. Alonso, the King, his face etched with worry, leads the group, followed by his brother, Sebastian, and Antonio, the Duke of Milan. Behind them trails Ferdinand, the King's son, his youthful features betraying a mixture of fear and excitement at this unexpected turn of events. Gonzalo, an aging but loyal counsellor, completes the group, his lined face reflecting the gravity of their predicament.

The noblemen, unused to such hardship, stumble across the deck, their presence hindering rather than helping the crew's frantic efforts. The Boatswain, his patience wearing thin, turns to them, his voice laced with irritation. "My lords," he says, his tone respectful yet firm, "I mean no disrespect, but I urge you to seek the safety of the lower decks. Your presence here serves only to impede our work."

Gonzalo, ever the diplomat, steps forward, his voice calm amidst the surrounding chaos. "My good fellow," he says, "surely you understand that we have noblemen of high standing aboard this vessel. It is only natural that we should concern ourselves with their well-being."

The Boatswain, however, is unmoved. "Noble or not," he retorts, "the sea shows no favour to rank or title. Death comes for all men, highborn or low, when it chooses. Now, I pray you, go below and leave us to our work!"

His words, blunt though they may be, strike a chord with the noblemen, reminding them that in the face of nature's fury, all men are equal. Reluctantly, they retreat below deck, leaving the Boatswain and his crew to battle the elements alone.

But despite their best efforts, the situation continues to deteriorate. The storm intensifies, its fury unrelenting, and the ship groans under the strain. The mariners, their faces etched with despair, cry out that all is lost.

Gonzalo, peering out from below deck, observes the Boatswain's tireless efforts. "I find myself strangely comforted by that fellow," he remarks to his companions. "He seems unfazed by this tempest, as though he has stared death in the face many times before. If I am to meet my end this day, I would rather it be at the hands of a hangman than to drown like a rat in a cage."

His words, though spoken in jest, offer a glimmer of hope, a reminder that even in the darkest of times, the human spirit can find solace in unexpected places. Yet, as the storm rages on, it seems that even hope itself might not be enough to save them from the watery abyss that awaits.
summary:
Certainly! This passage is from the opening scene of Shakespeare's play "The Tempest." It takes place on a ship caught in a violent storm at sea. Here’s a summary of the main content:

1. **Setting and Commotion**: The ship is in the midst of a tempest with thunder and lightning. The Ship-Master orders the Boatswain to speak to the crew to prevent the ship from running aground.

2. **Crew's Efforts**: The Boatswain rallies the Mariners, urging them to work quickly to take in the topsail and follow the master’s commands.

3. **Noblemen’s Interference**: Several noblemen, including Alonso (the King), Sebastian, Antonio, Ferdinand, and Gonzalo, enter the deck. They interfere with the crew's work, but the Boatswain demands they go below deck and not disrupt their labor.

4. **Confrontations**: Gonzalo reminds the Boatswain of the high-ranking passengers aboard, but the Boatswain asserts that their rank is irrelevant in the face of the storm. He sarcastically invites Gonzalo to command the elements if he can.

5. **Desperation and Realizations**: Despite the efforts, the situation worsens. The Mariners cry out that all is lost and prepare for the worst. The noblemen express their frustration and fear. Gonzalo notes that he takes a peculiar comfort in the Boatswain, believing his fate to be hanging rather than drowning, implying hope that they might survive.

6. **Chaos and Resignation**: As the storm intensifies, the Mariners lose hope and urge everyone to pray. Antonio and Sebastian express anger towards the Boatswain, blaming him for their plight. Finally, with the ship’s dire situation evident, Gonzalo wishes for any kind of dry land over the perilous sea, resigning himself to fate.

This scene sets the stage for the subsequent events of the play, establishing the perilous situation that leads to the shipwreck central to the plot of "The Tempest."

原文:
Scene I. On a ship at sea: a tempestuous noise of thunder and lightning heard.
Enter a Ship-Master and a Boatswain.
Mast. Boatswain!
Boats. Here, master: what cheer?
Mast. Good, speak to the mariners: fall to’t, yarely, or we run ourselves aground: bestir, bestir.Exit.
Enter Mariners.
5Boats. Heigh, my hearts! cheerly, cheerly, my hearts! yare, yare! Take in the topsail. Tend to the master’s whistle. Blow, till thou burst thy wind, if room enough!
Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Antonio, Ferdinand, Gonzalo, and others.
Alon. Good boatswain, have care. Where’s the master? Play the men.
10Boats. I pray now, keep below.
Ant. Where is the master, boatswain?
4
Boats. Do you not hear him? You mar our labour: keep your cabins: you do assist the storm.
Gon. Nay, good, be patient.
15Boats. When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers for the name of king? To cabin: silence! trouble us not.
Gon. Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.
Boats. None that I more love than myself. You are a 20Counsellor; if you can command these elements to silence, and work the peace of the present, we will not hand a rope more; use your authority: if you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long, and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap. Cheerly, good I. 1. 25hearts! Out of our way, I say.Exit.
Gon. I have great comfort from this fellow: methinks he hath no drowning mark upon him; his complexion is perfect gallows. Stand fast, good Fate, to his hanging: make the rope of his destiny our cable, for our own doth 30little advantage. If he be not born to be hanged, our case is miserable.Exeunt.
Re-enter Boatswain.
Boats. Down with the topmast! yare! lower, lower! Bring her to try with main-course. [A cry within.] A plague upon this howling! they are louder than the weather 35or our office.
Re-enter Sebastian, Antonio, and Gonzalo.
Yet again! what do you here? Shall we give o’er, and drown? Have you a mind to sink?
Seb. A pox o’ your throat, you bawling, blasphemous, incharitable dog!
40Boats. Work you, then.
Ant. Hang, cur! hang, you whoreson, insolent noise-maker. We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.
5
Gon. I’ll warrant him for drowning; though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell, and as leaky as an unstanched 45wench.
Boats. Lay her a-hold, a-hold! set her two courses off to sea again; lay her off.
Enter Mariners wet.
Mariners. All lost! to prayers, to prayers! all lost!
Boats. What, must our mouths be cold?
I. 1. 50Gon. The king and prince at prayers! let’s assist them,
For our case is as theirs.
Seb.
I’m out of patience.
Ant. We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards:
This wide-chapp’d rascal,—would thou mightst lie drowning
The washing of ten tides!
Gon.
He’ll be hang’d yet,
55Though every drop of water swear against it,
And gape at widest to glut him.
A confused noise within: “Mercy on us!”—“We split, we split!”—“Farewell my wife and children!”—“Farewell, brother!”—“We split, we split, we split!”
60Ant. Let’s all sink with the king.
Seb. Let’s take leave of him.Exeunt Ant. and Seb.
Gon. Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground, long heath, brown furze, any thing. The wills above be done! but I would fain die a 65dry death.Exeunt.

原文:
Now begin;
For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.
URSULA.
The pleasant’st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream,
And greedily devour the treacherous bait:
So angle we for Beatrice; who even now
Is couched in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.
HERO.
Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.
[They advance to the bower.]
No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggards of the rock.
URSULA.
But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
HERO.
So says the Prince, and my new-trothed lord.
URSULA.
And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
HERO.
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them, if they lov’d Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.
URSULA.
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
HERO.
O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man;
But Nature never fram’d a woman’s heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprising what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly, that to her
All matter else seems weak. She cannot love,
Nor take no shape nor project of affection,
She is so self-endear’d.
URSULA.
Sure I think so;
And therefore certainly it were not good
She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.
HERO.
Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man,
How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featur’d,
But she would spell him backward: if fair-fac’d,
She would swear the gentleman should be her sister;
If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antick,
Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed;
If low, an agate very vilely cut;
If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds;
If silent, why, a block moved with none.
So turns she every man the wrong side out,
And never gives to truth and virtue that
Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.
URSULA.
Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.
HERO.
No; not to be so odd, and from all fashions,
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable.
But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,
She would mock me into air: O! she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
Therefore let Benedick, like cover’d fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:
It were a better death than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.
URSULA.
Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.
HERO.
No; rather I will go to Benedick,
And counsel him to fight against his passion.
And, truly, I’ll devise some honest slanders
To stain my cousin with. One doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.
生成:
Hwæt! Þis is se spræc betwux Hero and Ursula, þær Beatrice hlystendum earum standeð unȝeseowen:

***

**Ursula:** "Hwæt, Hero, is þeos Beatrice swa blind þæt heo ne cann ȝiet Benedickes lufe geseon?"

**Hero:** "Ne, Ursula, ic ne wene þæt heo hit wite. Heo is swa oferhydiȝ and deopþanc þæt heo ælcum were wiðstandeð."

**Ursula:** "Þonne sculan we hi befōn, swā swā se fiscere his hrinȝ mid æte befēhð!"

**Hero:** "Ac hū? Heo is swa glēaw and scearpȝetungen, þæt heo ūre searuwa þurhsceawiþ."

**Ursula:** "Ne forseoh þu, Hero. Ic hæbbe ȝepōht ānne cræft. We sprecað hlūde, swā swā heo ūre word gehīeran mæȝe, ac we ne spricaþ rihte tō hiere. We sprecað swā swā we nē wēnan þæt heo hit gehīere."

**Hero:** "Þæt is ȝōd ȝepōht, Ursula. Ac hwæt sculan we secȝan?"

**Ursula:** "We sprecaþ ymbe Benedickes lufe tō Beatrice. We secȝaþ þæt he be hire dreameð, and þæt he hiere fæȝer and ȝewittig seȝe."

**Hero:** "Ac þæt is lēas! Benedick ne lufað Beatrice."

**Ursula:** "Ne belimpð hit ūre hwæðer hit sōþ sīe oþþe lēas. Hit belimpð ūre þæt Beatrice hit ȝelīefe. Þonne heo þās word gehīere, þonne onȝinneþ heo tō þencenne ymbe Benedick. And þonne heo ymbe hine þenceð, þonne onȝinneþ heo hine tō lufienne."

**Hero:** "Þū eart swa searucræftig, Ursula! Ac ic ondreede me þæt Beatrice Benedick ne lufaþ."

**Ursula:** "Ne forseoh þu, Hero. Þær is nān wīf swa heardheort þæt heo ne cann lufe ȝefrīȝnan. And Benedick is ȝōd wer, and wlanc, and weleȝeboren. He is wyrþe ælces wīfes lufe."

**Hero:** "Þæt is sōþ, Ursula. Ac Beatrice is swa ungelīc oðrum wīfum. Heo is swa wīslīc and swa ungesæliȝ. Ic ondreede me þæt heo næfre ne lufaþ."

**Ursula:** "Ne beo þu swa unhydiȝ, Hero. Se wealdenda God hæfþ ȝeseted þæt ælc mann sceal his ȝefēran findan. And ic wēne þæt Benedick is ȝeseted tō Beatrices ȝefēran."

**Hero:** "God ȝebletsode ūre searuwa, Ursula. Ac hwæt sceal ic dōn?"

**Ursula:** "Þū scealt nān þinȝ dōn. Læt mē dōn þæt ic dōn wille. Ic sprece wið Benedick, and ic hine tīhte þæt he Beatrice his lufe ætīewe. And þonne heo his lufe ȝefrīȝne, þonne onȝinneþ heo hine tō lufienne."

**Hero:** "Þū eart swa ȝōd frēond, Ursula. Ic þance þē for þīnum ȝōdum rǣde."

***

And swa Ursula and Hero þone cræft ȝespon, and Beatrice, hlystendum earum, eall ȝehīerde.
summary:
Certainly! The passage is a dialogue between Hero and Ursula from Shakespeare's play "Much Ado About Nothing." Here is a summary of the main content:

1. **Eavesdropping Setup**: Beatrice is secretly listening to Hero and Ursula's conversation, as they are aware and intentionally speaking loud enough for her to hear.
  
2. **Fishing Metaphor**: Ursula uses a fishing metaphor to describe how they are luring Beatrice with their words, similar to baiting a fish.

3. **Beatrice's Disdain**:
    - Hero and Ursula discuss Beatrice's disdainful and proud nature.
    - Hero describes Beatrice as someone who is critical of every man's appearance and character.
    - They debate whether Benedick loves Beatrice and if it would be good for her to know.
  
4. **Benedick's Love for Beatrice**:
    - Hero confirms that Benedick loves Beatrice, as told by the Prince and her fiancé.
    - She explains that she had persuaded them not to tell Beatrice to avoid her mocking Benedick.
  
5. **Beatrice's Critical Nature**:
    - Hero elaborates on Beatrice's critical attitude towards men.
    - No matter how perfect a man appears, Beatrice always finds fault.

6. **Plan to Prevent Mockery**: 
    - Hero fears that if Beatrice knew of Benedick's affections, she would mock him endlessly.
    - They decide it’s better for Benedick to hide his feelings than face Beatrice's scorn.

7. **Decision on Action**:
    - Ursula suggests they should tell Beatrice about Benedick's love to see her reaction, but Hero prefers to advise Benedick to fight against his passion.
    - Hero even considers tarnishing Beatrice's reputation subtly to prevent her from mocking Benedick.

The overall aim of the conversation is to manipulate Beatrice into falling in love with Benedick by playing on her critical nature and making her believe that he loves her deeply despite her flaws.

6. **Plan to Prevent Mockery**: 
    - Hero fears that if Beatrice knew of Benedick's affections, she would mock him endlessly.
    - They decide it’s better for Benedick to hide his feelings than face Beatrice's scorn.

7. **Decision on Action**:
    - Ursula suggests they should tell Beatrice about Benedick's love to see her reaction, but Hero prefers to advise Benedick to fight against his passion.
    - Hero even considers tarnishing Beatrice's reputation subtly to prevent her from mocking Benedick.

The overall aim of the conversation is to manipulate Beatrice into falling in love with Benedick by playing on her critical nature and making her believe that he loves her deeply despite her flaws.

原文:
Now begin;
For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.
URSULA.
The pleasant’st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream,
And greedily devour the treacherous bait:
So angle we for Beatrice; who even now
Is couched in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.
HERO.
Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.
[They advance to the bower.]
No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggards of the rock.
URSULA.
But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?
HERO.
So says the Prince, and my new-trothed lord.
URSULA.
And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
HERO.
They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them, if they lov’d Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.
URSULA.
Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?
HERO.
O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man;
But Nature never fram’d a woman’s heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprising what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly, that to her
All matter else seems weak. She cannot love,
Nor take no shape nor project of affection,
She is so self-endear’d.
URSULA.
Sure I think so;
And therefore certainly it were not good
She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.
HERO.
Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man,
How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featur’d,
But she would spell him backward: if fair-fac’d,
She would swear the gentleman should be her sister;
If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antick,
Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed;
If low, an agate very vilely cut;
If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds;
If silent, why, a block moved with none.
So turns she every man the wrong side out,
And never gives to truth and virtue that
Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.
URSULA.
Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.
HERO.
No; not to be so odd, and from all fashions,
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable.
But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,
She would mock me into air: O! she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
Therefore let Benedick, like cover’d fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:
It were a better death than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.
URSULA.
Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.
HERO.
No; rather I will go to Benedick,
And counsel him to fight against his passion.
And, truly, I’ll devise some honest slanders
To stain my cousin with. One doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.

原文:
BAPTISTA.
Gentlemen, importune me no farther,
For how I firmly am resolv’d you know;
That is, not to bestow my youngest daughter
Before I have a husband for the elder.
If either of you both love Katherina,
Because I know you well and love you well,
Leave shall you have to court her at your pleasure.
GREMIO.
To cart her rather: she’s too rough for me.
There, there, Hortensio, will you any wife?
KATHERINA.
[To Baptista] I pray you, sir, is it your will
To make a stale of me amongst these mates?
HORTENSIO.
Mates, maid! How mean you that? No mates for you,
Unless you were of gentler, milder mould.
KATHERINA.
I’ faith, sir, you shall never need to fear;
I wis it is not half way to her heart;
But if it were, doubt not her care should be
To comb your noddle with a three-legg’d stool,
And paint your face, and use you like a fool.
HORTENSIO.
From all such devils, good Lord deliver us!
GREMIO.
And me, too, good Lord!
TRANIO.
Husht, master! Here’s some good pastime toward:
That wench is stark mad or wonderful froward.
LUCENTIO.
But in the other’s silence do I see
Maid’s mild behaviour and sobriety.
Peace, Tranio!
TRANIO.
Well said, master; mum! and gaze your fill.
BAPTISTA.
Gentlemen, that I may soon make good
What I have said,—Bianca, get you in:
And let it not displease thee, good Bianca,
For I will love thee ne’er the less, my girl.
KATHERINA.
A pretty peat! it is best put finger in the eye, and she knew why.
BIANCA.
Sister, content you in my discontent.
Sir, to your pleasure humbly I subscribe:
My books and instruments shall be my company,
On them to look, and practise by myself.
LUCENTIO.
Hark, Tranio! thou mayst hear Minerva speak.
HORTENSIO.
Signior Baptista, will you be so strange?
Sorry am I that our good will effects
Bianca’s grief.
GREMIO.
Why will you mew her up,
Signior Baptista, for this fiend of hell,
And make her bear the penance of her tongue?
BAPTISTA.
Gentlemen, content ye; I am resolv’d.
Go in, Bianca.

Hwæt! Þis is nā from þǣm plegan "The Taming of the Shrew" be William Shakespeare. Þæt is nā Old English, ac Modern English! Old English, ēac Anglisc gehāten, wæs gesprecen oþ þæt 12. hundredgēar.  

Ic cann understandan þæt þū wilt habban þā scene in Old English, ac hit is earfoðe for mē, a māgister of ealdum bōcum, tō wrytanne in stīle þæs 11. hundredgēares.  

Þēah hwæðere, ic cann tellan þē þæt þīn sumnung is gōd. Hit is clear and hit understandaþ þā characters and þā gemǣnelicu idee of þǣm passage. 

Gif þū wilt habban sumne help mid Old English texts, ic eom hēr! 

(Translation:  

What! This is not from the play "The Taming of the Shrew" by William Shakespeare. That is not Old English, but Modern English! Old English, also called Anglo-Saxon, was spoken until the 12th century. 

I can understand that you want the scene in Old English, but it is difficult for me, a master of old books, to write in the style of the 11th century. 

However, I can tell you that your summary is good. It is clear and it understands the characters and the common ideas of the passage.  

If you want some help with Old English texts, I am here!)
summary:
Certainly! This passage is from William Shakespeare's play "The Taming of the Shrew." Here’s a summary of the main content:

Baptista, the father of Katherina (the "shrew") and Bianca, tells the suitors of both daughters that he will not allow Bianca to be married until Katherina, the elder daughter, is wed. Gremio and Hortensio, who find Katherina too difficult to court, express their reluctance through sarcastic remarks and insults about her temperament.

Katherina lashes out, showing her frustration about being treated as a commodity to her father. She has a sharp exchange with Hortensio, making clear her disdain.

Tranio and Lucentio, who are observing the scene, comment on the contrasting behaviors of the two sisters. Lucentio is taken with Bianca's quiet and gentle demeanor.

Baptista sends Bianca away to avoid the conflict, reassuring her of his love despite the circumstances. Katherina reacts with bitterness, while Bianca submissively accepts her father's decision, indicating she will focus on her studies.

Hortensio and Gremio question Baptista’s decision to restrict Bianca’s suitors because of Katherina’s behavior, but Baptista insists resolutely on his decision, and Bianca exits the scene as instructed.

Overall, the passage highlights the familial and societal pressures around marriage, the dynamics between the sisters, and the behavior of their suitors.

原文:
FLAVIUS.
Hence! home, you idle creatures, get you home.
Is this a holiday? What, know you not,
Being mechanical, you ought not walk
Upon a labouring day without the sign
Of your profession? Speak, what trade art thou?
CARPENTER.
Why, sir, a carpenter.
MARULLUS.
Where is thy leather apron and thy rule?
What dost thou with thy best apparel on?
You, sir, what trade are you?
COBBLER.
Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but, as you would say, a cobbler.
MARULLUS.
But what trade art thou? Answer me directly.
COBBLER.
A trade, sir, that I hope I may use with a safe conscience, which is indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.
MARULLUS.
What trade, thou knave? Thou naughty knave, what trade?
COBBLER.
Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me; yet, if you be out, sir, I can mend you.
MARULLUS.
What mean’st thou by that? Mend me, thou saucy fellow!
COBBLER.
Why, sir, cobble you.
FLAVIUS.
Thou art a cobbler, art thou?
COBBLER.
Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl; I meddle with no tradesman’s matters, nor women’s matters, but withal I am indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes: when they are in great danger, I recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon neat’s leather have gone upon my handiwork.
FLAVIUS.
But wherefore art not in thy shop today?
Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?
COBBLER.
Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes, to get myself into more work. But indeed, sir, we make holiday to see Caesar, and to rejoice in his triumph.
MARULLUS.
Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home?
What tributaries follow him to Rome,
To grace in captive bonds his chariot wheels?
You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things!
O you hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome,
Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft
Have you climb’d up to walls and battlements,
To towers and windows, yea, to chimney tops,
Your infants in your arms, and there have sat
The livelong day with patient expectation,
To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome.
And when you saw his chariot but appear,
Have you not made an universal shout,
That Tiber trembled underneath her banks
To hear the replication of your sounds
Made in her concave shores?
And do you now put on your best attire?
And do you now cull out a holiday?
And do you now strew flowers in his way,
That comes in triumph over Pompey’s blood?
Be gone!
Run to your houses, fall upon your knees,
Pray to the gods to intermit the plague
That needs must light on this ingratitude.
FLAVIUS.
Go, go, good countrymen, and, for this fault
Assemble all the poor men of your sort,
Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears
Into the channel, till the lowest stream
Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.
生成:
Hwæt! On þǣm dæg, swā Cāsere his sigorbēacen hæfde āhafen, ēodon twēgen gerēfan, Flāvius and Marullus, geond þā strǣta Rōmebyrig. Þǣr gesāwon hīe micelne hlēoþor and dream geond þæt folc, þe for Cāsere's sige fægen wǣron and heora dæghwāmlic weorc forlǣten hæfdon.

Þā cwæð Flāvius mid yrre, "Hwi standaþ gē hēr, īdele menn, mid swelcum hlēoþre? Nāt gē þæt hit is se dæghwāmlica dæd? Gāþ tō ēowrum weorcum and lǣtaþ ēowre cræfta ēow fēdan, nā Cāsere's sige!"

Marullus ēac þæt folc mid grimman andwlitan ongann, "Ealā, gē ungesibblican menn! Hafath gē forgieten þone tīman þā gē Pōmpeius mid blōstmum and sangum onfengon, þā hē mid sige hām fōr? And nū, for Cāsere, þe ofer Pōmpeius' blōde stæppeþ, scēawiath gē ēowre weorc forlǣten and mid hlēoþre þā strǣta gefyllan? Is þis ēower trymnes? Is þis ēower ārstæfednes?"

He clypode on sumne sceowyrhta, þe mid his betstum hrægle gefrætewod wæs, "And þū, sceowyrhta, hwi ne sitst þū æt þīnum weorce? Hwi ne bīdst þū þīnre nædle and þīnum þræde getrywe?"

Se sceowyrhta him andswarode mid glīwgeornes, "Ealā, hlāford, ic bīde getrywe þǣm læste, ac hit ne mæg nā leng min cræft weorðian. Forþǣm þe Cāsere hāteþ þæt ealle menn scēolon hēora cræfta forlǣtan and hine mid hlēoþre onfōn."

Marullus him ācweðan wolde, ac Flāvius hine gelette, "Lǣt hine gān," cwæð hē. "Þis folc ne cann bet. Hīe sindon swā fēðerum on winde, þe æfre mid þǣm strēame snīðath. Gā wē heonon and biddaþ þæt ūre godas þisum folce heora synna forgifen."

And swā ēodon þā gerēfan heonon, heora heortan mid sāre and gnornunge gefyllte. Þæt folc, þēah, heora worda ne gymdon, ac hēoldon on mid heora hlēoþre and dreame, heora heortan mid ungesibbum and ungesceadwīsnysse āfyllede.

This passage, though not an exact translation, attempts to capture the essence of the original scene in Old English, reflecting the language's alliterative style and employing words and phrases common to the period. It highlights the themes of loyalty, fickleness, and the fickle nature of the common people, as well as the tension between the ruling class and the working class.  The passage evokes the atmosphere of ancient Rome and the social dynamics at play during Caesar's rise to power.

Flavius and Marullus, two Roman officials, encounter a group of commoners in the streets who are celebrating and taking a day off in honor of Caesar's triumph. Flavius scolds the crowd, calling them idle and questioning their lack of respect for the laboring day. Marullus interrogates the tradesmen about their professions and criticizes a cobbler for being out in his best clothes instead of working. The cobbler humorously defends his presence by making puns about his trade.

Marullus then launches into a passionate speech, chastising the people for their ingratitude and fickleness. He reminds them of their past adoration of Pompey, a former Roman leader defeated by Caesar. Marullus condemns their celebration of Caesar, who has triumphed over Pompey's blood, and urges them to feel shame for their disloyalty. Flavius orders them to disperse, return to their homes, and pray for forgiveness to avoid the consequences of their ingratitude.

The passage highlights themes of loyalty, ingratitude, and the shifting allegiances of the Roman populace.

Certainly! This passage is an excerpt from William Shakespeare's play "Julius Caesar." Here’s a summary of the main content:

Flavius and Marullus, two Roman officials, encounter a group of commoners in the streets who are celebrating and taking a day off in honor of Caesar's triumph. Flavius scolds the crowd, calling them idle and questioning their lack of respect for the laboring day. Marullus interrogates the tradesmen about their professions and criticizes a cobbler for being out in his best clothes instead of working. The cobbler humorously defends his presence by making puns about his trade.

Marullus then launches into a passionate speech, chastising the people for their ingratitude and fickleness. He reminds them of their past adoration of Pompey, a former Roman leader defeated by Caesar. Marullus condemns their celebration of Caesar, who has triumphed over Pompey's blood, and urges them to feel shame for their disloyalty. Flavius orders them to disperse, return to their homes, and pray for forgiveness to avoid the consequences of their ingratitude.

The passage highlights themes of loyalty, ingratitude, and the shifting allegiances of the Roman populace.

原文:
FLAVIUS.
Hence! home, you idle creatures, get you home.
Is this a holiday? What, know you not,
Being mechanical, you ought not walk
Upon a labouring day without the sign
Of your profession? Speak, what trade art thou?
CARPENTER.
Why, sir, a carpenter.
MARULLUS.
Where is thy leather apron and thy rule?
What dost thou with thy best apparel on?
You, sir, what trade are you?
COBBLER.
Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but, as you would say, a cobbler.
MARULLUS.
But what trade art thou? Answer me directly.
COBBLER.
A trade, sir, that I hope I may use with a safe conscience, which is indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.
MARULLUS.
What trade, thou knave? Thou naughty knave, what trade?
COBBLER.
Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me; yet, if you be out, sir, I can mend you.
MARULLUS.
What mean’st thou by that? Mend me, thou saucy fellow!
COBBLER.
Why, sir, cobble you.
FLAVIUS.
Thou art a cobbler, art thou?
COBBLER.
Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl; I meddle with no tradesman’s matters, nor women’s matters, but withal I am indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes: when they are in great danger, I recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon neat’s leather have gone upon my handiwork.
FLAVIUS.
But wherefore art not in thy shop today?
Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?
COBBLER.
Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes, to get myself into more work. But indeed, sir, we make holiday to see Caesar, and to rejoice in his triumph.
MARULLUS.
Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home?
What tributaries follow him to Rome,
To grace in captive bonds his chariot wheels?
You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things!
O you hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome,
Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft
Have you climb’d up to walls and battlements,
To towers and windows, yea, to chimney tops,
Your infants in your arms, and there have sat
The livelong day with patient expectation,
To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome.
And when you saw his chariot but appear,
Have you not made an universal shout,
That Tiber trembled underneath her banks
To hear the replication of your sounds
Made in her concave shores?
And do you now put on your best attire?
And do you now cull out a holiday?
And do you now strew flowers in his way,
That comes in triumph over Pompey’s blood?
Be gone!
Run to your houses, fall upon your knees,
Pray to the gods to intermit the plague
That needs must light on this ingratitude.
FLAVIUS.
Go, go, good countrymen, and, for this fault
Assemble all the poor men of your sort,
Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears
Into the channel, till the lowest stream
Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.

原文:
BRABANTIO.
What is the reason of this terrible summons?
What is the matter there?
RODERIGO.
Signior, is all your family within?
IAGO.
Are your doors locked?
BRABANTIO.
Why, wherefore ask you this?
IAGO.
Zounds, sir, you’re robb’d, for shame put on your gown,
Your heart is burst, you have lost half your soul;
Even now, now, very now, an old black ram
Is tupping your white ewe. Arise, arise,
Awake the snorting citizens with the bell,
Or else the devil will make a grandsire of you:
Arise, I say.
BRABANTIO.
What, have you lost your wits?
RODERIGO.
Most reverend signior, do you know my voice?
BRABANTIO.
Not I. What are you?
RODERIGO.
My name is Roderigo.
BRABANTIO.
The worser welcome.
I have charg’d thee not to haunt about my doors;
In honest plainness thou hast heard me say
My daughter is not for thee; and now in madness,
Being full of supper and distempering draughts,
Upon malicious bravery, dost thou come
To start my quiet.
RODERIGO.
Sir, sir, sir,—
BRABANTIO.
But thou must needs be sure
My spirit and my place have in them power
To make this bitter to thee.
RODERIGO.
Patience, good sir.
BRABANTIO.
What tell’st thou me of robbing?
This is Venice. My house is not a grange.
RODERIGO.
Most grave Brabantio,
In simple and pure soul I come to you.
IAGO.
Zounds, sir, you are one of those that will not serve God if the devil bid you. Because we come to do you service, and you think we are ruffians, you’ll have your daughter cover’d with a Barbary horse; you’ll have your nephews neigh to you; you’ll have coursers for cousins and gennets for germans.
BRABANTIO.
What profane wretch art thou?
IAGO.
I am one, sir, that comes to tell you your daughter and the Moor are now making the beast with two backs.
BRABANTIO.
Thou art a villain.
IAGO.
You are a senator.
BRABANTIO.
This thou shalt answer. I know thee, Roderigo.
RODERIGO.
Sir, I will answer anything. But I beseech you,
If ’t be your pleasure, and most wise consent,
(As partly I find it is) that your fair daughter,
At this odd-even and dull watch o’ the night,
Transported with no worse nor better guard,
But with a knave of common hire, a gondolier,
To the gross clasps of a lascivious Moor:
If this be known to you, and your allowance,
We then have done you bold and saucy wrongs.
But if you know not this, my manners tell me,
We have your wrong rebuke. Do not believe
That from the sense of all civility,
I thus would play and trifle with your reverence.
Your daughter (if you have not given her leave)
I say again, hath made a gross revolt,
Tying her duty, beauty, wit, and fortunes
In an extravagant and wheeling stranger
Of here and everywhere. Straight satisfy yourself:
If she be in her chamber or your house,
Let loose on me the justice of the state
For thus deluding you.
BRABANTIO.
Strike on the tinder, ho!
Give me a taper! Call up all my people!
This accident is not unlike my dream,
Belief of it oppresses me already.
Light, I say, light!
生成:
Hwæt! Ic, Ælfric, gleawmann and bocera, þæt gehyrde þæt on Venetían byrig, þær stódan stænen húses mid hrófum heahum, þær wæs sum wer se wæs Brǽbantío gehâten. Se Brǽbantío wæs ealdormann, æþele and rice, and him wæs dóhtor, Desdemóna gehâten, fæger on hiwe and freóndlic on mode.

Sōþlice, þær wæs on þære ylcan byrig cene cempa, Othello gehâten, þe wæs þegn on þæs heres þegnunge, strang on gefeohte and snotor on geþeahte. Se Othello wæs blæc on hiwe, forþæm þe he wæs of Móres cynne.

Nú hæfde se Othello and seo Desdemóna heora lufu behyddon fram Brǽbantíon, forþæm þe hie wiston þæt him ne licode þæt his dóhtor sceolde ænigum ceorle gifte gesecan, þe ne wæs of his agnum cynne and hæleþe.

Ac hit gelamp þæt Iago, se wæs flítende cniht and fæcne on his worde, gehyrde þæt se Othello and seo Desdemóna hæfdon heora lufu behyddon. Þa eode se Iago to Roderígon, þe wæs oþer cniht, se lufode þa Desdemónan mid eallum his heortan.

Þa cwæð se Iago to þam Roderígon, "Ealā, þu Roderíg, hwi eart þu swa unrót? Ic wát þæt þu lufast þa Desdemónan, ac ic wat eac þæt se Othello hæfþ hire æt þinum handum gelæht."

Þa wearð se Roderígo swiðe unrót, and cwæð, "Hwat sceal ic dōn? Se Othello is strangra þonne ic, and he hæfþ þæs heres fultum. Ne dear ic him on gewinn cuman."

Þa cwæð se Iago, "Ne þearft þu him on gewinn cuman. Ic wat hu þu hi magst forlætan. We sculon gan to Brǽbantíon, and him secgan þæt se Othello hæfþ his dóhtor æt his handum gelæht."

Þa eodon hie to Brǽbantíon húse, and wurdon in gelædde to his bæddreste, forþæm þe hit wæs niht. Þa cwæð se Iago to Brǽbantíon, "A'wæcnu, a'wæcnu, ealdormann! Þin dóhtor is mid þam blæcan þeowene gewiten!"

Þa wearð se Brǽbantío swiðe astyred, and aras of his reste, and cwæð, "Hwat segst þu, þu lyttigenda þeof? Hwanon com þu, and hwæt woldest þu her?"

Þa cwæð se Iago, "Ne beo þu onstyred, ealdormann. Ic secge þæt ic gese, and ic wát þæt ic secge. Se Othello hæfþ þine dóhtor gelæht, and hie sindon nú ætgædere on his huse."

Þa wearð se Brǽbantío swiðe unrót, and eode út on þa stræt, and begann to cleopianne, "Wapna, wapna! Man gelæcþ þone þeowan, and bringþ hine to me! He hæfþ mine dóhtor gelæht, and hie is forloren!"

Þa comon þa burgware ūt of heora húsum, and wurdon astyrede mid þam gebeate. Þa wearð þær mycel gefeoht, and man sloh fela manna on ægþre healfe.

Ac on þam ende wearð se Othello gefangen, and man lædde hine to Brǽbantíon. Þa cwæð se Brǽbantío to him, "Þu earma þeowan, hu dorstest þu mine dóhtor gelæccan? Ic wát þæt þu hi hæfst bepæced mid þinum wiccecræftum, forþæm þe nan wif ne mihte þe lufian on oþre wisan."

Þa cwæð se Othello, "Næfre ic þa Desdemónan ne bepæhte. Heo lufode me for minum geearnungum, and forþæm þe ic hi lufode."

Ac se Brǽbantío nolde him gehyran, ac het hine lædan to cwearterne. And swa wearð seo lufu þæs Othellon and þære Desdemónan gehworfen to sárnesse.
summary:
Certainly! This passage is from Act 1, Scene 1 of William Shakespeare's play "Othello." 

In this scene, Iago and Roderigo awaken Brabantio, a Venetian senator, in the middle of the night to inform him that his daughter Desdemona has secretly eloped with Othello, a Moorish general in the Venetian army. Iago uses racist and provocative language to describe the union, aiming to incite Brabantio's anger. Roderigo, who is in love with Desdemona, supports Iago's claims and tries to convince Brabantio that they are acting out of concern for his honor. Initially skeptical, Brabantio becomes increasingly distressed and orders his household to investigate the situation, fearing that his nightmare has become reality.

原文:
When Jesus understood it, he said unto them, Why trouble ye
the woman? for she hath wrought a good work upon me.
For ye have the poor always with you; but me ye have not
always.
For in that she hath poured this ointment on my body, she did
it for my burial.
Verily I say unto you, Wheresoever this gospel shall be preached in the whole world, there shall also this, that this woman hath done, be told for a memorial of her.

Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, went unto the chief priests,

And said unto them, What will ye give me, and I will deliver him unto you? And they covenanted with him for thirty pieces of silver.

And from that time he sought opportunity to betray him.

Now the first day of the feast of unleavened bread the
disciples came to Jesus, saying unto him, Where wilt thou that
we prepare for thee to eat the passover?
And he said, Go into the city to such a man, and say unto him,
The Master saith, My time is at hand; I will keep the passover
at thy house with my disciples.
And the disciples did as Jesus had appointed them; and they made ready the passover.

40:026:020 Now when the even was come, he sat down with the twelve.

And as they did eat, he said, Verily I say unto you, that one
of you shall betray me.
And they were exceeding sorrowful, and began every one of them
to say unto him, Lord, is it I?
And he answered and said, He that dippeth his hand with me in
the dish, the same shall betray me.
The Son of man goeth as it is written of him: but woe unto that man by whom the Son of man is betrayed! it had been good for that man if he had not been born.

Then Judas, which betrayed him, answered and said, Master, is it I? He said unto him, Thou hast said.

And as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and blessed it, and brake it, and gave it to the disciples, and said, Take, eat; this is my body.

And he took the cup, and gave thanks, and gave it to them,
saying, Drink ye all of it;
For this is my blood of the new testament, which is shed for
many for the remission of sins.
But I say unto you, I will not drink henceforth of this fruit of the vine, until that day when I drink it new with you in my Father's kingdom.

And when they had sung an hymn, they went out into the mount of Olives.

Then saith Jesus unto them, All ye shall be offended because of me this night: for it is written, I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock shall be scattered abroad.

But after I am risen again, I will go before you into Galilee.

Peter answered and said unto him, Though all men shall be
offended because of thee, yet will I never be offended.
Jesus said unto him, Verily I say unto thee, That this night,
before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice.
Peter said unto him, Though I should die with thee, yet will I
not deny thee. Likewise also said all the disciples.
Then cometh Jesus with them unto a place called Gethsemane, and saith unto the disciples, Sit ye here, while I go and pray yonder.

And he took with him Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, and
began to be sorrowful and very heavy.
Then saith he unto them, My soul is exceeding sorrowful, even
unto death: tarry ye here, and watch with me.
And he went a little farther, and fell on his face, and prayed, saying, O my Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me: nevertheless not as I will, but as thou wilt.

And he cometh unto the disciples, and findeth them asleep, and
saith unto Peter, What, could ye not watch with me one hour?
Watch and pray, that ye enter not into temptation: the spirit
indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.
He went away again the second time, and prayed, saying, O my Father, if this cup may not pass away from me, except I drink it, thy will be done.

And he came and found them asleep again: for their eyes were
heavy.
And he left them, and went away again, and prayed the third
time, saying the same words.
Then cometh he to his disciples, and saith unto them, Sleep on now, and take your rest: behold, the hour is at hand, and the Son of man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.

Rise, let us be going: behold, he is at hand that doth betray me.

And while he yet spake, lo, Judas, one of the twelve, came, and with him a great multitude with swords and staves, from the chief priests and elders of the people.

Now he that betrayed him gave them a sign, saying, Whomsoever
I shall kiss, that same is he: hold him fast.
And forthwith he came to Jesus, and said, Hail, master; and
kissed him.
And Jesus said unto him, Friend, wherefore art thou come? Then
came they, and laid hands on Jesus and took him.
And, behold, one of them which were with Jesus stretched out
his hand, and drew his sword, and struck a servant of the high
priest's, and smote off his ear.
Then said Jesus unto him, Put up again thy sword into his
place: for all they that take the sword shall perish with the
sword.
Thinkest thou that I cannot now pray to my Father, and he
shall presently give me more than twelve legions of angels?
But how then shall the scriptures be fulfilled, that thus it must be?
In that same hour said Jesus to the multitudes, Are ye come out as against a thief with swords and staves for to take me? I sat daily with you teaching in the temple, and ye laid no hold on me.

But all this was done, that the scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled. Then all the disciples forsook him, and fled.

## Þā Hālgan Gemyndu:  Sēo Ofdung, Sēo Unsǣlð, and Sēo Forgifennes

Hēr byð gesæd be þām weorðfullum and þām wītum tīdum, be þām dagon þe foresceawodon þā ðrowunge ūres Hælendes, þæs Hīhstan Cyninges, Hælendes Cristes.  Þās tīdlican gyltas and þās hālēgan hæmedas wǣron gescrifene on þām Godspelle, þæt wē magon gemunan and understandan þā micclan lufu þæs Ælmihtigan, and þā dēopnesse his āgenes onsǣgednesse for ūrum synnum.

**Se Halga Ofdung**

Hit wæs on Bethania, þǣr se Hælend wæs mid his leorningcnihtum.  And þǣr com an wīf mid alabastron boxe mid deorwyrde nardunge, and heo geat þā sealfe ofer þæs Hælendes heafod, and se stenc þæs wyrtgemannes gefylde þæt hūs.  Sum þāra þe þǣr wǣron wurdon gebolgen, and cwǣdon betwux him, "Hwi is þēos sealfung þus forspilled?  Þēos sealf mihte beon geseald for miclum feo, and þæt feoh mihte beon geseald þearfum." 

Ac se Hælend cwæð, "Lǣtað hīe; hwi dō gē hīe gedrēfed? Hēo hæfð gōd weorc gedōn on mē.  Sōþ ic secge ēow, þæt hwǣr sēo godspell gebodod byð on eallum middangearde, þonne byð þæt þēos wīf dyde gebodod ēac, on hīre gemynd."  Forþǣm se Hælend wiste þæt his tīd wæs gehende, and þæt hē sceolde beon geseald on þā handa synfulra manna.

**Þæs Iūdas Ārlēasnes**

And Iūdas Iscariot, ān þāra twelf leorningcnihta, ēode tō þām ealdor-sacerdum and cwæð, "Hwæt wylle gē mē sellan, and ic hine ēow belǣde?"  Hīe behēton him þrītig seolfor-peninga.  And of þām timan sōhte hē gēarne hwænne hē mihte hine belǣdan.

**Seo Forman Hūsel-hālgoþ**

On þām forman dæge þæs Æsterlican hlāfmǣsses ēode Iūdas ūt fram þām Hælendes and his leorningcnihtum, and se Hælend cwæð, "Nu is Mannes Sunu geglenged, and God is geglenged þurh hine.  Gif God is geglenged þurh hine, God glengð ēac hine on him sylfum, and hē glengð hine hræde."

And þā hē þæt gesæd hæfde, hē nam hlāf, and þanciende hē hine bræc, and sealde his leorningcnihtum, and cwæð, "Nimað, etað; þis is min līchama."  And hē nam þone calic, and þanciende hē hine sealde him, and cwæð, "Drincað of þisum eallum; þis is min blōd þære niwan cyðnesse, þæt byð for manegum gegoted on synna forgyfenesse."

**Sēo Forsecgennes**

Þā cwæð se Hælend him, "Ealle gē bēoð gedrēfede on þisse nihte on mē; hit is āwriten, 'Ic slēa þone hyrde, and þā scēap þæs heordes beoð toscādene.'"  Þā cwæð Petrus him, "Þēah þe ealle gedrēfede bēoð on þē, ic næfre ne beo gedrēfed."

Se Hælend him andswarode and cwæð, "Sōþ ic secge þē, þæt þū on þisse nihte, ǣr se cocc crāwe, þrīwa widsacast þæt þū mē cuðest." Petrus cwæð wið hine, "Þēah þe ic sceolde mid þē dēaþ þolian, ne widsace ic þē."  And eall þæt his leorningcnihtas cwǣdon.

**Gebede on Getsemane**

Þā ēode se Hælend mid him ofer þone burn Cedron, þǣr wæs an wyrtūn, and hē ēode intō þām wyrtūne, and his leorningcnihtas mid him.  Þā cwæð hē to his leorningcnihtum, "Sittað hēr, þā hwīle þe ic gā and ic me þær gebidde."  And hē nam mid him Petrum and Iacobum and Iohannem, and hē ongann grēatly gedrēfed and unrōt.  

And hē cwæð him, "Min sāwl is swīðe geunrōtod oð dēaþ; gebīdað hēr and wacoleað mid mē."  And hē ēode lythwōn forþ, and hē āstrehte hine ofer þā eorðan, and gebæd þæt, gif hit mihte beon, þæt þæt stund fēore fram him. And hē cwæð, "Abba, Fæder, ealle þing þē synt mihtige; āfyrra þysne calic fram mē; ac nā minn willa, ac þīn sy gedōn."

Þā com hē tō his leorningcnihtum, and hē funde hīe slæpende, and hē cwæð tō Petre, "Simone, slēpst þū? Ne mihtest þū ān tīd wacian? Wacoleað and gebiddað, þæt gē on costnunge ne gān; witodlice se gast is gearu, ac se līchama is unmihtig."

**Sēo Handunge**

And þā gyt þā hē spræc, þā com Iūdas, ān þāra twelf, and mid him micel menigu mid sweordum and mid sāwlum, fram þām ealdor-sacerdum and þām bocerum and þām ealdrum.  Se þe hine belǣwde sealde him tācen, þus cweðende, "Se þe ic cysse, hē hit is; nimað hine, and lædað hine gewarlice."

And sōne hē genealæcte tō him, and cwæð, "Rabbī, Rabbī," and cyste hine. And hīe hyra handa on hine wurpon, and namon hine.

And ān þāra þe þǣr ymbūtūnden his sweord brēd, and slōh þæs sacerda ealdres þēowan, and his eare of-ācearf.  Þā cwæð se Hælend him, "Læt þīn sweord on his stōwe; ealle þā þe sweord nimað, mid sweorde hīe forweorðað. Wenst þū þæt ic ne mihte nu mīnne Fæder biddan, and hē sende mē mā þonne twelf legionas engla?  Ac hū magon Godes gewritu beon gefyllede, þæt hit þus gebyrige?"

Þā forlēton ealle his leorningcnihtas hine, and flugon.  And hīe læddon þone Hælend tō þām ealdor-sacerde, þǣr ealle þā ealdras and þā boceras and þā ealdran gesamnode wǣron.

Þus wæs se Hælend geseald, se Hyrde for þām scēapum, se Līf for þām dēaðe.  His onsǣgednes, his lufu, his forgifennes wæs swa brād swa se heofon, swa dēop swa þā grunde.  Lēornien wē fram his bysene, and gemunen þā micelnesse his gife.
summary:
Certainly! This passage describes key events leading up to the arrest of Jesus Christ, highlighting moments from the New Testament. Here's a summary:

1. **Anointing at Bethany**: A woman anoints Jesus with ointment; Jesus defends her act as preparation for His burial and states it will be remembered wherever the gospel is preached.

2. **Judas's Betrayal**: Judas Iscariot agrees with the chief priests to betray Jesus for thirty pieces of silver.

3. **Last Supper**: During the Passover meal, Jesus predicts His betrayal by one of His disciples. He institutes the Lord's Supper, symbolizing His body and blood given for the remission of sins.

4. **Jesus Predicts Peter’s Denial**: Jesus tells His disciples that they will abandon Him. Peter vehemently denies he will, but Jesus predicts Peter will deny Him three times before the rooster crows.

5. **Prayer at Gethsemane**: Jesus, feeling sorrowful, prays for strength to face the impending suffering. He returns to find His disciples sleeping and asks them to stay awake and pray.

6. **Jesus’s Arrest**: Judas arrives with a mob to arrest Jesus, identifying Him with a kiss. One of Jesus's disciples cuts off the ear of the high priest’s servant, but Jesus heals the servant and submits to His arrest, emphasizing the fulfillment of the scriptures. The disciples then flee.

This summarizes the significant events leading to Jesus’s eventual crucifixion, including the themes of betrayal, prophecy, and fulfillment of scripture.

原文:
When Jesus understood it, he said unto them, Why trouble ye
the woman? for she hath wrought a good work upon me.
For ye have the poor always with you; but me ye have not
always.
For in that she hath poured this ointment on my body, she did
it for my burial.
Verily I say unto you, Wheresoever this gospel shall be preached in the whole world, there shall also this, that this woman hath done, be told for a memorial of her.

Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, went unto the chief priests,

And said unto them, What will ye give me, and I will deliver him unto you? And they covenanted with him for thirty pieces of silver.

And from that time he sought opportunity to betray him.

Now the first day of the feast of unleavened bread the
disciples came to Jesus, saying unto him, Where wilt thou that
we prepare for thee to eat the passover?
And he said, Go into the city to such a man, and say unto him,
The Master saith, My time is at hand; I will keep the passover
at thy house with my disciples.
And the disciples did as Jesus had appointed them; and they made ready the passover.

40:026:021 Now when the even was come, he sat down with the twelve.

And as they did eat, he said, Verily I say unto you, that one
of you shall betray me.
And they were exceeding sorrowful, and began every one of them
to say unto him, Lord, is it I?
And he answered and said, He that dippeth his hand with me in
the dish, the same shall betray me.
The Son of man goeth as it is written of him: but woe unto that man by whom the Son of man is betrayed! it had been good for that man if he had not been born.

Then Judas, which betrayed him, answered and said, Master, is it I? He said unto him, Thou hast said.

And as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and blessed it, and brake it, and gave it to the disciples, and said, Take, eat; this is my body.

And he took the cup, and gave thanks, and gave it to them,
saying, Drink ye all of it;
For this is my blood of the new testament, which is shed for
many for the remission of sins.
But I say unto you, I will not drink henceforth of this fruit of the vine, until that day when I drink it new with you in my Father's kingdom.

And when they had sung an hymn, they went out into the mount of Olives.

Then saith Jesus unto them, All ye shall be offended because of me this night: for it is written, I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock shall be scattered abroad.

But after I am risen again, I will go before you into Galilee.

Peter answered and said unto him, Though all men shall be
offended because of thee, yet will I never be offended.
Jesus said unto him, Verily I say unto thee, That this night,
before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice.
Peter said unto him, Though I should die with thee, yet will I
not deny thee. Likewise also said all the disciples.
Then cometh Jesus with them unto a place called Gethsemane, and saith unto the disciples, Sit ye here, while I go and pray yonder.

And he took with him Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, and
began to be sorrowful and very heavy.
Then saith he unto them, My soul is exceeding sorrowful, even
unto death: tarry ye here, and watch with me.
And he went a little farther, and fell on his face, and prayed, saying, O my Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me: nevertheless not as I will, but as thou wilt.

And he cometh unto the disciples, and findeth them asleep, and
saith unto Peter, What, could ye not watch with me one hour?
Watch and pray, that ye enter not into temptation: the spirit
indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.
He went away again the second time, and prayed, saying, O my Father, if this cup may not pass away from me, except I drink it, thy will be done.

And he came and found them asleep again: for their eyes were
heavy.
And he left them, and went away again, and prayed the third
time, saying the same words.
Then cometh he to his disciples, and saith unto them, Sleep on now, and take your rest: behold, the hour is at hand, and the Son of man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.

Rise, let us be going: behold, he is at hand that doth betray me.

And while he yet spake, lo, Judas, one of the twelve, came, and with him a great multitude with swords and staves, from the chief priests and elders of the people.

Now he that betrayed him gave them a sign, saying, Whomsoever
I shall kiss, that same is he: hold him fast.
And forthwith he came to Jesus, and said, Hail, master; and
kissed him.
And Jesus said unto him, Friend, wherefore art thou come? Then
came they, and laid hands on Jesus and took him.
And, behold, one of them which were with Jesus stretched out
his hand, and drew his sword, and struck a servant of the high
priest's, and smote off his ear.
Then said Jesus unto him, Put up again thy sword into his
place: for all they that take the sword shall perish with the
sword.
Thinkest thou that I cannot now pray to my Father, and he
shall presently give me more than twelve legions of angels?
But how then shall the scriptures be fulfilled, that thus it must be?
In that same hour said Jesus to the multitudes, Are ye come out as against a thief with swords and staves for to take me? I sat daily with you teaching in the temple, and ye laid no hold on me.

But all this was done, that the scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled. Then all the disciples forsook him, and fled.
