天地之道宏大深邃，尚且还要节制，珍惜其光彩，人的耳目又怎能长久劳累而不休息呢？人的精神又怎能长久驰骋而不耗尽呢？所以说人的气血和五脏是人的精华。血气如能专注聚集在五脏之内而不外溢，那么这胸腹内的五脏就充实而嗜欲也随之减少。五脏充实而嗜欲减少，就能使耳目清明、视听就畅达。耳目清明、视听畅达，叫做“明”。五脏能归属于心而不与心违逆，这样旺盛之气占优势而使人行为不乖悖、怪僻，人的精神就旺盛而精气不散泄。精神旺盛和精气不散泄则顺畅，顺畅就调匀，调匀则通达无阻，通达无阻就能产生出神奇的能力。这种能力能使人视无不见、听无不闻，没有什么事办不成的。这样，忧患祸害就不会侵入，邪气歪风也无法侵扰。
因此有些事情到四海之外去追求寻找却不能得到，有些则持守在身体之内却不能见效。所以贪多则反而获得少，看见大的反而所知甚少。人的五官七窍是精神的门窗，而气血则是五脏的使者。如果耳目沉溺在声色当中，那么五脏就会动荡不安。五脏动荡不安，那么血气就会激荡不休。血气激荡不休，那么精神就会驰骋在外而不能内守。精神驰骋在外不能持守，那么灾祸就会来临，即使祸大如山丘，你也没法感觉得到。所以，如果让耳目精明通畅而不受外界的诱惑、气志虚静恬愉而省却嗜欲、五脏安宁充盈而不外泄、精神持守于内心而不外越，那么即使是遥远的往事和未来的事情也不够你所认识的，更何况只是觉察眼前一些祸福之间的事情呢！所以说“精神逸出内心越远，所知道的就越少”。这就充分说明精神是不能外泄散逸的。所以，五色迷乱眼睛，使双目昏暗不明；五声哗乱耳朵，使双耳堵塞不聪；五味扰乱舌味，使口舌麻木无味；追逐名利而惑乱心性，使人行为放荡不羁。这四样东西，世间一般性的人是用来养生的，但实际上却是人生的累赘。所以说，嗜欲使人精气散逸，而爱憎之情则使人心力疲惫，假如不赶快清除它们，就会使人气血日耗殆尽。
summary: 这段文字主要探讨了宇宙生成、阴阳二气与万物的关系，以及人与自然和宇宙之间的和谐。文章首先描述了上古时期的混沌状态与阴阳二气的形成，解释了天地万物的产生过程。接着，探讨了人与天地自然的对应关系，通过五脏六腑及其功能与自然现象之间的对应，强调人类身体与自然宇宙之间的密切联系。最后，文章讨论了精神内守和清净恬逸对健康的重要性，提出追求外在物质和名利会影响内在精神的养护，导致身体和精神的失调，从而引发各种问题。因此，保持精神的内守和五脏的安宁是身体健康和长寿的关键。

原文:
21. Were it necessary to add any FURTHER PROOF AGAINST THE EXISTENCE OF MATTER after what has been said, I could instance several of those errors and difficulties (not to mention impieties) which have sprung from that tenet. It has occasioned numberless controversies and disputes in philosophy, and not a few of far greater moment in religion. But I shall not enter into the detail of them in this place, as well because I think arguments A POSTERIORI are unnecessary for confirming what has been, if I mistake not, sufficiently demonstrated A PRIORI, as because I shall hereafter find occasion to speak somewhat of them.
22. I am afraid I have given cause to think I am needlessly prolix in handling this subject. For, to what purpose is it to dilate on that which may be demonstrated with the utmost evidence in a line or two, to any one that is capable of the least reflexion? It is but looking into your own thoughts, and so trying whether you can conceive it possible for a sound, or figure, or motion, or colour to exist without the mind or unperceived. This easy trial may perhaps make you see that what you contend for is a downright contradiction. Insomuch that I am content to put the whole upon this issue:--If you can but CONCEIVE it possible for one extended movable substance, or, in general, for any one idea, or anything like an idea, to exist otherwise than in a mind perceiving it, I shall readily give up the cause. And, as for all that COMPAGES of external bodies you contend for, I shall grant you its existence, THOUGH (1.) YOU CANNOT EITHER GIVE ME ANY REASON WHY YOU BELIEVE IT EXISTS [Vide sect. lviii.], OR (2.) ASSIGN ANY USE TO IT WHEN IT IS SUPPOSED TO EXIST [Vide sect. lx.]. I say, the bare possibility of your opinions being true shall pass for an argument that it is so. [Note: i.e. although your argument be deficient in the two requisites of an hypothesis.--Ed.]
23. But, say you, surely there is nothing easier than for me to imagine trees, for instance, in a park, or books existing in a closet, and nobody by to perceive them. I answer, you may so, there is no difficulty in it; but what is all this, I beseech you, more than framing in your mind certain ideas which you call BOOKS and TREES, and the same time omitting to frame the idea of any one that may perceive them? BUT DO NOT YOU YOURSELF PERCEIVE OR THINK OF THEM ALL THE WHILE? This therefore is nothing to the purpose; it only shows you have the power of imagining or forming ideas in your mind: but it does not show that you can conceive it possible the objects of your thought may exist without the mind. To make out this, IT IS NECESSARY THAT YOU CONCEIVE THEM EXISTING UNCONCEIVED OR UNTHOUGHT OF, WHICH IS A MANIFEST REPUGNANCY. When we do our utmost to conceive the existence of external bodies, we are all the while only contemplating our own ideas. But the mind taking no notice of itself, is deluded to think it can and does conceive bodies existing unthought of or without the mind, though at the same time they are apprehended by or exist in itself. A little attention will discover to any one the truth and evidence of what is here said, and make it unnecessary to insist on any other proofs against the existence of material substance.
24. THE ABSOLUTE EXISTENCE OF UNTHINKING THINGS ARE WORDS WITHOUT A MEANING.--It is very obvious, upon the least inquiry into our thoughts, to know whether it is possible for us to understand what is meant by the ABSOLUTE EXISTENCE OF SENSIBLE OBJECTS IN THEMSELVES, OR WITHOUT THE MIND. To me it is evident those words mark out either a direct contradiction, or else nothing at all. And to convince others of this, I know no readier or fairer way than to entreat they would calmly attend to their own thoughts; and if by this attention the emptiness or repugnancy of those expressions does appear, surely nothing more is requisite for the conviction. It is on this therefore that I insist, to wit, that the ABSOLUTE existence of unthinking things are words without a meaning, or which include a contradiction. This is what I repeat and inculcate, and earnestly recommend to the attentive thoughts of the reader.
25. THIRD ARGUMENT.[Note: Vide sect. iii. and vii.]--REFUTATION OF LOCKE.--All our ideas, sensations, notions, or the things which we perceive, by whatsoever names they may be distinguished, are visibly inactive--there is nothing of power or agency included in them. So that ONE IDEA or object of thought CANNOT PRODUCE or make ANY ALTERATION IN ANOTHER. To be satisfied of the truth of this, there is nothing else requisite but a bare observation of our ideas. For, since they and every part of them exist only in the mind, it follows that there is nothing in them but what is perceived: but whoever shall attend to his ideas, whether of sense or reflexion, will not perceive in them any power or activity; there is, therefore, no such thing contained in them. A little attention will discover to us that the very being of an idea implies passiveness and inertness in it, insomuch that it is impossible for an idea to do anything, or, strictly speaking, to be the cause of anything: neither can it be the resemblance or pattern of any active being, as is evident from sect. 8. Whence it plainly follows that extension, figure, and motion cannot be the cause of our sensations. To say, therefore, that these are the effects of powers resulting from the configuration, number, motion, and size of corpuscles, must certainly be false. [Note: Vide sect. cii.]
26. CAUSE OF IDEAS.--We perceive a continual succession of ideas, some are anew excited, others are changed or totally disappear. There is therefore some cause of these ideas, whereon they depend, and which produces and changes them. That this cause cannot be any quality or idea or combination of ideas, is clear from the preceding section. It must therefore be a substance; but it has been shown that there is no corporeal or material substance: it remains therefore that the CAUSE OF IDEAS is an incorporeal active substance or Spirit.
27. NO IDEA OF SPIRIT.--A spirit is one simple, undivided, active being--as it perceives ideas it is called the UNDERSTANDING, and as it produces or otherwise operates about them it is called the WILL. Hence there can be no idea formed of a soul or spirit; for all ideas whatever, being passive and inert (vide sect. 25), they cannot represent unto us, by way of image or LIKENESS, that which acts. A little attention will make it plain to any one, that to have an idea which shall be like that active principle of motion and change of ideas is absolutely impossible. Such is the nature of SPIRIT, or that which acts, that it cannot be of itself perceived, BUT ONLY BY THE EFFECTS WHICH IT PRODUCETH. If any man shall doubt of the truth of what is here delivered, let him but reflect and try if he can frame the idea of any power or active being, and whether he has ideas of two principal powers, marked by the names WILL and UNDERSTANDING, distinct from each other as well as from a third idea of Substance or Being in general, with a relative notion of its supporting or being the subject of the aforesaid powers--which is signified by the name SOUL or SPIRIT. This is what some hold; but, so far as I can see, the words WILL [Note: "Understanding, mind."--Edit 1710.], SOUL, SPIRIT, do not stand for different ideas, or, in truth, for any idea at all, but for something which is very different from ideas, and which, being an agent, cannot be like unto, or represented by, any idea whatsoever. Though it must be owned at the same time that we have some notion of soul, spirit, and the operations of the mind: such as willing, loving, hating--inasmuch as we know or understand the meaning of these words.
28. I find I can excite ideas in my mind at pleasure, and vary and shift the scene as oft as I think fit. It is no more than willing, and straightway this or that idea arises in my fancy; and by the same power it is obliterated and makes way for another. This making and unmaking of ideas doth very properly denominate the mind active. Thus much is certain and grounded on experience; but when we think of unthinking agents or of exciting ideas exclusive of volition, we only amuse ourselves with words.
29. IDEAS OF SENSATION DIFFER FROM THOSE OF REFLECTION OR MEMORY.--But, whatever power I may have over MY OWN thoughts, I find the ideas actually perceived by Sense have not a like dependence on my will. When in broad daylight I open my eyes, it is not in my power to choose whether I shall see or no, or to determine what particular objects shall present themselves to my view; and so likewise as to the hearing and other senses; the ideas imprinted on them are not creatures of my will. There is THEREFORE SOME OTHER WILL OR SPIRIT that PRODUCES THEM.
30. LAWS OF NATURE.--The ideas of Sense are more strong, lively, and DISTINCT than those of the imagination; they have likewise a steadiness, order, and coherence, and are not excited at random, as those which are the effects of human wills often are, but in a regular train or series, the admirable connexion whereof sufficiently testifies the wisdom and benevolence of its Author. Now THE SET RULES OR ESTABLISHED METHODS WHEREIN THE MIND WE DEPEND ON EXCITES IN US THE IDEAS OF SENSE, ARE CALLED THE LAWS OF NATURE; and these we learn by experience, which teaches us that such and such ideas are attended with such and such other ideas, in the ordinary course of things.
生成:
## A Treatise on the Futility of Material Substance and the Primacy of Spirit

The pursuit of truth, that elusive beacon illuminating the cavernous depths of human understanding, often leads us down labyrinthine paths, fraught with uncertainty and shadowed by the limitations of our own perception. Such is the case with the enduring philosophical enigma concerning the nature of reality: Does a world of material substance exist independently of our minds, or are the objects of our perception merely phantoms, ethereal constructs woven from the very fabric of our thoughts? This discourse, steeped in centuries of fervent debate, finds itself at an impasse, with proponents of both materialism and idealism entrenched in seemingly irreconcilable positions. 

It is the contention of this treatise that the notion of material substance, existing as a separate entity divorced from the perceiving mind, is inherently flawed, leading to a morass of philosophical contradictions and ultimately failing to provide a satisfactory explanation for the world we experience. Instead, I posit that it is the active principle of spirit, a realm beyond the confines of our physical senses, which serves as the wellspring of our perceptions, orchestrating the symphony of sensations we perceive as reality.

The bedrock of the materialist argument rests upon the assumption that objects possess an intrinsic existence, independent of any observer. This notion, however appealing in its simplicity, crumbles upon closer examination. For how can we, in good conscience, assert the independent existence of that which is fundamentally unknowable without the act of perception? 

Consider the nature of our sensory experiences: the vibrant hues of a summer sunset, the melodious strains of a string quartet, the gentle caress of a warm breeze. Can we conceive of these sensations existing in the absence of a mind to perceive them? Can we fathom the existence of a crimson sunset without an eye to behold its fiery splendor, or the dulcet tones of a violin concerto without an ear to register its harmonious resonance? I posit that such a notion is inherently contradictory. To imagine these sensations, to conjure them in the mind's eye, is to engage in the very act of perception, thus rendering their purported independent existence null and void. 

Furthermore, the concept of an unperceived object, existing in some absolute sense beyond the realm of thought, teeters precariously on the precipice of meaninglessness. If such an object is utterly imperceptible, devoid of any qualities that could register upon our senses or be apprehended by our minds, then what distinguishes it from utter non-existence?  Is it not merely an empty abstraction, a phantom concept devoid of any tangible reality? To speak of an object's existence while simultaneously denying any possible means of verifying or even conceiving of that existence is to engage in a linguistic sleight of hand, a semantic dance devoid of any substantive meaning.

Moreover, the materialist position struggles to account for the undeniable activity and dynamism inherent in our experience of the world.  Ideas, the fundamental building blocks of our thoughts and perceptions, are by their very nature passive and inert. They possess no intrinsic power to initiate change or to exert influence upon one another.  A solitary idea, suspended in the vacuum of an unperceived world, would remain forever static, frozen in an eternal state of inert potentiality. And yet, our experience of the world is anything but static. We are bombarded by a ceaseless torrent of sensations, a vibrant tapestry of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and textures, all swirling and interacting in a dynamic dance of perception. 

What, then, is the source of this ceaseless activity? If ideas themselves are powerless, then there must be some external force, some animating principle, responsible for breathing life into the inert world of perception. This active principle, I argue, is the essence of spirit – an immaterial, incorporeal entity that transcends the limitations of the physical realm. It is the spirit that animates our perceptions, that orchestrates the intricate ballet of sensations we experience as reality.

While we may not be able to directly perceive this spirit, to grasp its essence in its totality, we can nonetheless infer its existence through its effects. Just as we cannot directly observe the wind, but can witness its passage through the rustling leaves and billowing sails, so too can we discern the presence of spirit through its influence on the world of our perceptions. It is the spirit that breathes life into the inert world of ideas, that transforms passive potentiality into dynamic actuality. 

This is not to suggest that the mind is merely a passive recipient of the spirit's influence. Indeed, we possess the capacity for reflection, for memory, for the active manipulation of ideas. We can conjure images in our minds, recall past experiences, and engage in imaginative flights of fancy.  Yet even in these acts of mental creation, we are not creating ex nihilo.  We are, rather, working with the raw materials of perception provided by the spirit, shaping and molding them according to our own unique will and understanding.

This interplay between the active principle of spirit and the receptive capacity of the human mind is evident in the distinction between those sensations that are imposed upon us involuntarily, such as the blinding light of the midday sun, and those ideas we are able to summon at will, such as the recollection of a childhood memory or the mental image of a distant land. The former speaks to the spirit's power to impress upon us certain fundamental aspects of reality, while the latter highlights the mind's ability to actively engage with and manipulate those impressions.

Further evidence for the spirit's influence can be found in the remarkable order and regularity that pervades the natural world. The celestial bodies move with predictable precision, the seasons change in an eternal cycle, and the laws of physics operate with unwavering consistency. This inherent order, this grand symphony of natural laws, cannot be adequately explained by the random interactions of inert matter.  It points, instead, to the presence of an intelligent design, a guiding hand that orchestrates the intricate workings of the cosmos. This guiding hand, I submit, is none other than the spirit, the divine architect who has imbued the universe with its inherent order and purpose.

In conclusion, the pursuit of a comprehensive understanding of reality necessitates moving beyond the limitations of the materialist perspective. The notion of a material world existing independently of the perceiving mind ultimately collapses under the weight of its own contradictions. It is only by acknowledging the primacy of spirit, the active principle that animates our perceptions and orchestrates the grand symphony of the cosmos, that we can hope to unlock the true nature of reality and our place within its magnificent tapestry.
summary:
Certainly! The passage s primarily an argument against the existence of material substances and in favor of the notion that all ideas and objects of thought exist only in the mind. Here are the key points:

1. **Against Materialism**: The author argues that the idea of material substances existing independently of the mind leads to numerous philosophical and religious controversies and contradictions.

2. **Perception is Key**: The argument asserts that it is impossible to conceive of sounds, colors, motions, or other sensations existing without being perceived by a mind. If one tries to imagine such things, they are still being perceived by that person's mind, making their independent existence contradictory.

3. **Impossibility of Absolute Existence**: The author maintains that the concept of the absolute existence of unperceived objects (external to the mind) is either a contradiction or meaningless. Such objects, if they exist unthought of, are not fathomable and therefore not real.

4. **Ideas and Activity**: All ideas are inherently passive and inert, incapable of causing or affecting change by themselves since they exist only in the mind. This asserts the immaterial nature of what we perceive.

5. **Role of Spirit**: The argument concludes that the continuous experience of ideas must be caused by an active, incorporeal substance or spirit since ideas themselves lack power or agency. Therefore, the true cause of our experiences is a spirit, or God.

6. **Human Understanding and Will**: Acknowledges that the mind, or spirit, actively produces or operates about ideas but that humans cannot form ideas or images of this active principle, only conceptualize it through its effects.

7. **Difference in Ideas**: Differentiates between the passive ideas of sensations, which are not subject to individual will (e.g., seeing in broad daylight), and ideas formed by memory or reflection, dependent on the mind's activity.

8. **Laws of Nature**: Describes the consistent and orderly patterns in which sensory ideas are experienced as "laws of nature," which are established by the will of the spirit or God that produces them.

The passage ultimately emphasizes that the notion of material substance independent of the mind is flawed and proposes that an active spiritual substance is the true source of our sensory experiences.

Such is the nature of SPIRIT, or that which acts, that it cannot be of itself perceived, BUT ONLY BY THE EFFECTS WHICH IT PRODUCETH. If any man shall doubt of the truth of what is here delivered, let him but reflect and try if he can frame the idea of any power or active being, and whether he has ideas of two principal powers, marked by the names WILL and UNDERSTANDING, distinct from each other as well as from a third idea of Substance or Being in general, with a relative notion of its supporting or being the subject of the aforesaid powers--which is signified by the name SOUL or SPIRIT. This is what some hold; but, so far as I can see, the words WILL [Note: "Understanding, mind."--Edit 1710.], SOUL, SPIRIT, do not stand for different ideas, or, in truth, for any idea at all, but for something which is very different from ideas, and which, being an agent, cannot be like unto, or represented by, any idea whatsoever. Though it must be owned at the same time that we have some notion of soul, spirit, and the operations of the mind: such as willing, loving, hating--inasmuch as we know or understand the meaning of these words.
28. I find I can excite ideas in my mind at pleasure, and vary and shift the scene as oft as I think fit. It is no more than willing, and straightway this or that idea arises in my fancy; and by the same power it is obliterated and makes way for another. This making and unmaking of ideas doth very properly denominate the mind active. Thus much is certain and grounded on experience; but when we think of unthinking agents or of exciting ideas exclusive of volition, we only amuse ourselves with words.
29. IDEAS OF SENSATION DIFFER FROM THOSE OF REFLECTION OR MEMORY.--But, whatever power I may have over MY OWN thoughts, I find the ideas actually perceived by Sense have not a like dependence on my will. When in broad daylight I open my eyes, it is not in my power to choose whether I shall see or no, or to determine what particular objects shall present themselves to my view; and so likewise as to the hearing and other senses; the ideas imprinted on them are not creatures of my will. There is THEREFORE SOME OTHER WILL OR SPIRIT that PRODUCES THEM.
31. LAWS OF NATURE.--The ideas of Sense are more strong, lively, and DISTINCT than those of the imagination; they have likewise a steadiness, order, and coherence, and are not excited at random, as those which are the effects of human wills often are, but in a regular train or series, the admirable connexion whereof sufficiently testifies the wisdom and benevolence of its Author. Now THE SET RULES OR ESTABLISHED METHODS WHEREIN THE MIND WE DEPEND ON EXCITES IN US THE IDEAS OF SENSE, ARE CALLED THE LAWS OF NATURE; and these we learn by experience, which teaches us that such and such ideas are attended with such and such other ideas, in the ordinary course of things.
summary:
Certainly! The passage s primarily an argument against the existence of material substances and in favor of the notion that all ideas and objects of thought exist only in the mind. Here are the key points:

1. **Against Materialism**: The author argues that the idea of material substances existing independently of the mind leads to numerous philosophical and religious controversies and contradictions.

2. **Perception is Key**: The argument asserts that it is impossible to conceive of sounds, colors, motions, or other sensations existing without being perceived by a mind. If one tries to imagine such things, they are still being perceived by that person's mind, making their independent existence contradictory.

3. **Impossibility of Absolute Existence**: The author maintains that the concept of the absolute existence of unperceived objects (external to the mind) is either a contradiction or meaningless. Such objects, if they exist unthought of, are not fathomable and therefore not real.

4. **Ideas and Activity**: All ideas are inherently passive and inert, incapable of causing or affecting change by themselves since they exist only in the mind. This asserts the immaterial nature of what we perceive.

5. **Role of Spirit**: The argument concludes that the continuous experience of ideas must be caused by an active, incorporeal substance or spirit since ideas themselves lack power or agency. Therefore, the true cause of our experiences is a spirit, or God.

6. **Human Understanding and Will**: Acknowledges that the mind, or spirit, actively produces or operates about ideas but that humans cannot form ideas or images of this active principle, only conceptualize it through its effects.

7. **Difference in Ideas**: Differentiates between the passive ideas of sensations, which are not subject to individual will (e.g., seeing in broad daylight), and ideas formed by memory or reflection, dependent on the mind's activity.

8. **Laws of Nature**: Describes the consistent and orderly patterns in which sensory ideas are experienced as "laws of nature," which are established by the will of the spirit or God that produces them.

The passage ultimately emphasizes that the notion of material substance independent of the mind is flawed and proposes that an active spiritual substance is the true source of our sensory experiences.

原文:
21. Were it necessary to add any FURTHER PROOF AGAINST THE EXISTENCE OF MATTER after what has been said, I could instance several of those errors and difficulties (not to mention impieties) which have sprung from that tenet. It has occasioned numberless controversies and disputes in philosophy, and not a few of far greater moment in religion. But I shall not enter into the detail of them in this place, as well because I think arguments A POSTERIORI are unnecessary for confirming what has been, if I mistake not, sufficiently demonstrated A PRIORI, as because I shall hereafter find occasion to speak somewhat of them.
22. I am afraid I have given cause to think I am needlessly prolix in handling this subject. For, to what purpose is it to dilate on that which may be demonstrated with the utmost evidence in a line or two, to any one that is capable of the least reflexion? It is but looking into your own thoughts, and so trying whether you can conceive it possible for a sound, or figure, or motion, or colour to exist without the mind or unperceived. This easy trial may perhaps make you see that what you contend for is a downright contradiction. Insomuch that I am content to put the whole upon this issue:--If you can but CONCEIVE it possible for one extended movable substance, or, in general, for any one idea, or anything like an idea, to exist otherwise than in a mind perceiving it, I shall readily give up the cause. And, as for all that COMPAGES of external bodies you contend for, I shall grant you its existence, THOUGH (1.) YOU CANNOT EITHER GIVE ME ANY REASON WHY YOU BELIEVE IT EXISTS [Vide sect. lviii.], OR (2.) ASSIGN ANY USE TO IT WHEN IT IS SUPPOSED TO EXIST [Vide sect. lx.]. I say, the bare possibility of your opinions being true shall pass for an argument that it is so. [Note: i.e. although your argument be deficient in the two requisites of an hypothesis.--Ed.]
23. But, say you, surely there is nothing easier than for me to imagine trees, for instance, in a park, or books existing in a closet, and nobody by to perceive them. I answer, you may so, there is no difficulty in it; but what is all this, I beseech you, more than framing in your mind certain ideas which you call BOOKS and TREES, and the same time omitting to frame the idea of any one that may perceive them? BUT DO NOT YOU YOURSELF PERCEIVE OR THINK OF THEM ALL THE WHILE? This therefore is nothing to the purpose; it only shows you have the power of imagining or forming ideas in your mind: but it does not show that you can conceive it possible the objects of your thought may exist without the mind. To make out this, IT IS NECESSARY THAT YOU CONCEIVE THEM EXISTING UNCONCEIVED OR UNTHOUGHT OF, WHICH IS A MANIFEST REPUGNANCY. When we do our utmost to conceive the existence of external bodies, we are all the while only contemplating our own ideas. But the mind taking no notice of itself, is deluded to think it can and does conceive bodies existing unthought of or without the mind, though at the same time they are apprehended by or exist in itself. A little attention will discover to any one the truth and evidence of what is here said, and make it unnecessary to insist on any other proofs against the existence of material substance.
24. THE ABSOLUTE EXISTENCE OF UNTHINKING THINGS ARE WORDS WITHOUT A MEANING.--It is very obvious, upon the least inquiry into our thoughts, to know whether it is possible for us to understand what is meant by the ABSOLUTE EXISTENCE OF SENSIBLE OBJECTS IN THEMSELVES, OR WITHOUT THE MIND. To me it is evident those words mark out either a direct contradiction, or else nothing at all. And to convince others of this, I know no readier or fairer way than to entreat they would calmly attend to their own thoughts; and if by this attention the emptiness or repugnancy of those expressions does appear, surely nothing more is requisite for the conviction. It is on this therefore that I insist, to wit, that the ABSOLUTE existence of unthinking things are words without a meaning, or which include a contradiction. This is what I repeat and inculcate, and earnestly recommend to the attentive thoughts of the reader.
25. THIRD ARGUMENT.[Note: Vide sect. iii. and vii.]--REFUTATION OF LOCKE.--All our ideas, sensations, notions, or the things which we perceive, by whatsoever names they may be distinguished, are visibly inactive--there is nothing of power or agency included in them. So that ONE IDEA or object of thought CANNOT PRODUCE or make ANY ALTERATION IN ANOTHER. To be satisfied of the truth of this, there is nothing else requisite but a bare observation of our ideas. For, since they and every part of them exist only in the mind, it follows that there is nothing in them but what is perceived: but whoever shall attend to his ideas, whether of sense or reflexion, will not perceive in them any power or activity; there is, therefore, no such thing contained in them. A little attention will discover to us that the very being of an idea implies passiveness and inertness in it, insomuch that it is impossible for an idea to do anything, or, strictly speaking, to be the cause of anything: neither can it be the resemblance or pattern of any active being, as is evident from sect. 8. Whence it plainly follows that extension, figure, and motion cannot be the cause of our sensations. To say, therefore, that these are the effects of powers resulting from the configuration, number, motion, and size of corpuscles, must certainly be false. [Note: Vide sect. cii.]
26. CAUSE OF IDEAS.--We perceive a continual succession of ideas, some are anew excited, others are changed or totally disappear. There is therefore some cause of these ideas, whereon they depend, and which produces and changes them. That this cause cannot be any quality or idea or combination of ideas, is clear from the preceding section. It must therefore be a substance; but it has been shown that there is no corporeal or material substance: it remains therefore that the CAUSE OF IDEAS is an incorporeal active substance or Spirit.
27. NO IDEA OF SPIRIT.--A spirit is one simple, undivided, active being--as it perceives ideas it is called the UNDERSTANDING, and as it produces or otherwise operates about them it is called the WILL. Hence there can be no idea formed of a soul or spirit; for all ideas whatever, being passive and inert (vide sect. 25), they cannot represent unto us, by way of image or LIKENESS, that which acts. A little attention will make it plain to any one, that to have an idea which shall be like that active principle of motion and change of ideas is absolutely impossible. Such is the nature of SPIRIT, or that which acts, that it cannot be of itself perceived, BUT ONLY BY THE EFFECTS WHICH IT PRODUCETH. If any man shall doubt of the truth of what is here delivered, let him but reflect and try if he can frame the idea of any power or active being, and whether he has ideas of two principal powers, marked by the names WILL and UNDERSTANDING, distinct from each other as well as from a third idea of Substance or Being in general, with a relative notion of its supporting or being the subject of the aforesaid powers--which is signified by the name SOUL or SPIRIT. This is what some hold; but, so far as I can see, the words WILL [Note: "Understanding, mind."--Edit 1710.], SOUL, SPIRIT, do not stand for different ideas, or, in truth, for any idea at all, but for something which is very different from ideas, and which, being an agent, cannot be like unto, or represented by, any idea whatsoever. Though it must be owned at the same time that we have some notion of soul, spirit, and the operations of the mind: such as willing, loving, hating--inasmuch as we know or understand the meaning of these words.

It is no more than willing, and straightway this or that idea arises in my fancy; and by the same power it is obliterated and makes way for another. This making and unmaking of ideas doth very properly denominate the mind active. Thus much is certain and grounded on experience; but when we think of unthinking agents or of exciting ideas exclusive of volition, we only amuse ourselves with words.
29. IDEAS OF SENSATION DIFFER FROM THOSE OF REFLECTION OR MEMORY.--But, whatever power I may have over MY OWN thoughts, I find the ideas actually perceived by Sense have not a like dependence on my will. When in broad daylight I open my eyes, it is not in my power to choose whether I shall see or no, or to determine what particular objects shall present themselves to my view; and so likewise as to the hearing and other senses; the ideas imprinted on them are not creatures of my will. 原文:
The idea of an object is an essential part of the belief of it, but not the whole. We conceive many things, which we do not believe. In order then to discover more fully the nature of belief, or the qualities of those ideas we assent to, let us weigh the following considerations.
It is evident, that all reasonings from causes or effects terminate in conclusions, concerning matter of fact; that is, concerning the existence of objects or of their qualities. It is also evident, that the idea, of existence is nothing different from the idea of any object, and that when after the simple conception of any thing we would conceive it as existent, we in reality make no addition to or alteration on our first idea. Thus when we affirm, that God is existent, we simply form the idea of such a being, as he is represented to us; nor is the existence, which we attribute to him, conceived by a particular idea, which we join to the idea of his other qualities, and can again separate and distinguish from them. But I go farther; and not content with asserting, that the conception of the existence of any object is no addition to the simple conception of it, I likewise maintain, that the belief of the existence joins no new ideas to those which compose the idea of the object. When I think of God, when I think of him as existent, and when I believe him to be existent, my idea of him neither encreases nor diminishes. But as it is certain there is a great difference betwixt the simple conception of the existence of an object, and the belief of it, and as this difference lies not in the parts or composition of the idea, which we conceive; it follows, that it must lie in the manner, in which we conceive it.
Suppose a person present with me, who advances propositions, to which I do not assent, that Caesar dyed in his bed, that silver is more fusible, than lead, or mercury heavier than gold; it is evident, that notwithstanding my incredulity, I clearly understand his meaning, and form all the same ideas, which he forms. My imagination is endowed with the same powers as his; nor is it possible for him to conceive any idea, which I cannot conceive; nor conjoin any, which I cannot conjoin. I therefore ask, Wherein consists the difference betwixt believing and disbelieving any proposition? The answer is easy with regard to propositions, that are proved by intuition or demonstration. In that case, the person, who assents, not only conceives the ideas according to the proposition, but is necessarily determined to conceive them in that particular manner, either immediately or by the interposition of other ideas. Whatever is absurd is unintelligible; nor is it possible for the imagination to conceive any thing contrary to a demonstration. But as in reasonings from causation, and concerning matters of fact, this absolute necessity cannot take place, and the imagination is free to conceive both sides of the question, I still ask, Wherein consists the deference betwixt incredulity and belief? since in both cases the conception of the idea is equally possible and requisite.
It will not be a satisfactory answer to say, that a person, who does not assent to a proposition you advance; after having conceived the object in the same manner with you; immediately conceives it in a different manner, and has different ideas of it. This answer is unsatisfactory; not because it contains any falshood, but because it discovers not all the truth. It is contest, that in all cases, wherein we dissent from any person, we conceive both sides of the question; but as we can believe only one, it evidently follows, that the belief must make some difference betwixt that conception to which we assent, and that from which we dissent. We may mingle, and unite, and separate, and confound, and vary our ideas in a hundred different ways; but until there appears some principle, which fixes one of these different situations, we have in reality no opinion: And this principle, as it plainly makes no addition to our precedent ideas, can only change the manner of our conceiving them.
All the perceptions of the mind are of two kinds, viz. impressions and ideas, which differ from each other only in their different degrees of force and vivacity. Our ideas are copyed from our impressions, and represent them in all their parts. When you would any way vary the idea of a particular object, you can only encrease or diminish its force and vivacity. If you make any other change on it, it represents a different object or impression. The case is the same as in colours. A particular shade of any colour may acquire a new degree of liveliness or brightness without any other variation. But when you produce any other variation, it is no longer the same shade or colour. So that as belief does nothing but vary the manner, in which we conceive any object, it can only bestow on our ideas an additional force and vivacity. An opinion, therefore, or belief may be most accurately defined, a lively idea related to or associated with a present impression.[6]
生成:
## The Force of Belief: A Treatise on the Nature of Assent

The human mind, that boundless realm of thought and imagination, navigates a constant stream of concepts, conjuring images and entertaining possibilities with remarkable agility. Yet, within this intricate landscape, a crucial distinction arises, separating the mere conception of an idea from the act of believing it. While our cognitive faculties readily entertain a multitude of notions, from the whimsical to the profound, it is the act of belief that imbues these concepts with a certain power, transforming them from fleeting phantoms of thought into convictions that shape our understanding of the world and guide our actions within it.

To truly grasp the essence of belief, we must first acknowledge that the act of believing in an object's existence does not, in itself, introduce any novel elements to our conception of that object. When we conceive of something, be it a majestic unicorn or the intricate workings of a complex machine, we form a mental representation, a blueprint of sorts, that outlines its defining characteristics. Belief, then, does not alter this blueprint; it does not add details or enhance the resolution of our mental image. Rather, it operates on a different level altogether. It is not a matter of adding to our conception but of imbuing it with a distinct quality, a force that elevates it from the realm of mere contemplation to that of conviction.

Consider, for instance, the concept of a celestial city, adorned with towers of gold and streets paved with precious stones. We can readily conjure such an image in our minds, tracing the contours of its fantastical architecture and marveling at its opulence. However, our ability to conceive of this wondrous city does not necessitate our belief in its actual existence. We can entertain the idea, exploring its every detail with intellectual curiosity, without ever succumbing to the conviction that such a place truly exists beyond the realm of our imagination.

This distinction highlights the crucial point that disbelief does not equate to an inability to understand or conceive. We may fully comprehend the intricacies of a complex scientific theory without necessarily accepting its veracity. Similarly, we can grasp the tenets of a particular religion without feeling compelled to embrace its doctrines as articles of faith. Disbelief, therefore, is not a deficiency of intellect or imagination but rather a different mode of engaging with an idea, one characterized by a certain reservation, a withholding of full assent.

This leads us to the crux of the matter: the manner in which we conceive an idea. Belief, in its essence, is not defined by the content of our conceptions but by the specific way in which we hold them in our minds. It is a particular determination, a firm conviction that goes beyond mere acknowledgement and imbues the idea with a sense of reality and weight. To believe is to embrace an idea not as a hypothetical possibility but as an actuality, a truth that shapes our understanding of ourselves and the world around us.

To further illuminate this distinction, let us consider the various perceptions of the mind, which can be broadly categorized as impressions and ideas. Impressions, such as those derived from our senses, possess a vividness, a forcefulness that commands our attention. They are immediate, visceral experiences that leave an undeniable imprint on our consciousness. Ideas, on the other hand, are less vibrant copies of these original impressions, lacking the immediacy and intensity of their sensory counterparts.

This difference in vivacity and force is central to understanding the nature of belief. When we believe in something, the idea representing that belief takes on a strength and vitality akin to an impression. It is no longer a pale shadow flickering at the periphery of our awareness but a potent force occupying center stage in our minds. This forceful conception, imbued with the weight of conviction, influences our thoughts, emotions, and ultimately, our actions.

In essence, belief is a lively idea, pulsating with a force borrowed from the immediacy of present impressions. It is this vivacity, this sense of realness, that distinguishes a mere concept from a deeply held belief. When an idea takes hold of us with such intensity, it ceases to be a mere object of contemplation and transforms into a guiding principle, shaping our perceptions and influencing our interactions with the world.

Therefore, the essence of belief lies not in the novelty of the ideas themselves but in the manner in which they are apprehended by the mind. It is the force of conviction, the vivacity with which an idea is conceived, that elevates it from the realm of speculation to the realm of belief, imbuing it with the power to shape our understanding, guide our actions, and ultimately, define the very fabric of our realities.
summary:
This passage explores the nature of belief and how it differs from mere conception or imagination. It begins by stating that while we can conceive many things without necessarily believing in them, the belief in an object's existence adds no new ideas to the simple conception of it. The difference between belief and disbelief is not in the ideas themselves but in the manner of conceiving them.

The author uses examples to illustrate that disbelief does not imply a lack of understanding or the inability to conceive the ideas in question. Rather, belief involves a particular determination or manner of conceiving those ideas. The passage further explains that all perceptions of the mind are either impressions (vivid and forceful) or ideas (less vivid copies of impressions). The difference between belief and mere conception lies in the degree of force and vivacity with which an idea is conceived. Hence, belief is essentially a lively or forceful idea associated with a present impression.

The idea of an object is an essential part of the belief of it, but not the whole. We conceive many things, which we do not believe. In order then to discover more fully the nature of belief, or the qualities of those ideas we assent to, let us weigh the following considerations.
It is evident, that all reasonings from causes or effects terminate in conclusions, concerning matter of fact; that is, concerning the existence of objects or of their qualities. It is also evident, that the idea, of existence is nothing different from the idea of any object, and that when after the simple conception of any thing we would conceive it as existent, we in reality make no addition to or alteration on our first idea. Thus when we affirm, that God is existent, we simply form the idea of such a being, as he is represented to us; nor is the existence, which we attribute to him, conceived by a particular idea, which we join to the idea of his other qualities, and can again separate and distinguish from them. But I go farther; and not content with asserting, that the conception of the existence of any object is no addition to the simple conception of it, I likewise maintain, that the belief of the existence joins no new ideas to those which compose the idea of the object. When I think of God, when I think of him as existent, and when I believe him to be existent, my idea of him neither encreases nor diminishes. But as it is certain there is a great difference betwixt the simple conception of the existence of an object, and the belief of it, and as this difference lies not in the parts or composition of the idea, which we conceive; it follows, that it must lie in the manner, in which we conceive it.
Suppose a person present with me, who advances propositions, to which I do not assent, that Caesar dyed in his bed, that silver is more fusible, than lead, or mercury heavier than gold; it is evident, that notwithstanding my incredulity, I clearly understand his meaning, and form all the same ideas, which he forms. My imagination is endowed with the same powers as his; nor is it possible for him to conceive any idea, which I cannot conceive; nor conjoin any, which I cannot conjoin. I therefore ask, Wherein consists the difference betwixt believing and disbelieving any proposition? The answer is easy with regard to propositions, that are proved by intuition or demonstration. In that case, the person, who assents, not only conceives the ideas according to the proposition, but is necessarily determined to conceive them in that particular manner, either immediately or by the interposition of other ideas. Whatever is absurd is unintelligible; nor is it possible for the imagination to conceive any thing contrary to a demonstration. But as in reasonings from causation, and concerning matters of fact, this absolute necessity cannot take place, and the imagination is free to conceive both sides of the question, I still ask, Wherein consists the deference betwixt incredulity and belief? since in both cases the conception of the idea is equally possible and requisite.
It will not be a satisfactory answer to say, that a person, who does not assent to a proposition you advance; after having conceived the object in the same manner with you; immediately conceives it in a different manner, and has different ideas of it. This answer is unsatisfactory; not because it contains any falshood, but because it discovers not all the truth. It is contest, that in all cases, wherein we dissent from any person, we conceive both sides of the question; but as we can believe only one, it evidently follows, that the belief must make some difference betwixt that conception to which we assent, and that from which we dissent. We may mingle, and unite, and separate, and confound, and vary our ideas in a hundred different ways; but until there appears some principle, which fixes one of these different situations, we have in reality no opinion: And this principle, as it plainly makes no addition to our precedent ideas, can only change the manner of our conceiving them.
All the perceptions of the mind are of two kinds, viz. impressions and ideas, which differ from each other only in their different degrees of force and vivacity. Our ideas are copyed from our impressions, and represent them in all their parts. When you would any way vary the idea of a particular object, you can only encrease or diminish its force and vivacity. If you make any other change on it, it represents a different object or impression. The case is the same as in colours. A particular shade of any colour may acquire a new degree of liveliness or brightness without any other variation. But when you produce any other variation, it is no longer the same shade or colour. So that as belief does nothing but vary the manner, in which we conceive any object, it can only bestow on our ideas an additional force and vivacity. An opinion, therefore, or belief may be most accurately defined, a lively idea related to or associated with a present impression.[6]

When I think of God, when I think of him as existent, and when I believe him to be existent, my idea of him neither encreases nor diminishes. But as it is certain there is a great difference betwixt the simple conception of the existence of an object, and the belief of it, and as this difference lies not in the parts or composition of the idea, which we conceive; it follows, that it must lie in the manner, in which we conceive it.
Suppose a person present with me, who advances propositions, to which I do not assent, that Caesar dyed in his bed, that silver is more fusible, than lead, or mercury heavier than gold; it is evident, that notwithstanding my incredulity, I clearly understand his meaning, and form all the same ideas, which he forms. My imagination is endowed with the same powers as his; nor is it possible for him to conceive any idea, which I cannot conceive; nor conjoin any, which I cannot conjoin. I therefore ask, Wherein consists the difference betwixt believing and disbelieving any proposition? The answer is easy with regard to propositions, that are proved by intuition or demonstration. In that case, the person, who assents, not only conceives the ideas according to the proposition, but is necessarily determined to conceive them in that particular manner, either immediately or by the interposition of other ideas. Whatever is absurd is unintelligible; nor is it possible for the imagination to conceive any thing contrary to a demonstration. But as in reasonings from causation, and concerning matters of fact, this absolute necessity cannot take place, and the imagination is free to conceive both sides of the question, I still ask, Wherein consists the deference betwixt incredulity and belief? since in both cases the conception of the idea is equally possible and requisite.
It will not be a satisfactory answer to say, that a person, who does not assent to a proposition you advance; after having conceived the object in the same manner with you; immediately conceives it in a different manner, and has different ideas of it. This answer is unsatisfactory; not because it contains any falshood, but because it discovers not all the truth. It is contest, that in all cases, wherein we dissent from any person, we conceive both sides of the question; but as we can believe only one, it evidently follows, that the belief must make some difference betwixt that conception to which we assent, and that from which we dissent. We may mingle, and unite, and separate, and confound, and vary our ideas in a hundred different ways; but until there appears some principle, which fixes one of these different situations, we have in reality no opinion: And this principle, as it plainly makes no addition to our precedent ideas, can only change the manner of our conceiving them.
All the perceptions of the mind are of two kinds, viz. impressions and ideas, which differ from each other only in their different degrees of force and vivacity. Our ideas are copyed from our impressions, and represent them in all their parts. When you would any way vary the idea of a particular object, you can only encrease or diminish its force and vivacity. If you make any other change on it, it represents a different object or impression. The case is the same as in colours. A particular shade of any colour may acquire a new degree of liveliness or brightness without any other variation. But when you produce any other variation, it is no longer the same shade or colour. So that as belief does nothing but vary the manner, in which we conceive any object, it can only bestow on our ideas an additional force and vivacity. An opinion, therefore, or belief may be most accurately defined, a lively idea related to or associated with a present impression.[6]
summary:
This passage explores the nature of belief and how it differs from mere conception or imagination. It begins by stating that while we can conceive many things without necessarily believing in them, the belief in an object's existence adds no new ideas to the simple conception of it. The difference between belief and disbelief is not in the ideas themselves but in the manner of conceiving them.

The author uses examples to illustrate that disbelief does not imply a lack of understanding or the inability to conceive the ideas in question. Rather, belief involves a particular determination or manner of conceiving those ideas. The passage further explains that all perceptions of the mind are either impressions (vivid and forceful) or ideas (less vivid copies of impressions). The difference between belief and mere conception lies in the degree of force and vivacity with which an idea is conceived. Hence, belief is essentially a lively or forceful idea associated with a present impression.

原文:
There is, in Dr. Tillotson's writings, an argument against the real presence, which is as concise, and elegant, and strong as any argument can possibly be supposed against a doctrine, so little worthy of a serious refutation. It is acknowledged on all hands, says that learned prelate, that the authority, either of the scripture or of tradition, is founded merely in the testimony of the apostles, who were eye-witnesses to those miracles of our Saviour, by which he proved his divine mission. Our evidence, then, for the truth of the Christian religion is less than the evidence for the truth of our senses; because, even in the first authors of our religion, it was no greater; and it is evident it must diminish in passing from them to their disciples; nor can any one rest such confidence in their testimony, as in the immediate object of his senses. But a weaker evidence can never destroy a stronger; and therefore, were the doctrine of the real presence ever so clearly revealed in scripture, it were directly contrary to the rules of just reasoning to give our assent to it. It contradicts sense, though both the scripture and tradition, on which it is supposed to be built, carry not such evidence with them as sense; when they are considered merely as external evidences, and are not brought home to every one's breast, by the immediate operation of the Holy Spirit.
Nothing is so convenient as a decisive argument of this kind, which must at least silence the most arrogant bigotry and superstition, and free us from their impertinent solicitations. I flatter myself, that I have discovered an argument of a like nature, which, if just, will, with the wise and learned, be an everlasting check to all kinds of superstitious delusion, and consequently, will be useful as long as the world endures. For so long, I presume, will the accounts of miracles and prodigies be found in all history, sacred and profane.
87.Though experience be our only guide in reasoning concerning matters of fact; it must be acknowledged, that this guide is not altogether infallible, but in some cases is apt to lead us into errors. One, who in our climate, should expect better weather in any week of June than in one of December, would reason justly, and conformably to experience; but it is certain, that he may happen, in the event, to find himself mistaken. However, we may observe, that, in such a case, he would have no cause to complain of experience; because it commonly informs us beforehand of the uncertainty, by that contrariety of events, which we may learn from a diligent observation. All effects follow not with like certainty from their supposed causes. Some events are found, in all countries and all ages, to have been constantly conjoined together: Others are found to have been more variable, and sometimes to disappoint our expectations; so that, in our reasonings concerning matter of fact, there are all imaginable degrees of assurance, from the highest certainty to the lowest species of moral evidence.
A wise man, therefore, proportions his belief to the evidence. In such conclusions as are founded on an infallible experience, he expects the event with the last degree of assurance, and regards his past experience as a full proof of the future existence of that event. In other cases, he proceeds with more caution: He weighs the opposite experiments: He considers which side is supported by the greater number of experiments: to that side he inclines, with doubt and hesitation; and when at last he fixes his judgement, the evidence exceeds not what we properly call probability. All probability, then, supposes an opposition of experiments and observations, where the one side is found to overbalance the other, and to produce a degree of evidence, proportioned to the superiority. A hundred instances or experiments on one side, and fifty on another, afford a doubtful expectation of any event; though a hundred uniform experiments, with only one that is contradictory, reasonably beget a pretty strong degree of assurance. In all cases, we must balance the opposite experiments, where they are opposite, and deduct the smaller number from the greater, in order to know the exact force of the superior evidence.
88.To apply these principles to a particular instance; we may observe, that there is no species of reasoning more common, more useful, and even necessary to human life, than that which is derived from the testimony of men, and the reports of eye-witnesses and spectators. This species of reasoning, perhaps, one may deny to be founded on the relation of cause and effect. I shall not dispute about a word. It will be sufficient to observe that our assurance in any argument of this kind is derived from no other principle than our observation of the veracity of human testimony, and of the usual conformity of facts to the reports of witnesses. It being a general maxim, that no objects have any discoverable connexion together, and that all the inferences, which we can draw from one to another, are founded merely on our experience of their constant and regular conjunction; it is evident, that we ought not to make an exception to this maxim in favour of human testimony, whose connexion with any event seems, in itself, as little necessary as any other. Were not the memory tenacious to a certain degree, had not men commonly an inclination to truth and a principle of probity; were they not sensible to shame, when detected in a falsehood: Were not these, I say, discovered by experience to be qualities, inherent in human nature, we should never repose the least confidence in human testimony. A man delirious, or noted for falsehood and villany, has no manner of authority with us.
And as the evidence, derived from witnesses and human testimony, is founded on past experience, so it varies with the experience, and is regarded either as a proof or a probability, according as the conjunction between any particular kind of report and any kind of object has been found to be constant or variable. There are a number of circumstances to be taken into consideration in all judgements of this kind; and the ultimate standard, by which we determine all disputes, that may arise concerning them, is always derived from experience and observation. Where this experience is not entirely uniform on any side, it is attended with an unavoidable contrariety in our judgements, and with the same opposition and mutual destruction of argument as in every other kind of evidence. We frequently hesitate concerning the reports of others. We balance the opposite circumstances, which cause any doubt or uncertainty; and when we discover a superiority on any side, we incline to it; but still with a diminution of assurance, in proportion to the force of its antagonist.
89.This contrariety of evidence, in the present case, may be derived from several different causes; from the opposition of contrary testimony; from the character or number of the witnesses; from the manner of their delivering their testimony; or from the union of all these circumstances. We entertain a suspicion concerning any matter of fact, when the witnesses contradict each other; when they are but few, or of a doubtful character; when they have an interest in what they affirm; when they deliver their testimony with hesitation, or on the contrary, with too violent asseverations. There are many other particulars of the same kind, which may diminish or destroy the force of any argument, derived from human testimony.
Suppose, for instance, that the fact, which the testimony endeavours to establish, partakes of the extraordinary and the marvellous; in that case, the evidence, resulting from the testimony, admits of a diminution, greater or less, in proportion as the fact is more or less unusual. The reason why we place any credit in witnesses and historians, is not derived from any connexion, which we perceive a priori, between testimony and reality, but because we are accustomed to find a conformity between them. But when the fact attested is such a one as has seldom fallen under our observation, here is a contest of two opposite experiences; of which the one destroys the other, as far as its force goes, and the superior can only operate on the mind by the force, which remains. The very same principle of experience, which gives us a certain degree of assurance in the testimony of witnesses, gives us also, in this case, another degree of assurance against the fact, which they endeavour to establish; from which contradition there necessarily arises a counterpoize, and mutual destruction of belief and authority.
生成:
## The Fabric of Belief: Weaving Experience and Testimony in the Pursuit of Truth

The human mind, that restless explorer of the cosmos, finds itself perpetually engaged in a quest for truth.  Driven by an innate desire to comprehend the world and our place within it, we seek to pierce the veil of appearances and grasp the underlying reality that shapes our experiences. This pursuit, however noble, is fraught with challenges, for the path to truth is rarely straightforward. It winds through a labyrinth of evidence, both sensory and testimonial, demanding constant vigilance and a discerning mind to separate the wheat of genuine knowledge from the chaff of mere opinion or falsehood. 

At the heart of this epistemological endeavor lies the question of evidence: what constitutes reliable grounds for belief?  While the allure of absolute certainty might be tempting, experience teaches us that such a standard is often elusive, especially in the realm of human affairs. We are left, then, with the task of navigating a world painted in shades of gray, where probabilities, not certainties, guide our judgments. This, however, is not a cause for despair but rather an invitation to cultivate intellectual humility and a commitment to proportioning our beliefs to the strength of the available evidence.

Dr. Tillotson, in his treatise against the doctrine of transubstantiation, offers a compelling illustration of this principle. He argues that the evidence supporting the real presence of Christ in the Eucharist, resting primarily on the testimony of the apostles, pales in comparison to the immediacy and clarity of our sensory experience.  We see, taste, and feel bread and wine; to believe otherwise solely on the basis of secondhand accounts, however revered their source, would be to elevate belief above the dictates of reason.  

This line of reasoning, while presented in a theological context, unveils a fundamental truth applicable to the broader spectrum of human knowledge: experience, though not infallible, serves as our primary compass in navigating the world.  The warmth of the sun on our skin, the sting of a bee's venom, the taste of ripe fruit – these immediate encounters with reality form the bedrock of our understanding.  They provide the raw data against which we measure the veracity of claims and the reliability of testimony.

For it is through the conduit of testimony that we access a vast expanse of knowledge lying beyond the immediate reach of our senses.  History, science, culture – these intricate tapestries of human understanding are woven together by countless threads of individual accounts, passed down through generations, each contributing to the rich fabric of shared knowledge.  To dismiss testimony outright would be to sever ourselves from this collective inheritance, to confine ourselves to the narrow confines of our own limited experience.

Yet, the very nature of testimony, its indirectness, necessitates a degree of caution.  Unlike the immediacy of sensory data, testimony relies on the veracity and accuracy of the reporter, introducing an element of potential fallibility.  The wise individual, therefore, approaches testimony not with blind acceptance but with a discerning eye, evaluating its reliability based on a constellation of factors.

One such factor, and perhaps the most fundamental, lies in the observed regularities of human behavior.  Experience, that ever-present guide, reveals that humans, by and large, tend towards truth-telling. Language itself, that cornerstone of human interaction, derives its power from the shared assumption that communication aims at conveying truthful information.  Were deception the norm, the very foundations of language and social interaction would crumble.

This inherent tendency towards veracity is further reinforced by the workings of memory. While fallible, our minds possess a remarkable capacity for encoding and retrieving information, allowing us to recount past events with a reasonable degree of accuracy.  This reliability, however, is not absolute and can be influenced by a myriad of factors: the passage of time, the emotional salience of the event, the suggestibility of the individual, all contribute to the potential for distortion or error.

The discerning listener, therefore, must pay heed to these nuances, evaluating the credibility of testimony not as an all-or-nothing proposition but as existing along a spectrum of reliability. Testimony delivered by a known and trusted source, corroborated by independent accounts, and free from internal inconsistencies carries greater weight than an isolated, anonymous report rife with contradictions.  The manner in which testimony is delivered – with hesitation, conviction, or embellishment – also provides valuable clues to its veracity. 

This careful scrutiny becomes even more critical when encountering testimony that reports events deviating significantly from our established understanding of the world.  Extraordinary claims, as the adage goes, require extraordinary evidence.  This is not to say that we should dismiss such claims out of hand, but rather that our skepticism should be proportional to the degree to which the reported event challenges our existing framework of knowledge.

Consider, for instance, the claim of a miraculous healing.  Such an event, if true, would represent a violation of the laws of nature as we currently understand them.  Our skepticism, in this case, is not a sign of closed-mindedness but rather a reflection of the immense body of scientific knowledge that underpins our understanding of biology and medicine.  To accept such a claim based solely on anecdotal evidence would be to disregard the vast edifice of scientific knowledge painstakingly constructed over centuries.

This does not render belief in such events impossible, but it does raise the bar for evidence considerably.  The testimony of a single individual, even if seemingly sincere, is unlikely to outweigh the accumulated weight of scientific knowledge.  Multiple, independent eyewitnesses, preferably with expertise in relevant fields, providing detailed and consistent accounts, would be required to lend credence to such a claim.  Even then, alternative explanations, consistent with our current understanding of the world, would need to be rigorously explored.

This inherent tension between experience and testimony, between the familiar and the extraordinary, lies at the heart of many philosophical and theological debates.  When confronted with conflicting accounts, how are we to adjudicate?  Do we side with the weight of established knowledge, grounded in centuries of observation and experimentation, or do we grant credence to the possibility of events that challenge the very foundation of that knowledge?

The answer, as with most things philosophical, is not simple.  It requires a delicate balancing act, a willingness to entertain the possibility of the extraordinary without abandoning the anchor of reason and evidence.  It demands intellectual humility, recognizing the limits of our own understanding and the fallibility of human perception.

Ultimately, the pursuit of truth is an ongoing process, a journey of continual refinement and reevaluation.  It is a process that requires us to remain open to new information while holding fast to the principles of critical thinking and reasoned judgment.  For it is in the crucible of reasoned debate, where experience and testimony are carefully weighed and scrutinized, that we inch closer to a more complete and nuanced understanding of the world and our place within it.  The fabric of belief, woven from the threads of experience and testimony, is constantly being refined, strengthened by the inclusion of new knowledge, and made more resilient by the rigorous examination of its flaws. This ongoing process, though challenging, is the very essence of intellectual growth, leading us ever closer to the elusive yet alluring light of truth.
summary:
The passage discusses the reliability of evidence and testimony in reasoning, particularly in matters relating to religion and miraculous claims. The author references Dr. Tillotson's argument against the real presence of Christ in the Eucharist, highlighting that the evidence for religious beliefs, based on apostles' testimonies, is weaker than direct sensory evidence. The author then generalizes this principle to human testimony as a whole, arguing that our confidence in any testimony is based on our past experience with the veracity of human reports.

Key points include:
1. Experience is our primary guide in reasoning about facts, though it is not infallible.
2. A wise person should proportion their belief to the strength of evidence.
3. Human testimony is generally reliable because of observed regularities in truth-telling and memory but varies in strength based on circumstances.
4. Extraordinary claims (e.g., miracles) require stronger evidence, as they conflict with our usual experiences.
5. The credibility of testimony is affected by witness character, number, and the manner of testimony.
6. When testimony reports extraordinary events, there is a conflict of experiences, leading to a mutual weakening of belief.

Overall, the passage emphasizes that belief should be grounded in proportional evidence and that extraordinary claims require extraordinarily strong evidence due to their inherent improbability.
