原文:
Immanuel Kant is generally regarded as the greatest of the modern philosophers. Though he lived through the Seven Years War and the French Revolution, he never interrupted his teaching of philosophy at Königsberg in East Prussia. His most distinctive contribution was the invention of what he called the 'critical' philosophy, which, assuming as a datum that there is knowledge of various kinds, inquired how such knowledge comes to be possible, and deduced, from the answer to this inquiry, many metaphysical results as to the nature of the world. Whether these results were valid may well be doubted. But Kant undoubtedly deserves credit for two things: first, for having perceived that we have a priori knowledge which is not purely 'analytic', i.e. such that the opposite would be self-contradictory, and secondly, for having made evident the philosophical importance of the theory of knowledge.
Before the time of Kant, it was generally held that whatever knowledge was a priori must be 'analytic'. What this word means will be best illustrated by examples. If I say, 'A bald man is a man', 'A plane figure is a figure', 'A bad poet is a poet', I make a purely analytic judgement: the subject spoken about is given as having at least two properties, of which one is singled out to be asserted of it. Such propositions as the above are trivial, and would never be enunciated in real life except by an orator preparing the way for a piece of sophistry. They are called 'analytic' because the predicate is obtained by merely analysing the subject. Before the time of Kant it was thought that all judgements of which we could be certain a priori were of this kind: that in all of them there was a predicate which was only part of the subject of which it was asserted. If this were so, we should be involved in a definite contradiction if we attempted to deny anything that could be known a priori. 'A bald man is not bald' would assert and deny baldness of the same man, and would therefore contradict itself. Thus according to the philosophers before Kant, the law of contradiction, which asserts that nothing can at the same time have and not have a certain property, sufficed to establish the truth of all a priori knowledge.
Hume (1711-76), who preceded Kant, accepting the usual view as to what makes knowledge a priori, discovered that, in many cases which had previously been supposed analytic, and notably in the case of cause and effect, the connexion was really synthetic. Before Hume, rationalists at least had supposed that the effect could be logically deduced from the cause, if only we had sufficient knowledge. Hume argued—correctly, as would now be generally admitted—that this could not be done. Hence he inferred the far more doubtful proposition that nothing could be known a priori about the connexion of cause and effect. Kant, who had been educated in the rationalist tradition, was much perturbed by Hume's scepticism, and endeavoured to find an answer to it. He perceived that not only the connexion of cause and effect, but all the propositions of arithmetic and geometry, are 'synthetic', i.e. not analytic: in all these propositions, no analysis of the subject will reveal the predicate. His stock instance was the proposition 7 + 5 = 12. He pointed out, quite truly, that 7 and 5 have to be put together to give 12: the idea of 12 is not contained in them, nor even in the idea of adding them together. Thus he was led to the conclusion that all pure mathematics, though a priori, is synthetic; and this conclusion raised a new problem of which he endeavoured to find the solution.
The question which Kant put at the beginning of his philosophy, namely 'How is pure mathematics possible?' is an interesting and difficult one, to which every philosophy which is not purely sceptical must find some answer. The answer of the pure empiricists, that our mathematical knowledge is derived by induction from particular instances, we have already seen to be inadequate, for two reasons: first, that the validity of the inductive principle itself cannot be proved by induction; secondly, that the general propositions of mathematics, such as 'two and two always make four', can obviously be known with certainty by consideration of a single instance, and gain nothing by enumeration of other cases in which they have been found to be true. Thus our knowledge of the general propositions of mathematics (and the same applies to logic) must be accounted for otherwise than our (merely probable) knowledge of empirical generalizations such as 'all men are mortal'.
生成:
Immanuel Kant stands as a towering figure in the annals of modern philosophy, his legacy forever etched in the edifice of human thought. His philosophical system, meticulously constructed and profoundly influential, marked a radical departure from the prevailing schools of thought, ushering in a new era of critical inquiry and revolutionizing our understanding of knowledge itself. At the heart of Kant's philosophical project lay a profound question: How is knowledge possible? This seemingly simple query, posed with characteristic Kantian depth, became the driving force behind his groundbreaking work, leading him to develop his celebrated "critical philosophy."

Prior to Kant, the philosophical landscape was largely dominated by two opposing camps: rationalism and empiricism. Rationalists, championed by thinkers like Descartes and Leibniz, believed that reason itself was the primary source of knowledge. They argued that certain fundamental truths, such as the existence of God and the principles of logic and mathematics, could be apprehended through pure reason, independent of any sensory experience. Empiricists, on the other hand, led by figures like Locke and Hume, contended that all knowledge originated in sensory experience. They maintained that the mind, at birth, was a blank slate (tabula rasa) upon which experience imprinted itself, forming the basis of all our ideas and beliefs.

Kant, deeply influenced by both traditions, recognized the merits and limitations of each. He acknowledged the empiricists' emphasis on the role of experience in shaping our understanding of the world. However, he also recognized the limitations of pure empiricism, questioning how certain types of knowledge, particularly in mathematics and geometry, could be derived solely from sensory data. These disciplines seemed to possess a certainty and necessity that transcended the realm of mere empirical observation.

This led Kant to a groundbreaking insight: that there exists a priori knowledge, knowledge independent of experience, that is not merely analytic. Analytic propositions, as understood by Kant, are those in which the predicate is contained within the subject. For example, the statement "All bachelors are unmarried men" is analytic because the concept of being "unmarried" is already inherent in the definition of a "bachelor." The truth of such statements is self-evident and requires no appeal to experience.

Kant, however, posited the existence of synthetic a priori judgments, propositions whose truth is not self-evident from the concepts involved but is nonetheless known with certainty independent of experience. This challenged the prevailing philosophical dichotomy, which held that all a priori knowledge must be analytic. To illustrate this point, Kant turned to mathematics, particularly the proposition "7 + 5 = 12." This statement, he argued, is not analytic because the concept of "12" is not inherently contained within the concepts of "7," "5," or "+." It is a synthetic judgment, connecting distinct concepts in a way that is not immediately obvious from their definitions.

Yet, despite its synthetic nature, the truth of "7 + 5 = 12" is not dependent on empirical observation. We do not arrive at this truth by repeatedly adding seven apples to five apples and counting the result. Rather, its truth is apprehended a priori, through pure reason. This realization led Kant to formulate his central philosophical question: "How is pure mathematics possible?"

Kant's answer to this question formed the bedrock of his transcendental idealism. He argued that our ability to have certain knowledge of synthetic a priori propositions, such as those found in mathematics and geometry, stems from the very structure of our minds. The human mind, according to Kant, is not merely a passive recipient of sensory data but an active participant in structuring our experience. We possess innate categories of understanding, such as space, time, and causality, that are not derived from experience but are preconditions for having any experience at all. These categories act as lenses through which we perceive and organize the raw data of sensation, shaping it into the coherent world we experience.

Thus, mathematical knowledge, for Kant, is not a reflection of an objective reality existing independently of our minds but rather a product of the way our minds are structured. We can have certain knowledge of mathematical truths because they are grounded in the a priori forms of our intuition, particularly space and time. In this sense, Kant's philosophy represents a Copernican revolution in epistemology. Just as Copernicus shifted the center of the universe from the Earth to the Sun, Kant shifted the focus of knowledge from the external world to the structures of the human mind.

The implications of Kant's insights were far-reaching, reverberating throughout philosophy and beyond. His critical philosophy challenged the foundations of both rationalism and empiricism, offering a nuanced and sophisticated account of the nature of knowledge and its limits. Kant's emphasis on the active role of the mind in shaping experience paved the way for the development of idealism and phenomenology, while his exploration of the limits of reason laid the groundwork for postmodern thought.  

In conclusion, Kant's legacy lies in his relentless pursuit of the question: How is knowledge possible? His critical philosophy, with its emphasis on synthetic a priori judgments, transcendental idealism, and the structuring role of the mind, revolutionized our understanding of knowledge, reason, and the nature of reality itself.  His work continues to be a vital source of inspiration and debate, shaping philosophical discourse even today.
summary: The passage discusses Immanuel Kant's significant contributions to modern philosophy, particularly his development of 'critical' philosophy. Kant's work focused on understanding how various kinds of knowledge are possible and deducing metaphysical insights from this inquiry. He challenged the pre-existing notion that all a priori knowledge must be 'analytic' (where the predicate is inherent in the subject, making its denial self-contradictory), by demonstrating that some a priori knowledge is 'synthetic' (where the predicate is not inherent in the subject). Kant was influenced by David Hume, who had argued that knowledge of cause and effect, previously considered analytic, was actually synthetic. This revelation led Kant to conclude that synthetic a priori judgements exist, with mathematical and geometrical propositions (e.g., 7 + 5 = 12) serving as examples. Kant's philosophical question "How is pure mathematics possible?" sought to address how we can have certain knowledge of synthetic a priori propositions, challenging the empiricist view that mathematical knowledge comes from induction. The passage highlights the significance of Kant's insight into the nature of knowledge and its impact on philosophy.

原文:
Immanuel Kant is generally regarded as the greatest of the modern philosophers. Though he lived through the Seven Years War and the French Revolution, he never interrupted his teaching of philosophy at Königsberg in East Prussia. His most distinctive contribution was the invention of what he called the 'critical' philosophy, which, assuming as a datum that there is knowledge of various kinds, inquired how such knowledge comes to be possible, and deduced, from the answer to this inquiry, many metaphysical results as to the nature of the world. Whether these results were valid may well be doubted. But Kant undoubtedly deserves credit for two things: first, for having perceived that we have a priori knowledge which is not purely 'analytic', i.e. such that the opposite would be self-contradictory, and secondly, for having made evident the philosophical importance of the theory of knowledge.
Before the time of Kant, it was generally held that whatever knowledge was a priori must be 'analytic'. What this word means will be best illustrated by examples. If I say, 'A bald man is a man', 'A plane figure is a figure', 'A bad poet is a poet', I make a purely analytic judgement: the subject spoken about is given as having at least two properties, of which one is singled out to be asserted of it. Such propositions as the above are trivial, and would never be enunciated in real life except by an orator preparing the way for a piece of sophistry. They are called 'analytic' because the predicate is obtained by merely analysing the subject. Before the time of Kant it was thought that all judgements of which we could be certain a priori were of this kind: that in all of them there was a predicate which was only part of the subject of which it was asserted. If this were so, we should be involved in a definite contradiction if we attempted to deny anything that could be known a priori. 'A bald man is not bald' would assert and deny baldness of the same man, and would therefore contradict itself. Thus according to the philosophers before Kant, the law of contradiction, which asserts that nothing can at the same time have and not have a certain property, sufficed to establish the truth of all a priori knowledge.
Hume (1711-76), who preceded Kant, accepting the usual view as to what makes knowledge a priori, discovered that, in many cases which had previously been supposed analytic, and notably in the case of cause and effect, the connexion was really synthetic. Before Hume, rationalists at least had supposed that the effect could be logically deduced from the cause, if only we had sufficient knowledge. Hume argued—correctly, as would now be generally admitted—that this could not be done. Hence he inferred the far more doubtful proposition that nothing could be known a priori about the connexion of cause and effect. Kant, who had been educated in the rationalist tradition, was much perturbed by Hume's scepticism, and endeavoured to find an answer to it. He perceived that not only the connexion of cause and effect, but all the propositions of arithmetic and geometry, are 'synthetic', i.e. not analytic: in all these propositions, no analysis of the subject will reveal the predicate. His stock instance was the proposition 7 + 5 = 12. He pointed out, quite truly, that 7 and 5 have to be put together to give 12: the idea of 13 is not contained in them, nor even in the idea of adding them together. Thus he was led to the conclusion that all pure mathematics, though a priori, is synthetic; and this conclusion raised a new problem of which he endeavoured to find the solution.
The question which Kant put at the beginning of his philosophy, namely 'How is pure mathematics possible?' is an interesting and difficult one, to which every philosophy which is not purely sceptical must find some answer. The answer of the pure empiricists, that our mathematical knowledge is derived by induction from particular instances, we have already seen to be inadequate, for two reasons: first, that the validity of the inductive principle itself cannot be proved by induction; secondly, that the general propositions of mathematics, such as 'two and two always make four', can obviously be known with certainty by consideration of a single instance, and gain nothing by enumeration of other cases in which they have been found to be true. Thus our knowledge of the general propositions of mathematics (and the same applies to logic) must be accounted for otherwise than our (merely probable) knowledge of empirical generalizations such as 'all men are mortal'.

原文:
What, then, is the rightful limit to the sovereignty of the individual over himself? Where does the authority of society begin? How much of human life should be assigned to individuality, and how much to society?
Each will receive its proper share, if each has that which more particularly concerns it. To individuality should belong the part of life in which it is chiefly the individual that is interested; to society, the part which chiefly interests society.
Though society is not founded on a contract, and though no good purpose is answered by inventing a contract in order to deduce social obligations from it, every one who receives the protection of society owes a return for the benefit, and the fact of living in society renders it indispensable that each should be bound to[Pg 141] observe a certain line of conduct towards the rest. This conduct consists, first, in not injuring the interests of one another; or rather certain interests which, either by express legal provision or by tacit understanding, ought to be considered as rights; and secondly, in each person's bearing his share (to be fixed on some equitable principle) of the labours and sacrifices incurred for defending the society or its members from injury and molestation. These conditions society is justified in enforcing, at all costs to those who endeavour to withhold fulfilment. Nor is this all that society may do. The acts of an individual may be hurtful to others, or wanting in due consideration for their welfare, without going the length of violating any of their constituted rights. The offender may then be justly punished by opinion though not by law. As soon as any part of a person's conduct affects prejudicially the interests of others, society has jurisdiction over it, and the question whether the general welfare will or will not be promoted by interfering with it, becomes open to discussion. But there is no room for entertaining any such question when a person's conduct affects the interests of no persons besides himself, or needs not affect them unless they like (all the persons concerned being of full age, and[Pg 142] the ordinary amount of understanding). In all such cases there should be perfect freedom, legal and social, to do the action and stand the consequences.
It would be a great misunderstanding of this doctrine, to suppose that it is one of selfish indifference, which pretends that human beings have no business with each other's conduct in life, and that they should not concern themselves about the well-doing or well-being of one another, unless their own interest is involved. Instead of any diminution, there is need of a great increase of disinterested exertion to promote the good of others. But disinterested benevolence can find other instruments to persuade people to their good, than whips and scourges, either of the literal or the metaphorical sort. I am the last person to undervalue the self-regarding virtues; they are only second in importance, if even second, to the social. It is equally the business of education to cultivate both. But even education works by conviction and persuasion as well as by compulsion, and it is by the former only that, when the period of education is past, the self-regarding virtues should be inculcated. Human beings owe to each other help to distinguish the better from the worse, and encouragement to choose the[Pg 143] former and avoid the latter. They should be for ever stimulating each other to increased exercise of their higher faculties, and increased direction of their feelings and aims towards wise instead of foolish, elevating instead of degrading, objects and contemplations. But neither one person, nor any number of persons, is warranted in saying to another human creature of ripe years, that he shall not do with his life for his own benefit what he chooses to do with it. He is the person most interested in his own well-being: the interest which any other person, except in cases of strong personal attachment, can have in it, is trifling, compared with that which he himself has; the interest which society has in him individually (except as to his conduct to others) is fractional, and altogether indirect: while, with respect to his own feelings and circumstances, the most ordinary man or woman has means of knowledge immeasurably surpassing those that can be possessed by any one else. The interference of society to overrule his judgment and purposes in what only regards himself, must be grounded on general presumptions; which may be altogether wrong, and even if right, are as likely as not to be misapplied to individual cases, by persons no better acquainted with the circumstances of such[Pg 144] cases than those are who look at them merely from without. In this department, therefore, of human affairs, Individuality has its proper field of action. In the conduct of human beings towards one another, it is necessary that general rules should for the most part be observed, in order that people may know what they have to expect; but in each person's own concerns, his individual spontaneity is entitled to free exercise. Considerations to aid his judgment, exhortations to strengthen his will, may be offered to him, even obtruded on him, by others; but he himself is the final judge. All errors which he is likely to commit against advice and warning, are far outweighed by the evil of allowing others to constrain him to what they deem his good.
I do not mean that the feelings with which a person is regarded by others, ought not to be in any way affected by his self-regarding qualities or deficiencies. This is neither possible nor desirable. If he is eminent in any of the qualities which conduce to his own good, he is, so far, a proper object of admiration. He is so much the nearer to the ideal perfection of human nature. If he is grossly deficient in those qualities, a sentiment the opposite of admiration will follow. There is a degree of folly, and a degree of what may be[Pg 145] called (though the phrase is not unobjectionable) lowness or depravation of taste, which, though it cannot justify doing harm to the person who manifests it, renders him necessarily and properly a subject of distaste, or, in extreme cases, even of contempt: a person could not have the opposite qualities in due strength without entertaining these feelings. Though doing no wrong to any one, a person may so act as to compel us to judge him, and feel to him, as a fool, or as a being of an inferior order: and since this judgment and feeling are a fact which he would prefer to avoid, it is doing him a service to warn him of it beforehand, as of any other disagreeable consequence to which he exposes himself. It would be well, indeed, if this good office were much more freely rendered than the common notions of politeness at present permit, and if one person could honestly point out to another that he thinks him in fault, without being considered unmannerly or presuming. We have a right, also, in various ways, to act upon our unfavourable opinion of any one, not to the oppression of his individuality, but in the exercise of ours. We are not bound, for example, to seek his society; we have a right to avoid it (though not to parade the avoidance), for we have a right to choose the society most acceptable to us. We[Pg 146] have a right, and it may be our duty, to caution others against him, if we think his example or conversation likely to have a pernicious effect on those with whom he associates. We may give others a preference over him in optional good offices, except those which tend to his improvement. In these various modes a person may suffer very severe penalties at the hands of others, for faults which directly concern only himself; but he suffers these penalties only in so far as they are the natural, and, as it were, the spontaneous consequences of the faults themselves, not because they are purposely inflicted on him for the sake of punishment. A person who shows rashness, obstinacy, self-conceit—who cannot live within moderate means—who cannot restrain himself from hurtful indulgences—who pursues animal pleasures at the expense of those of feeling and intellect—must expect to be lowered in the opinion of others, and to have a less share of their favourable sentiments; but of this he has no right to complain, unless he has merited their favour by special excellence in his social relations, and has thus established a title to their good offices, which is not affected by his demerits towards himself.
生成:
## The Sovereign Self and the Social Fabric: A Discourse on Individual Liberty and Collective Responsibility

The human experience is perpetually caught in the tension between the poles of individual sovereignty and societal authority. We are at once independent beings, free to navigate the world according to our own internal compass, and interconnected nodes in a vast social tapestry, bound by invisible threads of shared responsibility. This inherent duality necessitates a delicate balancing act, a constant negotiation between the inviolable realm of personal freedom and the legitimate demands of the collective good. This essay seeks to delineate the contours of this delicate balance, exploring the boundaries of individual autonomy and illuminating the justifiable limits of societal intervention in personal conduct.

At the heart of this discourse lies the fundamental principle of self-ownership. Each individual is the rightful sovereign over their own thoughts, beliefs, and actions, insofar as these remain confined to the sphere of their own being. This principle recognizes the inherent dignity and autonomy of every individual, acknowledging their capacity for self-determination and their right to pursue their own vision of the good life, however idiosyncratic it may seem to others. This realm of personal sovereignty encompasses a vast expanse of human experience, including our personal beliefs, values, and aspirations; our choices regarding relationships, lifestyle, and self-expression; and our pursuit of happiness and fulfillment within the framework of our own values.

However, the human experience does not unfold in a vacuum. We are social creatures, living in communities where our actions inevitably ripple outwards, impacting the lives of those around us. This interconnectedness necessitates a recognition of our social responsibilities, a set of obligations that arise from our shared humanity and our interdependence within the social fabric. These obligations include, but are not limited to, respecting the rights and liberties of others, refraining from actions that cause harm, and contributing to the common good in ways that align with our capabilities.

This recognition of social responsibility forms the basis for justifiable societal intervention in individual conduct. When the actions of an individual infringe upon the well-being of others, transgressing the boundaries of their individual sovereignty, society has a legitimate interest in intervening. This intervention can take various forms, ranging from legal sanctions to social disapproval, depending on the severity of the transgression and the norms of the particular society. The guiding principle, however, remains consistent: the protection of individual rights and the preservation of the common good.

It is crucial to emphasize that societal intervention must be exercised with utmost restraint, carefully calibrated to address only those actions that demonstrably harm others or undermine the social fabric. The mere fact that an individual's choices or lifestyle deviate from societal norms or offend prevailing sensibilities does not constitute sufficient grounds for intervention. As long as an individual's actions remain confined to the sphere of their own being, causing no harm to others, society has no justifiable claim to interfere. To do so would be to encroach upon the sacred realm of individual liberty, stifling the very diversity of thought and experience that enriches the human tapestry.

This principle of minimal intervention extends to the realm of personal vices and moral failings. Society may rightfully condemn behaviors it deems harmful or unethical, even if those behaviors do not directly infringe upon the rights of others. Such condemnation, however, should manifest as natural consequences – social disapproval, loss of reputation, or diminished social standing – rather than as deliberately imposed punishments. Education and persuasion, rather than coercion, should be the primary tools for encouraging self-regarding virtues. While individuals have a responsibility to strive towards ethical conduct, ultimately, the responsibility for their choices and the consequences that flow from them rests with the individual.

The question then arises: how do we navigate this complex terrain, discerning the boundaries between legitimate societal concern and unwarranted intrusion? The answer lies in a nuanced understanding of harm and its various forms. Physical harm, such as violence or theft, represents the most readily acknowledged justification for societal intervention. However, harm can also manifest in less tangible forms, such as emotional distress, reputational damage, or economic disadvantage.

Determining the legitimacy of societal intervention in these less clear-cut cases requires careful consideration of several factors. Firstly, the severity of the potential harm must be weighed against the degree of intrusion on individual liberty. Secondly, the intent behind the action should be considered; unintentional harm carries a different weight than deliberate malice. Finally, cultural context plays a crucial role; what constitutes acceptable behavior varies across societies and evolves over time.

In navigating these complexities, it is essential to remember that the ultimate goal is not to create a society devoid of conflict or disagreement. Such a utopia is not only impossible but also undesirable. Instead, the aim is to foster a society where individuals are free to pursue their own vision of the good life while recognizing and upholding their responsibilities to the community. This delicate balance requires constant vigilance, open dialogue, and a willingness to engage with diverse perspectives, always striving to err on the side of liberty wherever possible.

In conclusion, the relationship between individual freedom and societal responsibility is not a zero-sum game. It is a delicate dance, a continuous negotiation between seemingly opposing forces. By acknowledging the inherent dignity and autonomy of each individual while recognizing our interconnectedness and shared responsibilities, we can strive to create a society that honors both the sovereign self and the social fabric upon which we all depend. This delicate balance, achieved through thoughtful deliberation and a commitment to liberty, is the cornerstone of a just and flourishing society.
summary:
The passage explores the limits of individual sovereignty versus societal authority and delineates when society can justifiably intervene in personal conduct. It posits that individuality should govern personal concerns, while society can exert authority over actions that impact others. Individuals owe certain behaviors to society, including not harming others and contributing equitably to communal defenses. Society can impose penalties through public opinion for actions that affect others' welfare, even if those actions don’t violate explicit rights.

The author emphasizes that personal conduct affecting only oneself should be free from societal interference. Education and persuasion, rather than compulsion, should encourage self-regarding virtues. While society may judge and react unfavorably to personal failings, these reactions should be natural consequences rather than purposefully punitive measures. The author asserts that individuals should be free to make decisions about their lives, as they are most invested in their well-being.

In summary, the passage underscores the balance between personal freedom and societal obligations, advocating for minimal societal intervention in purely personal matters while supporting societal influence and judgment in interactions affecting the collective well-being.

Each will receive its proper share, if each has that which more particularly concerns it. To individuality should belong the part of life in which it is chiefly the individual that is interested; to society, the part which chiefly interests society.

There is a degree of folly, and a degree of what may be[Pg 145] called (though the phrase is not unobjectionable) lowness or depravation of taste, which, though it cannot justify doing harm to the person who manifests it, renders him necessarily and properly a subject of distaste, or, in extreme cases, even of contempt: a person could not have the opposite qualities in due strength without entertaining these feelings. Though doing no wrong to any one, a person may so act as to compel us to judge him, and feel to him, as a fool, or as a being of an inferior order: and since this judgment and feeling are a fact which he would prefer to avoid, it is doing him a service to warn him of it beforehand, as of any other disagreeable consequence to which he exposes himself. It would be well, indeed, if this good office were much more freely rendered than the common notions of politeness at present permit, and if one person could honestly point out to another that he thinks him in fault, without being considered unmannerly or presuming. We have a right, also, in various ways, to act upon our unfavourable opinion of any one, not to the oppression of his individuality, but in the exercise of ours. We are not bound, for example, to seek his society; we have a right to avoid it (though not to parade the avoidance), for we have a right to choose the society most acceptable to us. We[Pg 147] have a right, and it may be our duty, to caution others against him, if we think his example or conversation likely to have a pernicious effect on those with whom he associates. We may give others a preference over him in optional good offices, except those which tend to his improvement. In these various modes a person may suffer very severe penalties at the hands of others, for faults which directly concern only himself; but he suffers these penalties only in so far as they are the natural, and, as it were, the spontaneous consequences of the faults themselves, not because they are purposely inflicted on him for the sake of punishment. A person who shows rashness, obstinacy, self-conceit—who cannot live within moderate means—who cannot restrain himself from hurtful indulgences—who pursues animal pleasures at the expense of those of feeling and intellect—must expect to be lowered in the opinion of others, and to have a less share of their favourable sentiments; but of this he has no right to complain, unless he has merited their favour by special excellence in his social relations, and has thus established a title to their good offices, which is not affected by his demerits towards himself.
summary:
The passage explores the limits of individual sovereignty versus societal authority and delineates when society can justifiably intervene in personal conduct. It posits that individuality should govern personal concerns, while society can exert authority over actions that impact others. Individuals owe certain behaviors to society, including not harming others and contributing equitably to communal defenses. Society can impose penalties through public opinion for actions that affect others' welfare, even if those actions don’t violate explicit rights.

The author emphasizes that personal conduct affecting only oneself should be free from societal interference. Education and persuasion, rather than compulsion, should encourage self-regarding virtues. While society may judge and react unfavorably to personal failings, these reactions should be natural consequences rather than purposefully punitive measures. The author asserts that individuals should be free to make decisions about their lives, as they are most invested in their well-being.

In summary, the passage underscores the balance between personal freedom and societal obligations, advocating for minimal societal intervention in purely personal matters while supporting societal influence and judgment in interactions affecting the collective well-being.

原文:
What, then, is the rightful limit to the sovereignty of the individual over himself? Where does the authority of society begin? How much of human life should be assigned to individuality, and how much to society?
Each will receive its proper share, if each has that which more particularly concerns it. To individuality should belong the part of life in which it is chiefly the individual that is interested; to society, the part which chiefly interests society.
Though society is not founded on a contract, and though no good purpose is answered by inventing a contract in order to deduce social obligations from it, every one who receives the protection of society owes a return for the benefit, and the fact of living in society renders it indispensable that each should be bound to[Pg 141] observe a certain line of conduct towards the rest. This conduct consists, first, in not injuring the interests of one another; or rather certain interests which, either by express legal provision or by tacit understanding, ought to be considered as rights; and secondly, in each person's bearing his share (to be fixed on some equitable principle) of the labours and sacrifices incurred for defending the society or its members from injury and molestation. These conditions society is justified in enforcing, at all costs to those who endeavour to withhold fulfilment. Nor is this all that society may do. The acts of an individual may be hurtful to others, or wanting in due consideration for their welfare, without going the length of violating any of their constituted rights. The offender may then be justly punished by opinion though not by law. As soon as any part of a person's conduct affects prejudicially the interests of others, society has jurisdiction over it, and the question whether the general welfare will or will not be promoted by interfering with it, becomes open to discussion. But there is no room for entertaining any such question when a person's conduct affects the interests of no persons besides himself, or needs not affect them unless they like (all the persons concerned being of full age, and[Pg 142] the ordinary amount of understanding). In all such cases there should be perfect freedom, legal and social, to do the action and stand the consequences.
It would be a great misunderstanding of this doctrine, to suppose that it is one of selfish indifference, which pretends that human beings have no business with each other's conduct in life, and that they should not concern themselves about the well-doing or well-being of one another, unless their own interest is involved. Instead of any diminution, there is need of a great increase of disinterested exertion to promote the good of others. But disinterested benevolence can find other instruments to persuade people to their good, than whips and scourges, either of the literal or the metaphorical sort. I am the last person to undervalue the self-regarding virtues; they are only second in importance, if even second, to the social. It is equally the business of education to cultivate both. But even education works by conviction and persuasion as well as by compulsion, and it is by the former only that, when the period of education is past, the self-regarding virtues should be inculcated. Human beings owe to each other help to distinguish the better from the worse, and encouragement to choose the[Pg 143] former and avoid the latter. They should be for ever stimulating each other to increased exercise of their higher faculties, and increased direction of their feelings and aims towards wise instead of foolish, elevating instead of degrading, objects and contemplations. But neither one person, nor any number of persons, is warranted in saying to another human creature of ripe years, that he shall not do with his life for his own benefit what he chooses to do with it. He is the person most interested in his own well-being: the interest which any other person, except in cases of strong personal attachment, can have in it, is trifling, compared with that which he himself has; the interest which society has in him individually (except as to his conduct to others) is fractional, and altogether indirect: while, with respect to his own feelings and circumstances, the most ordinary man or woman has means of knowledge immeasurably surpassing those that can be possessed by any one else. The interference of society to overrule his judgment and purposes in what only regards himself, must be grounded on general presumptions; which may be altogether wrong, and even if right, are as likely as not to be misapplied to individual cases, by persons no better acquainted with the circumstances of such[Pg 144] cases than those are who look at them merely from without. In this department, therefore, of human affairs, Individuality has its proper field of action. In the conduct of human beings towards one another, it is necessary that general rules should for the most part be observed, in order that people may know what they have to expect; but in each person's own concerns, his individual spontaneity is entitled to free exercise. Considerations to aid his judgment, exhortations to strengthen his will, may be offered to him, even obtruded on him, by others; but he himself is the final judge. All errors which he is likely to commit against advice and warning, are far outweighed by the evil of allowing others to constrain him to what they deem his good.
I do not mean that the feelings with which a person is regarded by others, ought not to be in any way affected by his self-regarding qualities or deficiencies. This is neither possible nor desirable. If he is eminent in any of the qualities which conduce to his own good, he is, so far, a proper object of admiration. He is so much the nearer to the ideal perfection of human nature. If he is grossly deficient in those qualities, a sentiment the opposite of admiration will follow. There is a degree of folly, and a degree of what may be[Pg 145] called (though the phrase is not unobjectionable) lowness or depravation of taste, which, though it cannot justify doing harm to the person who manifests it, renders him necessarily and properly a subject of distaste, or, in extreme cases, even of contempt: a person could not have the opposite qualities in due strength without entertaining these feelings. Though doing no wrong to any one, a person may so act as to compel us to judge him, and feel to him, as a fool, or as a being of an inferior order: and since this judgment and feeling are a fact which he would prefer to avoid, it is doing him a service to warn him of it beforehand, as of any other disagreeable consequence to which he exposes himself. It would be well, indeed, if this good office were much more freely rendered than the common notions of politeness at present permit, and if one person could honestly point out to another that he thinks him in fault, without being considered unmannerly or presuming. We have a right, also, in various ways, to act upon our unfavourable opinion of any one, not to the oppression of his individuality, but in the exercise of ours. We are not bound, for example, to seek his society; we have a right to avoid it (though not to parade the avoidance), for we have a right to choose the society most acceptable to us. We[Pg 148] have a right, and it may be our duty, to caution others against him, if we think his example or conversation likely to have a pernicious effect on those with whom he associates. We may give others a preference over him in optional good offices, except those which tend to his improvement. In these various modes a person may suffer very severe penalties at the hands of others, for faults which directly concern only himself; but he suffers these penalties only in so far as they are the natural, and, as it were, the spontaneous consequences of the faults themselves, not because they are purposely inflicted on him for the sake of punishment. A person who shows rashness, obstinacy, self-conceit—who cannot live within moderate means—who cannot restrain himself from hurtful indulgences—who pursues animal pleasures at the expense of those of feeling and intellect—must expect to be lowered in the opinion of others, and to have a less share of their favourable sentiments; but of this he has no right to complain, unless he has merited their favour by special excellence in his social relations, and has thus established a title to their good offices, which is not affected by his demerits towards himself.

原文:
These are the Rights, which make the Essence of Soveraignty; and which are the markes, whereby a man may discern in what Man, or Assembly of men, the Soveraign Power is placed, and resideth. For these are incommunicable, and inseparable. The Power to coyn Mony; to dispose of the estate and persons of Infant heires; to have praeemption in Markets; and all other Statute Praerogatives, may be transferred by the Soveraign; and yet the Power to protect his Subject be retained. But if he transferre the Militia, he retains the Judicature in vain, for want of execution of the Lawes; Or if he grant away the Power of raising Mony; the Militia is in vain: or if he give away the government of doctrines, men will be frighted into rebellion with the feare of Spirits. And so if we consider any one of the said Rights, we shall presently see, that the holding of all the rest, will produce no effect, in the conservation of Peace and Justice, the end for which all Common-wealths are Instituted. And this division is it, whereof it is said, “A kingdome divided in it selfe cannot stand:” For unlesse this division precede, division into opposite Armies can never happen. If there had not first been an opinion received of the greatest part of England, that these Powers were divided between the King, and the Lords, and the House of Commons, the people had never been divided, and fallen into this Civill Warre; first between those that disagreed in Politiques; and after between the Dissenters about the liberty of Religion; which have so instructed men in this point of Soveraign Right, that there be few now (in England,) that do not see, that these Rights are inseparable, and will be so generally acknowledged, at the next return of Peace; and so continue, till their miseries are forgotten; and no longer, except the vulgar be better taught than they have hetherto been.
And Can By No Grant Passe Away Without Direct Renouncing Of The Soveraign Power
And because they are essentiall and inseparable Rights, it follows necessarily, that in whatsoever, words any of them seem to be granted away, yet if the Soveraign Power it selfe be not in direct termes renounced, and the name of Soveraign no more given by the Grantees to him that Grants them, the Grant is voyd: for when he has granted all he can, if we grant back the Soveraignty, all is restored, as inseparably annexed thereunto.
The Power And Honour Of Subjects Vanisheth In The Presence Of The Power Soveraign
This great Authority being indivisible, and inseparably annexed to the Soveraignty, there is little ground for the opinion of them, that say of Soveraign Kings, though they be Singulis Majores, of greater Power than every one of their Subjects, yet they be Universis Minores, of lesse power than them all together. For if by All Together, they mean not the collective body as one person, then All Together, and Every One, signifie the same; and the speech is absurd. But if by All Together, they understand them as one Person (which person the Soveraign bears,) then the power of all together, is the same with the Soveraigns power; and so again the speech is absurd; which absurdity they see well enough, when the Soveraignty is in an Assembly of the people; but in a Monarch they see it not; and yet the power of Soveraignty is the same in whomsoever it be placed.
And as the Power, so also the Honour of the Soveraign, ought to be greater, than that of any, or all the Subjects. For in the Soveraignty is the fountain of Honour. The dignities of Lord, Earle, Duke, and Prince are his Creatures. As in the presence of the Master, the Servants are equall, and without any honour at all; So are the Subjects, in the presence of the Soveraign. And though they shine some more, some lesse, when they are out of his sight; yet in his presence, they shine no more than the Starres in presence of the Sun.
生成:
## The Indivisible Heart of Sovereignty

The concept of sovereignty, like an ancient oak, stands as a formidable presence in the landscape of political philosophy. Its roots run deep, anchoring the very structure of the state, its branches reaching towards the heavens, symbolizing the ultimate authority within a defined territory. Yet, the nature of this power, its inherent unity and indivisibility, has been a subject of much debate and scrutiny. To dissect sovereignty is to delve into the heart of governance, to understand the source of its strength and the potential pitfalls that lie in its division.

At the core of sovereignty lies a set of inherent rights and powers, inseparable and indispensable to its very existence. These are not mere privileges bestowed upon a ruler but fundamental aspects of what it means to be sovereign. Just as the heart cannot be separated from the body without extinguishing life, so too can these core powers not be severed from sovereignty without rendering it impotent, a hollow shell of authority. 

While the sovereign may choose to delegate specific tasks – the minting of coinage, the regulation of markets, the administration of justice – these remain mere extensions of the sovereign will, subject to revocation and amendment. The core powers, however, represent the very essence of sovereignty, the muscles that propel its actions and ensure its survival. The command of the military, the power to raise funds for the common good, and the control over doctrines and ideologies that shape the state's identity – these are not mere branches that can be pruned without consequence. They are the trunk of the oak, the central pillars upon which the entire edifice of the state rests.

To divide these core powers is to invite chaos and undermine the very purpose of sovereignty. When the authority to command the military is fractured, when multiple entities vie for the power of the purse, when conflicting ideologies wrestle for dominance within the state, the result is not a harmonious balance of power, but a breeding ground for discord and paralysis. The state, instead of functioning as a unified entity, becomes a battleground for competing factions, each claiming legitimacy and striving for supremacy.

The history of England stands as a stark testament to the perils of divided sovereignty. The English Civil War, a period of immense upheaval and bloodshed, was ignited by the very act of splitting the sovereign power. The Crown and Parliament, once partners in governance, became locked in a deadly struggle for supremacy, their conflict tearing the fabric of the nation. This tragic chapter serves as a cautionary tale, a stark reminder that sovereignty, like a sword, is most effective when wielded with a single, unwavering hand.

Furthermore, the inherent supremacy of the sovereign must be acknowledged and respected. The sovereign, as the embodiment of the state, occupies a position of unparalleled honor and authority.  This is not to suggest an absolute monarchy or a tyrannical regime, but rather a recognition of the necessary hierarchy within a well-ordered commonwealth.  

The sovereign's authority exceeds that of any individual or collective body within the state because it is from the sovereign that all other honors and ranks derive their legitimacy.  Just as the sun stands as the central celestial body within its system, so too does the sovereign represent the ultimate source of power and order within the state.  To challenge this hierarchy, to question the supremacy of the sovereign's position, is to invite instability and weaken the bonds that hold the commonwealth together.

This is not to say that the sovereign should rule with an iron fist, deaf to the voices of the people.  A wise and just sovereign understands that true strength lies not in brute force but in the consent of the governed.  However, this consent, this willingness to be governed, is predicated on the understanding that the sovereign stands as the ultimate arbiter, the final authority in matters of state.  

The sovereign's power, while immense, is not wielded for personal gain but for the common good, the preservation of order, and the pursuit of the collective well-being of the state.  The sovereign's prestige, far from being a tool of vanity, serves as a focal point for national unity, a symbol of collective identity and shared destiny.

In conclusion, the indivisibility of sovereignty stands as a cornerstone of a stable and effective state.  To attempt to dissect its core powers, to dilute its authority, is to invite instability and weaken the very fabric of governance.  The sovereign, as the embodiment of the state, must hold supreme authority, not for personal aggrandizement, but for the preservation of order and the pursuit of the common good.  It is in the unity and unwavering strength of the sovereign that the true potential of the state can be realized, and the well-being of its people secured.
summary: The passage discusses the nature and indivisibility of sovereign power. It argues that certain rights and powers are essential and cannot be separated from sovereignty without effectively nullifying the concept of sovereign authority. While a sovereign can delegate specific tasks or prerogatives (like coining money or handling markets), core powers such as the military, raising money, and controlling doctrines cannot be divided without causing conflict and diminishing the effectiveness of governance. The passage underscores that sovereignty is fundamentally tied to the unity and stability of the state, using the example of England's civil war as a cautionary tale about divided sovereignty. It further states that the honor and authority of the sovereign exceed those of any individual or collective subjects because the sovereign is the source of all honors and ranks within the state. The sovereign's power and prestige should be unchallenged and supreme to maintain order and focus within the commonwealth.

原文:
No moral Principles so clear and so generally received as the forementioned speculative Maxims.
If those speculative Maxims, whereof we discoursed in the foregoing chapter, have not an actual universal assent from all mankind, as we there proved, it is much more visible concerning PRACTICAL Principles, that they come short of an universal reception: and I think it will be hard to instance any one moral rule which can pretend to so general and ready an assent as, “What is, is”; or to be so manifest a truth as this, that “It is impossible for the same thing to be and not to be.” Whereby it is evident that they are further removed from a title to be innate; and the doubt of their being native impressions on the mind is stronger against those moral principles than the other. Not that it brings their truth at all in question. They are equally true, though not equally evident. Those speculative maxims carry their own evidence with them: but moral principles require reasoning and discourse, and some exercise of the mind, to discover the certainty of their truth. They lie not open as natural characters engraved on the mind; which, if any such were, they must needs be visible by themselves, and by their own light be certain and known to everybody. But this is no derogation to their truth and certainty; no more than it is to the truth or certainty of the three angles of a triangle being equal to two right ones because it is not so evident as “the whole is bigger than a part,” nor so apt to be assented to at first hearing. It may suffice that these moral rules are capable of demonstration: and therefore it is our own faults if we come not to a certain knowledge of them. But the ignorance wherein many men are of them, and the slowness of assent wherewith others receive them, are manifest proofs that they are not innate, and such as offer themselves to their view without searching.
Faith and Justice not owned as Principles by all Men.
Whether there be any such moral principles, wherein all men do agree, I appeal to any who have been but moderately conversant in the history of mankind, and looked abroad beyond the smoke of their own chimneys. Where is that practical truth that is universally received, without doubt or question, as it must be if innate? JUSTICE, and keeping of contracts, is that which most men seem to agree in. This is a principle which is thought to extend itself to the dens of thieves, and the confederacies of the greatest villains; and they who have gone furthest towards the putting off of humanity itself, keep faith and rules of justice one with another. I grant that outlaws themselves do this one amongst another: but it is without receiving these as the innate laws of nature. They practise them as rules of convenience within their own communities: but it is impossible to conceive that he embraces justice as a practical principle who acts fairly with his fellow-highwayman, and at the same time plunders or kills the next honest man he meets with. Justice and truth are the common ties of society; and therefore even outlaws and robbers, who break with all the world besides, must keep faith and rules of equity amongst themselves; or else they cannot hold together. But will any one say, that those that live by fraud or rapine have innate principles of truth and justice which they allow and assent to?
Objection: though Men deny them in their Practice, yet they admit them in their Thoughts answered.
Perhaps it will be urged, that the tacit assent of their minds agrees to what their practice contradicts. I answer, first, I have always thought the actions of men the best interpreters of their thoughts. But, since it is certain that most men’s practices, and some men’s open professions, have either questioned or denied these principles, it is impossible to establish an universal consent, (though we should look for it only amongst grown men,) without which it is impossible to conclude them innate. Secondly, it is very strange and unreasonable to suppose innate practical principles, that terminate only in contemplation. Practical principles, derived from nature, are there for operation, and must produce conformity of action, not barely speculative assent to their truth, or else they are in vain distinguished from speculative maxims. Nature, I confess, has put into man a desire of happiness and an aversion to misery: these indeed are innate practical principles which (as practical principles ought) DO continue constantly to operate and influence all our actions without ceasing: these may be observed in all persons and all ages, steady and universal; but these are INCLINATIONS OF THE APPETITE to good, not impressions of truth on the understanding. I deny not that there are natural tendencies imprinted on the minds of men; and that from the very first instances of sense and perception, there are some things that are grateful and others unwelcome to them; some things that they incline to and others that they fly: but this makes nothing for innate characters on the mind, which are to be the principles of knowledge regulating our practice. Such natural impressions on the understanding are so far from being confirmed hereby, that this is an argument against them; since, if there were certain characters imprinted by nature on the understanding, as the principles of knowledge, we could not but perceive them constantly operate in us and influence our knowledge, as we do those others on the will and appetite; which never cease to be the constant springs and motives of all our actions, to which we perpetually feel them strongly impelling us.
生成:
## The Elusive Nature of Innate Moral Principles: A Discourse on Action, Inclination, and the Absence of Universal Moral Truths

The human mind, a labyrinth of thought and emotion, has long grappled with the source of its moral compass. Are the principles that guide our actions, that whisper right from wrong, inherent truths etched upon our souls from birth, or are they acquired constructs, molded by the very fabric of our experiences? This question, steeped in philosophical debate for centuries, leads us down a path of introspection, forcing us to confront the very essence of morality and its role in the human experience. 

One school of thought, proponents of innate moral principles, posits that certain fundamental truths are woven into the fabric of our being, universal maxims that transcend cultural differences and societal norms. These principles, akin to self-evident truths like "What is, is," or "It is impossible for the same thing to be and not to be," are thought to form the bedrock of human morality, immutable and undeniable. 

However, a closer examination of the human condition, of the diverse tapestry of beliefs and actions that color our world, reveals a fundamental flaw in this line of reasoning. If moral principles were truly innate, universally acknowledged truths etched upon our very souls, wouldn't we expect a greater degree of consistency in their application? Shouldn't these principles, so deeply embedded in our being, manifest themselves uniformly across cultures and societies?

Alas, the reality paints a far more complex picture.  Moral principles, unlike the speculative maxims of logic and reason, are not universally accepted or self-evident.  Concepts like justice and truth, cornerstones of any moral framework, are interpreted and applied with a startling degree of variability.  What one culture holds as just and true, another might condemn as abhorrent and false. Even within the same society, interpretations of these principles can be fluid, evolving with the shifting sands of time and circumstance.

Furthermore, to argue that certain actions are inherently good or bad presupposes a universal understanding and acceptance of these moral principles, a claim that simply does not hold water upon closer inspection.  Take, for instance, the notion of justice. While most societies would agree that justice, in its purest form, strives for fairness and equity, the application of this principle often falls short of its lofty ideal.  Even groups operating outside the bounds of established law, groups often labeled as criminals or deviants, adhere to their own internal codes of justice and fairness.  Thieves, for example, may operate within a framework of rules and regulations that ensure a sense of order and fairness within their own ranks.  However, this adherence to internal codes of conduct stems not from an innate understanding of universal justice but rather from a pragmatic desire to maintain order and maximize their own self-interest within their chosen sphere of operation.

Some might argue that even if individuals do not explicitly acknowledge or consistently practice certain moral principles, they might still tacitly agree to them.  Perhaps these principles, while not always consciously applied, still lurk beneath the surface, influencing behavior in subtle and nuanced ways. This line of reasoning, however, fails to consider the inextricable link between belief and action.  If moral principles are truly ingrained within us, shouldn't they manifest themselves in our actions, the outward expressions of our inner beliefs?  To claim that individuals can genuinely believe in principles they routinely disregard is to sever the vital connection between thought and action, reducing morality to a mere theoretical construct devoid of practical application.

Practical principles, by their very nature, should lead to consistent action, not mere theoretical agreement. The disconnect between the professed belief in certain moral principles and the often contradictory actions of individuals casts serious doubt on the notion of innate morality.  If these principles were truly etched upon our souls, shouldn't they exert a more consistent and predictable influence on our behavior?

Instead of seeking the source of morality in some preordained set of principles, we might find more fruitful ground for exploration by examining the fundamental inclinations that shape human behavior.  Humans are, by nature, driven by a desire for happiness and an aversion to misery.  These are not lofty moral principles etched upon our understanding but rather innate inclinations of the appetite, powerful forces that guide our actions and shape our choices.  We gravitate towards that which brings pleasure and satisfaction while instinctively recoiling from pain and suffering. 

This inherent drive for happiness and avoidance of misery, while not inherently moral in nature, forms the foundation upon which we construct our moral frameworks. It is through the lens of these fundamental inclinations that we interpret our experiences, judge the actions of others, and ultimately, shape our own moral compasses. The desire for happiness, when channeled through the filter of reason and empathy, can lead to acts of altruism and compassion, while the same desire, if left unchecked by moral considerations, can manifest as greed, selfishness, and a callous disregard for the well-being of others.

Therefore, the inconsistencies we observe in the acknowledgment and practice of moral principles serve not to diminish the importance of morality but rather to highlight its complex and often contradictory nature. Morality, far from being an inherent set of unyielding truths, emerges from the crucible of human experience, shaped by our innate inclinations, cultural norms, and individual interpretations of right and wrong.  It is through the ongoing dialogue between our inherent desires and the social contracts we forge with one another that we navigate the complexities of the human condition, striving to create a world that aligns with our deeply held values, even as those values themselves continue to evolve.
summary:
The passage argues against the notion of innate moral principles, asserting that while speculative maxims (such as "What is, is" or "It is impossible for the same thing to be and not to be") are universally acknowledged, the same cannot be said for moral principles. The author points out that moral principles like justice and truth are not universally accepted or self-evident as innate knowledge should be. Even groups like thieves practice justice and fairness among themselves out of convenience rather than an inherent understanding of these principles.

Moreover, the passage rebuts the idea that people might tacitly agree to moral principles even if they don't practice them, emphasizing that actions are the best indicators of beliefs. The author asserts that practical principles should lead to consistent action, not mere theoretical agreement. Instead, the author acknowledges that while humans have innate desires for happiness and aversions to misery, these are inclinations of the appetite rather than imprinted truths on the understanding. Consequently, the inconsistencies in the acknowledgment and practice of moral principles further strengthen the argument that such principles are not innate.

原文:
No moral Principles so clear and so generally received as the forementioned speculative Maxims.
If those speculative Maxims, whereof we discoursed in the foregoing chapter, have not an actual universal assent from all mankind, as we there proved, it is much more visible concerning PRACTICAL Principles, that they come short of an universal reception: and I think it will be hard to instance any one moral rule which can pretend to so general and ready an assent as, “What is, is”; or to be so manifest a truth as this, that “It is impossible for the same thing to be and not to be.” Whereby it is evident that they are further removed from a title to be innate; and the doubt of their being native impressions on the mind is stronger against those moral principles than the other. Not that it brings their truth at all in question. They are equally true, though not equally evident. Those speculative maxims carry their own evidence with them: but moral principles require reasoning and discourse, and some exercise of the mind, to discover the certainty of their truth. They lie not open as natural characters engraved on the mind; which, if any such were, they must needs be visible by themselves, and by their own light be certain and known to everybody. But this is no derogation to their truth and certainty; no more than it is to the truth or certainty of the three angles of a triangle being equal to two right ones because it is not so evident as “the whole is bigger than a part,” nor so apt to be assented to at first hearing. It may suffice that these moral rules are capable of demonstration: and therefore it is our own faults if we come not to a certain knowledge of them. But the ignorance wherein many men are of them, and the slowness of assent wherewith others receive them, are manifest proofs that they are not innate, and such as offer themselves to their view without searching.
Faith and Justice not owned as Principles by all Men.
Whether there be any such moral principles, wherein all men do agree, I appeal to any who have been but moderately conversant in the history of mankind, and looked abroad beyond the smoke of their own chimneys. Where is that practical truth that is universally received, without doubt or question, as it must be if innate? JUSTICE, and keeping of contracts, is that which most men seem to agree in. This is a principle which is thought to extend itself to the dens of thieves, and the confederacies of the greatest villains; and they who have gone furthest towards the putting off of humanity itself, keep faith and rules of justice one with another. I grant that outlaws themselves do this one amongst another: but it is without receiving these as the innate laws of nature. They practise them as rules of convenience within their own communities: but it is impossible to conceive that he embraces justice as a practical principle who acts fairly with his fellow-highwayman, and at the same time plunders or kills the next honest man he meets with. Justice and truth are the common ties of society; and therefore even outlaws and robbers, who break with all the world besides, must keep faith and rules of equity amongst themselves; or else they cannot hold together. But will any one say, that those that live by fraud or rapine have innate principles of truth and justice which they allow and assent to?
Objection: though Men deny them in their Practice, yet they admit them in their Thoughts answered.
Perhaps it will be urged, that the tacit assent of their minds agrees to what their practice contradicts. I answer, first, I have always thought the actions of men the best interpreters of their thoughts. But, since it is certain that most men’s practices, and some men’s open professions, have either questioned or denied these principles, it is impossible to establish an universal consent, (though we should look for it only amongst grown men,) without which it is impossible to conclude them innate. Secondly, it is very strange and unreasonable to suppose innate practical principles, that terminate only in contemplation. Practical principles, derived from nature, are there for operation, and must produce conformity of action, not barely speculative assent to their truth, or else they are in vain distinguished from speculative maxims. Nature, I confess, has put into man a desire of happiness and an aversion to misery: these indeed are innate practical principles which (as practical principles ought) DO continue constantly to operate and influence all our actions without ceasing: these may be observed in all persons and all ages, steady and universal; but these are INCLINATIONS OF THE APPETITE to good, not impressions of truth on the understanding. I deny not that there are natural tendencies imprinted on the minds of men; and that from the very first instances of sense and perception, there are some things that are grateful and others unwelcome to them; some things that they incline to and others that they fly: but this makes nothing for innate characters on the mind, which are to be the principles of knowledge regulating our practice. Such natural impressions on the understanding are so far from being confirmed hereby, that this is an argument against them; since, if there were certain characters imprinted by nature on the understanding, as the principles of knowledge, we could not but perceive them constantly operate in us and influence our knowledge, as we do those others on the will and appetite; which never cease to be the constant springs and motives of all our actions, to which we perpetually feel them strongly impelling us.
